LEAD: Mildred E. Gillars, nicknamed Axis Sally by American soldiers in World War II for her Nazi propaganda radio broadcasts, died of cancer of the colon last Saturday at Grant Medical Center in Columbus, Ohio. She was 87 years old and lived in Columbus.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In true soap-opera style, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker walked off Centre Court this evening with the outcome of their semifinal match very much in doubt. Will Lendl, No. 1 in the world but frustrated time and again in his attempt to win Wimbledon, overcome what was a two-set deficit to reach a third consecutive final?

LEAD: Although noting that the prospects are ''bleak'' for any immediate relief from the drought gripping much of the Farm Belt, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said today that it was premature to consider Federal aid or other cash payments to assist farmers.

LEAD: Delegates to a Communist Party conference today approved a major overhaul of the Soviet political system in a stormy final session that included the first openly divided votes since the early years of the Soviet state.
LEAD: As many as 320,000 barbecues could be ruined this July 4 weekend because glass panels on new Sunbeam grills tend to shatter and sprinkle glass on the food below.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about the Pentagon procurement inquiry misidentified a company named in court documents. It is the C-Cubed Corporation, not C3 Inc.

LEAD: Hermann Cardinal Volk, the former Roman Catholic Bishop of Mainz and an advocate of ecumenism, died today after a lengthy illness, his press office said. He was 84 years old.

LEAD: Nearly three tons of cocaine was seized and three Colombians were arrested in a warehouse here Thursday night in what Federal officials said was the nation's largest seizure of cocaine outside of Florida, the authorities announced today.

LEAD: A Massachusetts Republican leader has criticized Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for campaigning for President outside the state on the day the state's fiscal year ended with a deficit of nearly $400 million.
LEAD: When asked what they are telling their home offices about Michael S. Dukakis, foreign diplomats are likely to say they do not interfere in America's affairs and move toward the canape tables.

LEAD: Richard Herrin, convicted in 1978 of killing his ex-girlfriend with a hammer while she slept in her Scarsdale home, has been denied parole for a second time because of the ''extreme gravity of the present offense,'' a state official said today.

LEAD: Two young girls were crushed to death and a third was severely injured yesterday when the front stoop and the archway of an apartment building in the East Village collapsed, the police said.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has reached out-of-court settlements with the families of almost all the victims of a fiery crash in May of a church bus in which 27 people were killed, lawyers said today.
LEAD: Top policy makers at the Federal Reserve voted in mid-May to push interest rates higher as a way of fighting inflationary pressures, according to minutes of the discussions released today.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci today halted payments to all contractors involved in nine military programs valued at nearly $1.7 billion because of evidence in court affidavits suggesting that competition for the contracts had been tainted by fraud.
LEAD: A prosecutor dropped criminal libel charges against a weekly newspaper editor today at the request of two legislators who said the case was giving the poor, rural area bad publicity.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions today extended through Sept. 28 buyer incentive programs that were scheduled to expire on Tuesday. Many of the Chevrolet rebates will be leaner, but Buick rebates will be unchanged except for those on the LeSabre, a spokeswoman said.
LEAD: Seven 3-year-old fillies, led by Goodbye Halo, have been entered in the Coaching Club American Oaks tomorrow at Belmont Park, the final leg of the New York filly triple crown series.

LEAD: Michael Harrington - champion of the poor, author of the influential ''The Other America,'' which helped to spur the war on poverty a quarter-century ago, co-chairman of the Democratic Socialists of America, distinguished professor of political science at Queens College - said yesterday that he considered it an honor to have been on President Nixon's ''enemies' list.
LEAD: Ron Guidry's night was finished in the fifth inning, when the evening was still in doubt. Later, as he sat in the Yankee clubhouse, he could not quite enjoy his accomplishment.
LEAD: THE patent battles are just beginning over TPA, or tissue plasminogen activator, the new genetic-engineered drug that helps dissolve blood clots in patients who have suffered a heart attack.

LEAD: Baseball Japan 12, United States 10: Japan, trailing by six runs after three innings, rallied for five runs in the fourth and scored twice in each of the last two innings to beat the American college all-stars, 12-10, in the fourth game of the annual Japan-United States Collegiate Series yesterday in Mito, Japan.

LEAD: Manfred Worner of West Germany began his term as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today with a pledge to seek progress in East-West arms talks.
LEAD: The dollar, shrugging off more central bank intervention, reached a new 1988 high against the yen in light trading yesterday and rose against the West German mark.

LEAD: Lionel Hampton and Wynton Marsalis, respectively the last active band leader from the big band era of the 1940's and the currently most publicized young jazz musician, shared a JVC Jazz Festival Concert on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Both Mr. Hampton and his big band and Mr. Marsalis and his quintet played programs that offered very little in the way of surprises or freshness.

LEAD: A pediatric surgeon has patented a new contraceptive based on a protein found in fetal tissue. The patent also covers a method for enhancing female fertility, based on antibodies to the same substance.

LEAD: Propelled by decades of frustration over unrepairable cars and unresponsive auto makers, state legislatures have rolled out one law after another to help owners exercise warranty rights. The auto industry, which has lost battles in 46 states since 1982, is now petitioning the Government for a law that would override some tough new state regulations.
LEAD: Touring the Western world with Peter Gabriel, a British rock singer, has changed Youssou N'Dour's music.

LEAD: Even as Stalinism's disastrous legacies come under attack in Moscow, the old tyrannical style flourishes in Rumania. Nicolae Ceausescu's harsh 20-year rule has turned one of Europe's traditional breadbaskets into a land of legendary deprivation. He has razed acres of ancient houses and churches in Bucharest, its once-elegant capital, to make a parade ground.

LEAD: An article on the Health page on Thursday about screening for breast cancer gave an incorrect percentage for women over 40 who said they had a mammogram in the last year; the correct figure was 17 percent. The article also imprecisely paraphrased a Federal recommendation for women between the ages of 40 and 50; they are urged to have mammograms every one or two years.

LEAD: Prices of all major farm crops rose yesterday, as commodity traders abandoned the caution they usually display before a long holiday weekend. The buying was attributed to forecasts of a hot, dry weekend in the nation's drought-ridden midsection.

LEAD: Even in the conservative wing of jazz, where undue ostentation is frowned upon, the pianist Dave McKenna represents an unusually staid presence. Mr. McKenna, who gave a solo performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday afternoon as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, is a dogged melodist who eschews fancy pyrotechnics, rarely wastes a note and, having established a tempo, holds to it with a metronomic accuracy.

LEAD: A Reporter's Notebook article yesterday about the Communist Party conference in Moscow misidentified the editor of the party newspaper Pravda. He is Viktor G. Afanasyev.
LEAD: Clarence (C) Sharpe and Billy Harper, two unjustly overlooked saxophonists, came to the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night as part of its jazz festival and performed wonderfully.

LEAD: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday in brisk trading before the Fourth of July holiday weekend.

LEAD: For the last three years the Reagan Administration was eager to see the dollar fall so that exports could climb. But during the dollar's remarkable surge in the last month, the officials in Washington have been uncommonly quiet.
LEAD: Laurence W. Beilenson, a lawyer who helped establish the Screen Actors Guild and other Hollywood unions in the 1930's, died of a stroke Monday. He was 89 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
LEAD: As a strike by 9,000 movie and television writers drags into its 18th week, it has become more than ever a psychological war.

LEAD: The spirit of her close friend, the late Alec Wilder, seemed to infuse the pianism of Marian McPartland during her solo concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday afternoon. Like Mr. Wilder, Miss McPartland is a musician who does not find jazz incompatible with semiclassical instrumental music of a wistful impressionistic sort.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Space workers will hold a special Fourth of July ceremony when they move the space shuttle Discovery to the launch pad to be readied for the first shuttle mission since the Challenger disaster.

LEAD: The NEC Corporation, a leading Japanese electronics maker, said this week that it would set up an institute in Princeton, N.J., to conduct computer and communications research. The institute will start work next May, NEC said.
LEAD: ''We want a convention just like our candidate: organized, orderly and short.''

LEAD: With a long-running hit still occupying its main stage at the Vivian Beaumont, Lincoln Center Theater is planning to stage the Beaumont's next season at the Lyceum, a Broadway theater on West 45th Street, instead of on its home turf at Lincoln Center.
LEAD: The Iraqi Foreign Minister acknowledged today that his country had used chemical weapons in its war against Iran, but said Iran had used them first.
LEAD: Cleaning up the radioactive and chemical pollution caused by the manufacture of nuclear bombs will cost $40 billion to $110 billion, a report by the Department of Energy said yesterday.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Coca-Cola Company misstated the company's public stance, in some editions, on its use of a non-narcotic derivative of the coca plant. Coca-Cola has previously acknowledged that coca is an ingredient in its cola.
LEAD: In a major retreat by its chairman, Frank Lorenzo, the Texas Air Corporation announced yesterday that it was canceling the sale of its Eastern Airlines shuttle to a new subsidiary.

LEAD: Rescue workers today found the bodies of five people, including a senior Spanish transportation official, after the official's helicopter crashed in a storm north of Madrid. A Civil Guard spokesman said the bodies of the chief of highway traffic, Rosa de Lima Manzano, and four men were found near the wreckage on a 4,800-foot-high peak near La Cabrera, a town 45 miles north of Madrid.

LEAD: Paul Riesman, former chairman of the anthropology department at Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., died of an aneurysm Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital, near his summer home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 50 years old and lived in Northfield.
LEAD: ''The shufflers are here,'' someone yelled out, and all the regulars at Lagoda's Saloon looked up to see the end of an era.
LEAD: Eight nonprofit professional theaters were awarded a total of $336,000 this week by the Fund for New American Plays to assist productions of original American plays in the coming season.

LEAD: The Connecticut Light and Power Co. filed formal applications today with the State Department of Public Utility Control to raise its natural gas and electricity rates a combined total of almost $116 million a year. The company had notified the department in May that it would file the applications seeking its first increase in rates since 1983.

LEAD: Chuck Daly, the most successful coach in the 31-year history of the Detroit Pistons, acknowledged yesterday that he had agreed to a multiyear contract with the team, which he led into the championship round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.
LEAD: In a rare public display of unity, three Cambodian opposition forces have agreed on a common front for coming talks with the Cambodian Government and Vietnam.

LEAD: It is the time of year when night in much of Finland means the sun lowers itself onto the horizon and perches there until morning, when you can read on a park bench at midnight and when this northern nation's boys of summer thrill their countrymen in contests of pesapallo, or Finnish baseball.

Brown of Southborough, Mass., were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye. The Rev. John McCarthy performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Two clerks at an all-night grocery were shot to death in Brooklyn early yesterday during an $800 robbery, the police said.

LEAD: M.T.M. Entertainment Inc., the highly successful television production company co-founded by the actress Mary Tyler Moore, has agreed to be acquired by a British production company, published reports say.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in New York yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Reagan Adminstration's regulations banning Federal aid to public health clinics that provide abortion counseling or referrals.

LEAD: Five firefighters battling flames inside an automobile dealership in downtown Hackensack, N.J., were killed in a cataract of burning timbers yesterday when the roof of the blazing building collapsed on them, fire officials said.

LEAD: ''A reasonable mistake in judgment'' was the most probable cause of a collision of two Army helicopters that killed 17 soldiers during night training here in March, a report by Army investigators said today.

LEAD: In a sport of overnight sensations and phenoms too young to attend R-rated movies, Stefan Edberg of Sweden was not progressing fast enough to suit his critics. He is No. 3 in the world and a two-time winner of the Australian Open, but is characterized as lacking determination, perhaps courage, when it really matters.
LEAD: Declarers who blunder in the play often offer the time-honored excuse: ''I had a blind spot.'' This seldom mollifies their partners.

LEAD: The spirit of Michel Fokine presided over the performance that Dance Theater of Harlem offered Thursday night at the City Center as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. One of the three works was by Fokine himself, another was a new version of a work created by him and the third might never have existed if it had not been for precedents set by this great balletic reformer.

LEAD: Bo Jackson, the outfielder-running back who suffered a severely torn left hamstring May 31, may be activated any day by the Kansas City Royals. . . . Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos, who coached his team to the last two Super Bowls, underwent surgery for the removal of a kidney stone Thursday in Denver.

LEAD: Reforms of New York City's overworked foster care system have awaited the outcome of a 15-year-old lawsuit aimed at curbing the influence of sectarian agencies. Now a Federal appeals court has cleared the way, giving responsibility for reform to the city and the private agencies that provide the services under contract.

LEAD: THIS was as close to a sure thing as there is in tennis. Even though Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf had been in three tournaments this year without crossing paths, everyone knew they would finally meet on Centre Court at Wimbledon in the final. According to London bookmakers, people bet so heavily on the likelihood of this happening that there was no second choice worth mentioning.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it would invest $80 million in a project to build a new line of engines at its plant in Tonawanda, N.Y. The Mark V engine, a V-8 that is designed for use in pickup trucks, motor homes and boats, is to be introduced in the 1991 model year. The Tonawanda plant employs 4,300 and produced 1.4 million engines in 1987.
LEAD: Takeovers continued to sweep corporate America in the second quarter, producing some of the biggest gains in the stock market during the period.

LEAD: The Defense Department's decision to freeze nine military equipment programs today because of reported contracting irregularities caught Pentagon managers completely by surprise, and left them wondering how they would put Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci's order into effect.

LEAD: Canada's one-dollar coin will completely replace the paper dollar bill within two years, the Government has announced. The coin was introduced last year under a plan to save taxpayers $175 million (Canadian) over 20 years because coins have a longer circulation life than paper bills. Public acceptance of the gold-colored 11-sided coin has been limited, but the Government has said that production of dollar bills will end on June 30, 1989, and that the bills will cease to be legal tender about a year later.

LEAD: ''MANSFIELD PARK,'' with its evangelical earnestness and lack of wit, has never been counted among Jane Austen's most popular novels. As the American critic Lionel Trilling wrote, ''There is scarcely one of our modern pieties that it does not offend.''

LEAD: DAVID SMYTH was trained at the Art Institute of Chicago but he trails none of the strangeness associated with Chicago art. His paintings, on view at the Alan Brown Gallery in Hartsdale (210 East Hartsdale Avenue), contain no otherworldly grotesquerie that would link him with artists such as Jim Nutt, Ed Paschke or Ellen Lanyon, to cite a few examples.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Justice Department's longstanding program to prosecute fraud at the Pentagon and among military contractors was criticized today in a report by Congress's General Accounting Office.

LEAD: For the past 14 years, Artpark, a 200-acre space along the Niagara River gorge, has offered the unusual combination of performing arts, painting and sculpture exhibitions and just plain relaxation. LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Briggs Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ashley Catlin Briggs to Jason Ruggles Bernhard, a son of Mrs. John H. Updike of Beverly, Mass., and Alexander A. Bernhard of Boston.

LEAD: BUD Greenspan's film remembrance of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, ''16 Days of Glory,'' is filled with poignant moments. None describes the fragility and frustrations of athletic success more than the scene of John Moffet on crutches.
LEAD: To the Editor:

A Vietnam veteran turned detective checks out dubious entrepreneurs. 2 * 11 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers.

LEAD: Carving Out an Attitude Michael Crichton was a doctor before he became a best-selling novelist. Here he describes the evolution of a young physician's feelings as he dissects a human face. This is one of many pieces in his collection ''Travels'' (Knopf).
LEAD: The Australian national team won as expected, the Syracuse eight lost as expected, and the treatment of the Queen's swans caused a stir today at the 144th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta.

LEAD: Fairfield, Conn. $300,000 264 Crestwood Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 20-year-old colonial; in-ground pool, 102- by 144-foot lot; taxes $2,939. Meriden, Conn. $140,000 42 Old Stagecoach Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 35-year-old ranch; large deck, full basement, c/a; taxes $1,459.

LEAD: At a time of coup rumors, back-room maneuvering and some handholding from the American Embassy, the Salvadoran Army high command has begun making major command changes that could affect the course of the civil war.
LEAD: The great cabana controversy is finally over.

LEAD: The evidence so far suggests that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy may be at least marginally more conservative than Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., the pivotal centrist he replaced, on issues including criminal law, the death penalty and perhaps civil rights.
LEAD: During the last decade, Long Islanders have been witnessing a David and Goliath scenario. The modern-day heroine is Nora Bredes.

LEAD: To the Editor: Sound the hurrahs for Ruth Wolff's paean to the unhurried and unregimented traveler (''Innocence Abroad,'' Travel, May 1). With the proliferation of guidebooks and ultraspecialized tours, it is a wonder that any traveler can just be left alone to savor wandering among streets, dropping in on unsuspecting shopkeepers, meandering to the point of even getting lost in quaint streets and parks, looking at sights for the sheer beauty of their ''being'' rather than of their attested place in history.

LEAD: Mrs. Fred Dixon of Spartanburg, S.C., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Patricia Dixon, to Arnold Zeitlin, the son of Mrs. Morris Zeitlin of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Mr. Zeitlin. An Aug. 20 wedding is planned.

LEAD: WITH the summer season now under way in earnest, numbers are already up from last year at Long Island's beach resorts, and complaints of overcrowded conditions, especially on weekends, have become widespread.

LEAD: MY DAUGHTER IS an athlete. Nowadays, this statement won't strike many parents as unusual, but it does me. Until her freshman year in high school, Ann was only marginally interested in sport of any kind. When she played, she didn't swing hard, often dropped the ball, and had an annoying habit of tittering on field or court.

LEAD: As she stood at the umpire's chair during the postmatch ceremony - trying to keep a stiff upper lip in the best British tradition -Martina Navratilova could have closed her eyes and recited all the parts by heart. This was the ninth time she had played a major role in this slice of Wimbledon pomp and circumstance, having become as much of a fixture on Centre Court as the Duke and Duchess of Kent.

LEAD: Q. We are building a new house that will have brick veneer on the lower half of the front wall (brick over block). I have heard that treating brick with silicone helps prevent penetration of water and the development of pressure cracks. Where can I find out about this and can I do it myself?

LEAD: Beth Ellen Jacobs, a senior vice president and the head of the international institutional-equity division of Shearson Lehman Hutton, and Dr. Keith Michael Gottesdiener, an assistant professor of clinical medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, were married last evening.

LEAD: You had an interesting account of Sea Cliff's Victorian houses [ ''Sea Cliff Adjusts to Historic Listing,'' June 12 ] . But I would like to tell you what I told the Landmarks Association. It is a well-established fact that 112 Sea Cliff Avenue was built in 1884. The date of 1887 is wrong. In 1888 the tower wing was added, and of course the tower is the most conspicuous feature of the house.
LEAD: Before George Steinbrenner dismissed Billy Martin, the Yankees had two major problems. Now they have one. If only Steinbrenner would dismiss himself. ALAN J. ERICKSON Leonia, N.J.

LEAD: Tim Miller's ''Some Golden States,'' presented at the downstairs theater of Performance Space 122 on Friday night, is a geographical and psychological tour that promises much. Autobiographical stage journeys can be fascinating, and this autobiography focuses on the coming-of-age of a young homosexual in the late 1970's and early 1980's - a time marked by the killing of Harvey Milk, a San Francisco city supervisor who was one of the country's first publicly avowed gay politicans, and by the first awareness of AIDS and its apparent singling out of homosexuals.
LEAD: MANY school boards say they are finding increased taxpayer resistance to education spending this year, as budgets grow because of higher teachers' salaries.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Getting dogs to appear asleep, geese to open their beaks and white doves to fly into darkness are just some of the tricks of Carlene White's trade.

LEAD: Closings in the week ending June 18 MANHATTAN East Midtown $829,000 721 Fifth Avenue (56th St.) (Trump Tower) 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 800-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, manned elevator, dining area, 2 exposures; common charge $750, taxes $1,320 (Broker: Corcoran Group)
LEAD: FATAL LIGHT By Richard Currey. 195 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/E. P. Dutton. $16.95.
LEAD: DON KING said that Bill Cayton was ''Satan in disguise.''

LEAD: CONSIDER A DROP IN THE ocean. This is what they're doing, on a rather grand scale, at the California Academy of Sciences, the 138-year-old museum in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. Part of a massive new exhibit entitled Wild California that is scheduled to open Oct. 9 and intended to illustrate the diversity of habitats and ecosystems within the state, the Sea Meadow diorama will represent life forms extant in a random squirt of coastal sea water -magnified 200 times.

LEAD: WHEN Pierre Elliott Trudeau stepped down after 15 years as Canada's Prime Minister in 1984, he told a friend that he had not realized before taking the job how limited its powers would turn out to be. Rarely did he have any real choices, he complained; almost everything was hemmed in by the ''realities'' imposed by previous governments, the powers of the provinces, the country's membership in the Western alliance and, above all, its proximity to the United States.

LEAD: Do creative artists wilt or thrive under the summer sun? Here are reports from 10 of them. Garrison Keillor, humorist: New York's been very good to me this summer - in fact, it's an easy haul here compared to Minnesota, where everything's drying up. My calender is absolutely free - it's like being a kid again, with no commitments except family birthdays and the like.

LEAD: As workers continued removing the rubble of a building stoop that collapsed Friday in the East Village, killing two girls and injuring a third, the chidren's stunned families began making funeral arrangements yesterday.

LEAD: AS the drought threatens crops in the Middle West, the prospects for the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company are beginning to look a bit shaky. The Decatur, Ill., company is a major grain processor and continued high grain prices could put a major squeeze on its profits in the fiscal year 1989, which began July 1.

LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim withdrew a slander suit on Friday that had been filed against Edgar M. Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, a spokesman said. Last year, Mr. Bronfman called Mr. Waldheim ''part and parcel of the Nazi killing machine.''

LEAD: Never mind the embarrassments like fighting in a topless bar in Texas and throwing handfuls of dirt at an umpire. Boys will be boys even if they are 60 years old. What really staggers the mind is that Billy Martin cannot manage any longer. Where did the inherently correct managerial decisions disappear to?

LEAD: HAVING FINALLY MADE A PACT with his own grease-painted devil, Simon Callow has been reaping critical praise in the title role of a seven-and-a-half-hour production of Goethe's ''Faust,'' a rarely performed work which just completed a run here that succeeded beyond his most infernal dreams.
LEAD: Some questions that Mikhail Gorbachev provoked when he launched the Soviet Union on reforms can now be answered. Others remain open and even bigger ones have arisen.
LEAD: Jeff Robinson pitched a two-hitter, and Darrell Evans, Pat Sheridan and Dave Bergman hit home runs today as the Detroit Tigers defeated the California Angels, 6-1.
LEAD: Some noteworthy defenders, past and present, Gold Glove and otherwise, define their positions: FIRST BASE

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sloan Wilson of Winter Park, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Ruth Wilson, to David William Geen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Geen of Pelham Manor, N.Y. Miss Wilson and her fiance, graduates of the University of Rochester, plan to marry Aug. 27.
LEAD: MUSICALS aren't written; they're rewritten.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Joan Baker Tower of Aiken, S.C., and Vinalhaven, Me., of the engagement of her daughter Elin Elisofon to David Cushing Fogg, a son of Mrs. George P. Fogg Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Coconut Grove, Fla., and the late Mr. Fogg. The couple plan to marry in September.

LEAD: THE CREW TENSES AS SIRENS WAIL AND warning lights wink on. All but one of the space shuttle's three main engines have mysteriously failed minutes after takeoff, leaving the ship crippled dozens of miles above the choppy Atlantic. Previously, the only option would have been a potentially deadly controlled crash in the water.

LEAD: PASSENGERS at Newark International Airport's recently opened Terminal C can now expect to collect their baggage from arriving flights within 15 minutes, say officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the 2,000-acre airport.

LEAD: ' An inevitable problem in a pluralistic society . . . is how does a religious body like the Catholic Church, with a declared stance against artificial contraception, cooperate with other religious and civic groups who do not share our moral viewpoint. ' - Bishop Stanley J. Ott of Baton Rouge, commenting in an unusual public dispute among the nation's Roman Catholic bishops over whether the church should approve disseminating information on the use of condoms to fight AIDS.

LEAD: RECENTLY, the International Business Machines Corporation announced a trade-in policy for personal computers; bring in your old I.B.M. PC, XT or AT and get a discount on a new PS/2 computer. It is a significant move on I.B.M.'s part, one that deserves attention from other computer makers as well, although the trade-in allowances that are offered do not seem to reflect realistic market values.

LEAD: Since last month's economic summit conference in Toronto, the dollar has risen against all major currencies. The dollar is now stronger against the West German mark and the yen, than at any time since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse. With the exception of West Germany, the central banks of the major trading nations are doing little to support their currencies against the dollar.

LEAD: ''THE poor performance of large numbers of black and Puerto Rican children was the chief cause of criticism of the school system in the 1960's. It was not providing basic literacy to a sizable proportion of its students; it was not abating crime and poverty; it was not molding good citizens . . . Reformers did not realize that the same charges had been leveled periodically over the previous 150 years.

LEAD: SOMETHING of an impasse has developed in the case of Richard Angelo, the former altar boy and Eagle Scout who was arrested seven months ago on charges of murdering patients at a hospital on Long Island by injecting them with muscle paralyzers.

LEAD: To the Editor: I beg to differ with the assessment of hotels in the Soviet Union. Traveling two years ago this spring, staying over in seven cities -Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Yalta, Tashkent, Samarkand and Bukhara - I felt spoiled by the superlative quarters providing good-size beds, spruced-up furnishings and, with one exception, clean and up-to-the-minute bathrooms.
LEAD: Philip G. Reed, a reporter and wire service executive for four decades, died of emphysema last Thursday at Waterbury Hospital in Connecticut. He was 79 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.
LEAD: AN AMERICAN RHAPSODY: THE STORY OF GEORGE GERSHWIN by Paul Kresh. Lodestar Books. 166 pages. $14.95.

LEAD: For a few hours this week the East Palo Alto Police Department locked its doors, borrowed officers from neighboring suburbs to patrol the city's mean streets and turned out in dress blues to mourn the first local officer killed in the line of duty.

LEAD: TWO challenges suggest themselves in connection with the diagramed deal. The first is to decide whether you would wish to play or defend a contract of six hearts. If you choose to defend, you must specify an opening lead. The second is to name the field with which the North player, named Everton Weekes, is connected.

LEAD: NIGHT OVER DAY OVER NIGHT. By Paul Watkins. (Knopf, $17.95.) Paul Watkins, a 23-year-old American, has written a first novel as obscure as its title. Told in the first person, it traces the declining psychic fortunes of a 17-year-old German who joins the SS in late 1944 and winds up fighting in the Battle of the Bulge.

LEAD: Janet Susan Granger and Thomas Edward Sacci, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Sacci of Bedford Hills, N.Y., plan to marry in September, the future bride's mother, Susan Granger of Westport, Conn., has announced.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy H. Dole of Bronxville, N.Y., and Dorset, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Sanford Dole to David John Berard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. George Berard of Pittstown, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: A Travel Advisory chart on June 12 gave an incorrect telephone number for information on automatic teller machines that provide local currency to Visa cardholders overseas. Holders of Visa gold cards may get information by calling 800-336-3386 or, in Alaska and Hawaii, 800-336-3379. A holder of a regular card may ask the issuing bank for a list of overseas cash machines.

LEAD: THE outcome of the dispute will not determine the winner of the World Series this year. Nor will it put anyone into or keep anyone out of the Hall of Fame. Yet it may be time to reconsider the method by which baseball's most prolific run producers are determined.
LEAD: ''Someday, I will tell my grandchildren that I was here,'' said Khashbikar Bokov, ''that I was part of the revolution.''

LEAD: It's not quite perestroika, but in Mexico, too, an entrenched party and keeper of the orthodox revolutionary flame is challenged by a new leader who urges bold democratic reform to rescue a tottering system. As in the Soviet Union, this challenge comes not from the opposition but from within the ruling party itself.
LEAD: The Supreme Court has ended its 1987-88 term on a moderate but unsteady course, with hints that a more conservative majority may be emerging.

LEAD: ALERTED to a slow sale of closed-circuit television tickets for his 1975 title bout with Joe Bugner in Malaysia, Muhammad Ali sat serenely high in the Kuala Lumpur Hilton and formally announced his retirement as the world heavyweight champion.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was back from the Soviet Union less than 36 hours when I read the May 22 Travel section. It was fun to retrace my steps and find out what I'd missed. There was one hint that I'd like to have known before I went, however, which your article also overlooked: It is almost impossible to spend rubles.

And dutifully we would roll across the Whitestone Bridge and exit at the Belmont

LEAD: Of all the city's prominent black politicians, Representative Floyd H. Flake of Queens is considered the most friendly to Mayor Koch. And of all the city's prominent black politicians, Mr. Flake, a minister as well as a politician, probably has the most to gain from his friend at City Hall.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FOR the first time in a major league career that began in 1966, Don Sutton, a 324-game winner, has been placed on the disabled list. It happened Friday night in Los Angeles, where the Dodgers assigned Sutton to the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to last Wednesday. Sutton, 43 years old, did not get a decision in his last start, a 4-3 loss to Houston Tuesday night, and complained afterward of a sore right elbow.

LEAD: Therese Marie Marion's engagement to Scott Christopher Linksey, a son of Judith Linskey of Fairfield, Conn., and Patrick M. Linskey of Darien, Conn., has been made known by her parents, Mary Anne Marion of Fairfield and John L. Marion of New York.
LEAD: Tell Billy not to skip town. As soon as ticket sales drop, George will remember how much he loves Billy. BARRY PINCHEFSKY New York

LEAD: STATE Transportation Commissioner Hazel Frank Gluck is looking to state-supported regional groups, working with business and government, as the linchpin of an effort to reduce traffic delays for hundreds of thousands of commuters.

LEAD: BARBECUE MEANS DIFFERENT things to different people. To someone from the Carolinas, it is shredded pork in a vinegar-based sauce. In California, it is synonymous with grilling outdoors. And according to the barbecue wizard of the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area, Robert Pearson, ''Northerners think of barbecue as a sugary, syrupy sauce that you put on ribs and chicken and that gives everything a burned taste.

LEAD: When a superior horse beats lesser rivals by an unexpectedly small margin, racetrackers often say that he won it on class alone. That was exactly how Seeking the Gold looked winning the $228,400 Dwyer Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: To the Editor: In the guide to Moscow's subway system and the palatial stations, the incredibly low fare of 5 kopecks or 1/20 of a ruble retained for their use is cited. But how does one arrive at the U.S. equivalent of ''about 3 cents''? According to the official rate imposed on tourists, whereby the ruble is worth almost as much as the British pound, 5 kopecks would equal about 8 U.S.

LEAD: LIFE BEING THE BEST & OTHER STORIES. By Kay Boyle. Edited by Sandra Whipple Spanier. (New Directions, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.) This collection of short stories celebrates the enduring artistic discipline of Kay Boyle, who, unlike some of her better-known peers, survived the halcyon days of Paris in the 1920's.

LEAD: ONE of the biggest problems plaguing the amusement park industry in recent years has been the continued shortage of summer employees, which has reached crippling proportions. As the pool of likely applicants has shrunk, a severe shortage of workers has forced the summer closure of some portions of parks, especially in the Northeast.

Brogan of Marquette, Mich., and the late Mr. Brogan, were married yesterday at the Pilgrim Church in Lake Geneva. The Rev. Wilbur H. Bartholomew, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To the Editor: Bill Keller, in his article about Riga ''Off the Beaten Path in Changing Nation, writes: ''The city's pride is the magnificent Lutheran Cathedral.''

LEAD: FOR months, Neil Cunningham has been tracking the maze of pipelines that crisscross Nepera Inc.'s sprawling plant here, probing the thousands of fittings to measure chemicals leaking into the air in this bucolic Orange County community.

LEAD: AT the height of his popularity in 1985, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi said that ''people's expectations are scary'' and that he could not possibly fulfill everyone's hopes. Today his political troubles are so grave that he spends much of his time assuring his advisers that the future is not as bleak as it seems.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After he began managing other people's money six years ago at the age of 31, Roberto C. Polo apparently came to consider his own comfort to be a good investment for his clients. By the time he was 37, Mr. Polo had homes, offices and art collections in New York, Paris and Geneva. But eyebrows rose as the former mid-level bank officer began to consume more conspicuously than his clients.
LEAD: An article on June 5 about the Midwest misidentified a home-run hitter in the 1960 World Series; he was Bill Mazeroski. The article also misidentified the losing pitcher; he was Ralph Terry.
LEAD: FROM fire departments and ambulance services to Little League baseball and city boards, the pinch for volunteers in Connecticut is becoming tighter.
LEAD: ''Someday, I will tell my grandchildren that I was here, that I was part of the revolution.'' - Khashbikar Bokov, a delegate to the 19th Communist Party conference. [ 6:1. ]

These lightweight materials can withstand very high temperatures making them ideal replacements for some metals in the aerospace, chemical and automobile industries. Dr. Maxine L. Savitz, director of the Garrett Ceramic Components Division of the Allied-Signal Aerospace Company, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about the state of ceramic research.

LEAD: The National Institutes of Health, yielding to Congressional pressure, has reversed its decision and will continue its $22 million program to develop an artificial human heart.

LEAD: Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia, left, clasping hands with Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut, third from right, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania yesterday at the Civil War battlefield in Pennsylvania. The occasion was the 125th Anniversary of the Union victory there in 1863.

LEAD: JAPANESE connoisseurs have an old saying: ''One, Raku; two, Hagi; three, Karatsu.'' They have long ranked the most precious ceramic wares made for the tea ceremony in this order. The charms of Hagi ware's rough clay and rich, pockmarked surfaces, laced with cracks in the glaze, take on character and deeper tones with age and use.

LEAD: Sarah Vaughan was understandably miffed during her Carnegie Hall concert on Thursday evening. The hall's unreliable sound system made it difficult for the singer to hear the members of her own backup trio. And the thin, watery sound that emanated from the stage left Andrew Simpkins's bass semi-audible and George Gaffney's piano an ineffectual tinkle.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II has had it with Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre. The generation-long dispute between the Swiss Archbishop and the Vatican began when the Archbishop denounced the church's mid-1960's liberalizations and kept to such Roman Catholic traditions as the Latin mass. He said the church had been infiltrated by ''wolves and thieves'' and was consumed by the ''cancer of liberalism.
LEAD: Melissa Brown and Mark Lambert Clifford were married yesterday at the Stowe (Vt.) Community Church by the Rev. Bruce Comiskey.

LEAD: EUROPEAN fashion houses, including Fendi, Valentino and Genny, are providing accessories to go with their ready-to-wear. Handbags, scarves, belts, gloves and shoes are designed to add pizazz to suits, dresses and separates.

LEAD: THE language used by lenders to describe their adjustable-rate mortgage offerings is hard to understand at best. But one option stands out for its complexity: the ''index,'' or the standard on which the adjustments in monthly payments will be based.
LEAD: NO one denies that the rapacious, powerful bluefish is fun to catch, but there is sharp disagreement over its merit on the dining table.
LEAD: THROUGHOUT Anatoly Karpov's numerous encounters with Gary Kasparov, it could be emphasized that the former world champion was bloody but uncowed. Is this still true?

LEAD: To the Editor: The Beriozkas in Moscow do indeed have a tempting variety of artistic items as Esther Fein said, but visitors should take with them heavy-duty capacious plastic sacks with sturdy handles or all they will bring home will be regrets over the beautiful things left behind because the flimsy paper bags supplied in the dollar shops can't make it to the airport in Moscow, and purchases made in Russia may not be shipped no matter how bulky they might be or how costly.

LEAD: Certainly not. Because with Billy Martin gone (for now) we fans will have to be fed a steady diet of real baseball news: like hits, runs and errors. Besides, Billy looked so happy as he watched from the dugout. Always smiling. That's our Billy. But all this hardly matters, for some time during the next six months, Martin will be named manager again.

LEAD: PEPSICO Summerfare is back at the State University of New York at Purchase, with a shorter schedule and many fewer events than last year but with some very exciting musical firsts among them.

LEAD: Kimberly Anne Charles, a daughter of Maj. Gen. and Mrs. William Miller Charles of Wichita, Kan., was married yesterday to David Richard Schrage, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Schrage of Ledyard, Conn. The Rev. James L. Pratt performed the ceremony at the Noank (Conn.) Baptist Church.

LEAD: TO THOSE WHO FOLLOW CONTEMPORARY art, the large rock behind Daniel Chester French's tiny second studio in Stockbridge, Mass., may seem strangely familiar. That's because its form, transposed onto a thin aluminum skin, reappeared on 57th Street in an untitled sculpture by Robert Lobe. Mr. Lobe, who lives in New York, spent the summer of 1985 living and working at Chesterwood, French's estate, in the popular 19th-century artist's former studio.

LEAD: EVER since the rehabilitation of South Norwalk began six years ago with the conversion of 1890's factories on Washington Street into fashionable condominiums and shops, the anticipated upgrading of surrounding streets has been markedly slow.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, has been the focus of hopes for improved New York City schools, much of the power over the schools belongs not to him but to the 288 members of community school boards. Should this 20-year-old decentralized system be changed? And if so, how?

LEAD: Not so long ago, it seemed the nearby Fresh Kills landfill would fill up quicker than Teleport I. The first speculative office building at the 100-acre Teleport Satellite Communication Center in northwestern Staten Island was only 60 percent occupied in January, a year after opening. Potential tenants were discouraged by the center's remote location between Victory Boulevard and South Avenue off the West Shore
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that he will go to the floor of the Democratic National Convention to push for a dozen of his policy proposals in the party's platform.

LEAD: WAINSCOTT'S newest restaurant, Sapore di Mare, is seafood, Italian and very Hamptons. If a movie maker were trying to catch the essence of the East End, Sapore di Mare would be perfect for location shots. It blossoms with an airy, summer aura: white stucco walls, wood and terra-cotta tile floors, ceiling fans, leafy palms and flower-encircled screened porches.

LEAD: PAINTBRUSHES and roller covers (the woolly sleeves that fit onto the roller and spread the paint) seldom receive the care they need. LEAD: MOMENTUM: Women in American Politics Now. By Ronna Romney and Beppie Harrison. (Crown, $18.95.) In 1973, there were 16 women in the House of Representatives. Fifteen years later, there are 23. That barely qualifies as progress, let alone the ''momentum'' of the title of this breezy, upbeat account of the current status of women in American political life.

LEAD: The ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party has never lost a presidential election, and Carlos Salinas de Gortari is virtually certain to continue that streak next Wednesday. But for the first time, the party cannot be absolutely sure of its prospects in another election: that of the 64 senators and 500 deputies to be chosen the same day.

LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation disclosed Friday that it purchased a health club in Ocala, Fla., little more than a year after one of its executives reportedly played a role in financially aiding a Florida Congressman who then had an interest in the spa.

LEAD: Eastport is in Southhampton - the Long Island town, that is, not the village - but not quite on the South Fork. Still, Robert Levitas, the developer of a 98-home project under way there, says that this one-time farming village is directly in the path of the westward expansion of the Hamptons. Already, he said, Eastport is ''really indistinguishable from Westhampton,'' though some brahmin beachcombers would argue.
LEAD: A 24-year-old Bronx man was shot to death outside a nightclub in Chelsea early yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: TO stand on the roof of the world is an experience that most of us believe we'll never have. To know what it's like to climb a major mountain and gain an eagle's-eye view, we have to be armchair mountaineers, relying on books or films. But a cable car line in Zermatt allows a reasonably fit person with no climbing experience to make such a climb, safely accompanied by a licensed mountain guide, and taste the thrill of true mountaineering - a brief membership in one of the world's most exclusive clubs.

Harrington of the State Police said officers arrested the owner of the property and 47 spectators and seized 80 fighting birds, $22,000 and birds' spurs.

LEAD: The women's singles final today at Wimbledon, matching top-seeded Steffi Graf against the second-seeded defending champion, Martina Navratilova, will be held after the completion of the men's semifinal between Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, which was suspended yesterday with Becker ahead, 2 sets to 1.

LEAD: NORTH STONINGTON FAIR The first major fair of the Connecticut season is the 24-year-old North Stonington Agricultural Fair, which opens Thursday with dozens of exhibits and events that attract more than 20,000 visitors.

LEAD: AFTER suffering for several decades from a reputation as unsafe, unclean and unsavory, the amusement park was transformed with the opening of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., in 1955. In the years since, the family orientation so successfully exploited by Walt Disney continues to be the driving force behind amusement park development.

LEAD: The coffin of Leonard Matlovich being carried to Congressional Cemetary yesterday in Washington. Mr. Matlovich was discharged from the Air Force in 1975 after declaring his homosexuality. Mr. Matlovich, 44 years old, died June 22 in California of complications from AIDS. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: IT IS AN EVEN-MONEY BET THAT despite a slightly higher voter turnout in this year's Presidential primaries, the turnout in November may fall to the lowest level in 40 years.

LEAD: A FLURRY of recent studies have confirmed what many gay-rights groups say they already knew: Harassment and crimes against homosexuals are increasing. Moreover, gay-rights advocates say, the incidents are becoming more violent.

LEAD: A leader of the Polish underground, Kornel Morawiecki, is hoping that American pressure will persuade the Warsaw authorities, who expelled him two months ago, to let him return to Poland and his family.

LEAD: STREAK: Joe DiMaggio and the Summer of '41. By Michael Seidel. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Baseball has its magic numbers: 2,130 (the number of consecutive games that Lou Gehrig played in over the course of 14 years), 511 (the number of career pitching victories racked up by Cy Young) and 56 (the number of consecutive games in which Joe DiMaggio hit safely in 1941).
LEAD: To the Editor: Philip Taubman and Tim Sandler's articles about going around on one's own in the Soviet Union offer superb advice.

LEAD: The Galveston City Council has approved a law requiring pit bull terriers and other animals designated to be vicious to wear fluorescent yellow collars.
LEAD: For 68 years, the state of Maine has supplied owners of small wood lots throughout the state with low-cost seedlings to replant land stripped of timber.

LEAD: The practice of trading New York City's approval of development projects for unrelated public amenities is a form of uneven taxation that distorts government and should be stopped, a report submitted to Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate has charged.

LEAD: I ONCE took a train from Warsaw to Athens, passing through every Eastern European country but East Germany, and watched with wonder as storybook towns passed my view and ancient laborers crowded my compartment. Winding through the Transylvanian Alps at dawn, we came upon horse-drawn sleighs in the snow and whole villages built of timber, the houses tall and balconied and painted in the pastel shades of butter mints.

LEAD: With the publication of the anonymous article ''It's Over, Debbie,'' the Journal of the American Medical Association brought to public consciousness the issue of euthanasia and the physician's role in it.

LEAD: Auto Racing Elliott Wins by Inches: Bill Elliott held off Rick Wilson yesterday to win the Firecracker 400 Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Elliott, who started 38th in the 42-car field, did not lead until 23 laps from the end of the 400-mile, 160-lap race. Once he got his Ford Thunderbird in front, however, he kept it there, beating Wilson's Oldsmobile Cutlass by less than the length of his hood.

LEAD: SHORT SEASON: And Other Stories. By Jerry Klinkowitz. (Johns Hopkins University, $16.95.) These 28 stories by Jerry Klinkowitz - who is the executive director of the Waterloo (Iowa) Indians baseball team when he isn't teaching English at the University of Northern Iowa - span a single season with the youthful, cheerful, league-leading Mason City Royals, a make-believe Class A farm club of the Kansas City Royals.
LEAD: A Palestinian youth died today, reportedly of a bullet wound, after a clash in which masked demonstrators threw rocks and gasoline bombs at Israeli soldiers in the West Bank town of Jenin.

LEAD: EATING at an Italian restaurant recently, Federal judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. spotted a neighbor - E. Claiborne Robins, former chairman of the A. H. Robins Company. ''I have to say hello to him,'' Judge Merhige said, trying to attract his eye, but Mr. Robins left without acknowledging the judge.

LEAD: After several months of hearing his Presidential campaign derided for a seeming inability to forge a coherent message, Vice President Bush finds political Washington taking him seriously again. Suddenly, it seems, George Bush has seized the initiative.

LEAD: BOB Fishel collapsed and died on his way home from the American League office, only a few blocks away, Thursday night. In other words, he worked until the final half hour of his life, which was exactly what he always wanted.

LEAD: Creative artiststend to take summer vacations like almost everyone else, but with a difference: their work generally remains an integral part of their life. The playwright Lanford Wilson blends puttering in his garden, watching baseball on TV and working on a play - not necessarily in that order. Spike Lee relishes the heat: it is the subject of the movie he is about to start shooting in Brooklyn.

LEAD: WE must be grateful to Stephen Schwartz (in The Book Review, Jan. 24, and in The New York Review of Books, June 16) and to Theodore Draper (in The New York Review of Books, April 14 and June 16) for their discussion of Freud's colleague Dr. Max Eitingon and his possible connections with the Soviet secret police in the 1930's.

LEAD: The bad and the beautiful unite in Rudolf Nureyev's new production of ''The Nutcracker,'' which had its United States premiere with the Paris Opera Ballet on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LEAD: The subject of the recent article ''Summer Homework Angers Parents'' (June 12) was about a situation I find most distressing. Apparently, some Branford parents are in an uproar about a public school principal's mandate that students grade five through eight read two books during summer vacation and then take a test on them when they return in the fall.

LEAD: In the Pacific Northwest the barbecue season doesn't have as much to do with the weather as it does with the salmon run. In early spring, Indians living near the Columbia River celebrate the first appearance of returning Chinook salmon with outdoor feasts, which are repeated, in backyards and restaurants, until the middle of fall.

LEAD: WITH THE RELEASE OF all Beethoven's piano concertos played on historical instruments (London Oiseau-Lyre 421 408; three CD's, cassettes or LP's), it is clear that some kind of milestone has been reached in the early music movement. It is also clear to some observers that the movement is now and then biting off more than it can chew, sometimes pressing forward for commercial reasons faster than the artistic results justify, confused in some quarters about its aims.
LEAD: THERE ACTUALLY ARE WOMEN WHO ENJOY parading around the beach in the bits of fabric that pass as swimsuits these days. It's just that these people are about as rare as a cold day in August.

LEAD: The rally in the dollar grew stronger, defying efforts by some central banks to check its rise. During the week the dollar rose as high as 133.9 yen and 1.82 marks. In mid-June, the dollar was worth only about 126 yen and 1.75 marks. The West Germans appeared most anxious to temper the dollar's comeback, with the Bundesbank raising its discount rate to 3 percent, from 2.5 percent, in hopes that higher interest rates would draw support to the mark.

LEAD: WITH themes ranging from baseball and chocolate to live shows and elaborate rides, amusement parks have become top tourist attractions. There are more than 600 theme and amusement parks in this country, drawing more than 235 million visitors each year, according to the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions, an industry trade group.

LEAD: THE POET AT THE PIANO: Portraits of Writers, Filmmakers, Playwrights, and Other Artists at Work. By Michiko Kakutani. (Times Books, $18.95.) LEAD: With only five hits in two games, the San Francisco Giants needed help today. And the Pittsburgh Pirates obliged. With the bases loaded and one out in the bottom of the eighth, the Pittsburgh reliever Barry Jones threw a wild pitch that bounced high in the air, enabling two runs to score as the Giants won, 2-1.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about Afghanistan in The Week in review on June 19 described American aid to Pakistan, incorrectly. Since 1981, the United States had spent or authorized more than $7 billion in aid to Pakistan. None of it has been covert.

LEAD: IRAN, Iraq and 46 other countries have anti-ship cruise missiles. Nineteen countries, including Argentina and India, own diesel-attack submarines. And 21 nations have naval mines, which, like the other two weapons, are capable of sinking large ships.

LEAD: JAZZ LISTENERS CONVERGED on New York this past week to soak up three festivals and stockpile enough information and gossip to last through the slow months. They're not known as a laconic or inhibited lot, but one word was scarcer than miniskirts in Iran - fusion.

LEAD: The fastest way to move a warhead between two points is with a ballistic missile - a fact that more and more countries are beginning to exploit. Ballistic missiles propel their payloads in the same way that rockets boost satellites into orbit: Once the boost phase ends, the missile is no longer powered.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH penalties for environmental pollution in the Hudson Valley are increasing, area environmental groups say state and Federal treasuries are receiving the benefits while an increasingly fragile environment is neglected.

LEAD: ROLLER coasters have consistently ranked as the most popular ride in surveys of amusement park visitors. And they have come a long way since 1884 when attendants at Coney Island pushed the cars up the incline on the Switchback Gravity Pleasure Railway so that riders could zoom down at hair-raising speeds of six miles an hour.

LEAD: MOVIE DISTRIBUTORS APPEAR to assume that, when summer arrives, the minds of their audiences go as soft as abandoned Eskimo Pies. At least, it looks that way. Schools are out. People are on vacation. Impulse theatergoing increases. Summer is a time for abbreviated, loose-fitting clothing and sloppy movies to match.

LEAD: AT 11:45 A.M., with a sigh of relief, I saw my younger daughter through the drizzle and onto the bus for the afternoon kindergarten session. It was one of those mornings when neither mother nor daughter won. I got nothing done, and she, as she tearfully and frequently took great pains to point out, had no fun.

LEAD: MORE than four months after the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, Dan Jansen is still awed at the amount of mail he is receiving. ''It's been unbelievable. They're still coming,'' the speed skater said from his house in Milwaukee this week. ''They're not nearly what they were for a while. Now we get one or two.

LEAD: Billy Martin is a controversial player from another baseball era, and it is unlikely that his style is necessary. Today, baseball prides itself in producing athletes whose skills have been sharpened. There are many fine players who let their ability with the bat, the glove, speed on the bases, and fine throwing arms speak for them.

LEAD: AS the drought in the nation's midsection worsened in recent months, and the price of soybeans, corn and other crops shot up, many investors were drawn for the first time to commodity futures. And when some rain fell last week, sending prices plunging, many learned, perhaps also for the first time, of the particular perils of this volatile market.

LEAD: For six years, President Reagan has pressed Congress to provide more military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. But on a trip to Central America this week, Secretary of State George P. Shultz appeared reluctant to discuss American aid for the contras.

LEAD: AFTER THE SUMMER SOLSTICE, the woodland trails in our Berkshire neighborhood swarm with fugitives from the city. They seek the bucolic, accompanied by Walkmans to supply Mozart on the meadow or rock on the rocks.

LEAD: WHEN WE WERE IN school, well-meaning teachers spent a lot of time denouncing cliches and demanding that we eliminate them from our thinking. Not only is that impossible, it is probably harmful to mental health. In a topsy-turvy world (there's one now!), one needs to feel solid ground under foot (another one!).

LEAD: An Aug. 6 wedding is planned by Alyssa Maria Bliss and Lawrence Scott Greenberg, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Bliss of New York, have announced. Mr. Greenberg is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Greenberg, also of New York.

LEAD: THE STORY OF THE 1988 VENICE Biennale is Jasper Johns - the best known, most influential and probably the most complex American painter in the last 30 years. No one else in the 43d biennale approaches him in stature, and the show that represents him - and the United States - ''Jasper Johns: Work From 1974-1986,'' has the kind of concentration that encourages an appraisal of his achievement.

The presentation is part of the continuing celebration of the the 200th anniversary of the Constitution, and will remain through Aug.

LEAD: MEMOIRS OF AN INVISIBLE MAN, by H. F. Saint. (Dell, $4.95.) ''The prose is so elegantly knowing, particularly the sport it makes of the Wall Street types who inadvertently help Nick out of his pickle, [ that ] 'Memoirs of an Invisible Man' sustains our interest to the end,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year.

LEAD: Shaken by a long labor dispute and the continuing attrition of readers and advertisers, Il Progresso Italo Americano has suspended publication, leaving in doubt the future of the only Italian-language daily newspaper in the United States.

The first, on Saturday evening, was an all-Tchaikovsky program that included the ''Capriccio Italien,'' a suite from ''Swan Lake,'' an orchestral arrangement of the Andante Cantabile (a string quartet movement) and the Piano Concerto No.

Shultz's visit to Central America last week appeared to be a renewed effort to isolate Nicaragua at a time when the Reagan Administration is perceived to be weakening and its policy toward the Sandinistas is seen to be in disarray, according to diplomats and government officials in the region.

LEAD: Pope John Paul II yesterday canonized a woman who entered a convent against her father's will, founded the first free school west of the Mississippi and at the age of 72 helped begin a school for Potawatami Indians at what is now Sugar Creek, Kan.
LEAD: Writers who aim to make serious contributions to the literature of the game have a Scylla-and-Charybdis problem.
LEAD: Six contemporary paintings, valued at $500,000, were stolen from a Manhattan art gallery over the weekend, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Information stored on personal com-puters at the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and several other Government agencies has been destroyed by a computer program designed to sabotage a private computer company in Texas.

She was 63 years old and lived in White Plains.
LEAD: A United States Navy warship in the Persian Gulf shot down an Iranian passenger plane today that the Navy said it mistook for a jet fighter, and Iran said all 290 people on board were killed.

LEAD: A Bronx judge, citing insufficient evidence, yesterday released without bail a suspect in a robbery and shooting rampage by five prep school classmates and said he would consider dismissing all charges against the youth.

LEAD: About 400 women demonstrated here Saturday against the implementation of Islamic law by President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. It was the second such protest in two weeks. Many women fear that the new code will negate 1961 laws that gave them the right to file for divorce or to demand the right to register marriages and divorces.

LEAD: Nicole Francisca Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Clark of San Diego, was married yesterday to Steven Paul Tulchin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Tulchin of New Rochelle, N.Y. Michael Romanoff, a town justice of Scarsdale, N.Y., officiated at the Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

LEAD: Mark McGwire hit a home run on the first pitch of the 16th inning today, his second straight game-winning homer in the 16th inning, and Stan Javier hit a homer two outs later as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, to win their fifth straight.

LEAD: Pete Rose, a manager whose job has been rumored to be in jeopardy, received support from his general manager and his team last night. Only the owner was missing in her support, and, of course, Marge Schott is the only one who counts.

LEAD: The board of the York International Corporation accepted an offer of $57.50 a share in cash and securities, or about $750 million, from a management group led by Citicorp's venture capital unit. LEAD: Three months after taking effect, the New York City law banning smoking in most public places wins overwhelming public approval, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

LEAD: USING a new particle accelerator, scientists at Cornell University have taken a snapshot of protein molecules with what amounts to a shutter speed of a billionth of a second. The scientists now hope to be able to capture changes that occur as often a million times a second as proteins perform crucial functions in the body.

LEAD: Revenge seems to help relieve the pain when police refuse to enter a locked parked car and turn off the burglar alarm that endlessly pierces the night. Such car alarms are mandated by law to shut off after 15 minutes. Too many of them don't. The police usually shrug off their responsibility to provide relief, for reasons the Department's legal adviser cannot explain.

LEAD: An increase in production and new orders, fueled by a growth in exports, helped the economy expand in June at the largest rate since December, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled for release today.

LEAD: DISCOUNT retailers are normally able to weather sales turndowns better than more traditional retailers, but so far this year the discounters have found their normal pricing edge blunted by competition.

LEAD: The scene has become nightmarish for the Yankees. They have thrived when Dave Righetti has pitched well, fallen when he has endured hard times, and now that he is struggling, every appearance on the mound is cause for concern.

LEAD: The energy that a number of politically active women devoted four years ago to obtaining a spot for a woman on the Democrats' national ticket has a new focus this year: increasing the number of women in top policy-making jobs, no matter which party wins the White House in November.

LEAD: Concerted action by the Federal Government and by schools and colleges can prevent a widely expected shortage of American scientists and engineers from becoming a ''self-fulfilling prophecy,'' a recent Government study maintains.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes edged slightly lower in extremely light post-holiday trading yesterday, as participants marked time in advance of an upcoming economic report.

LEAD: Robert H. Morosky, the former president of Allied Stores, is negotiating to buy the Gold Circle discount department store chain from Federated Department Stores, according to people in the retailing business. Gold Circle is one of the remaining Federated store divisions still to be sold by the Campeau Corporation, owners of both Federated and Allied Stores.

LEAD: Designing a computer-based system that can recognize human speech has long been a cherished goal of artificial intelligence researchers and linguists. After almost three decades of agonizingly slow progress, some researchers believe they are closing in on the ability to create machines that can recognize naturally spoken language from a variety of different speakers.
LEAD: A four-day celebration of the 150th anniversary of harness racing in the United States ended here on the Fourth of July in an atmosphere of mixed hope and gloom.

LEAD: Since immigration officials began full enforcement of the 1986 immigration law on June 1, many aliens who did not qualify for amnesty are finding themselves pushed deeper into an illegal subclass as they seek employment in the United States.
LEAD: A RECENT newspaper article detailing the joys of engine cooking brought back a flood of memories, most of them quite hilarious.

LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday introduced its Multifamily Guarantor Program, whereby the corporation will buy three types of fixed-rate multifamily mortgages from lenders for a like amount of multifamily mortgage participation certificates. Included will be both conventional and Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

LEAD: Iranian leaders have differed in the last few days on how to respond to the American downing of an Iranian airliner, with some, led by the Speaker of the Parliament, advocating a diplomatic offensive and others, led by a spiritual leader, urging attacks on American interests.
LEAD: Louisiana will offer tax-free shopping to foreign visitors under a bill approved by the Legislature and sent to Gov. Buddy Roemer. He is expected to sign the bill, to be effective Jan. 1.

LEAD: Ronnie Lamarque, co-owner of Risen Star, showed a $100,000 check at a news conference in New Orleans a yesterday and said it would go to the jockey, Eddie Delahoussaye, resolving his dispute with the colt's owners. Delahoussaye had complained that he had not received a 10 percent share of a $1 million bonus paid to Risen Star in recognition of the colt's performance in the Triple Crown races.

LEAD: A report in the Political Notes column on Sunday about the distribution of New York City funds to black churches listed a recipient incorrectly through an error by the New York City Comptroller's office.

LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States increased last week by 27, to 921, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. During the previous week, the rig count had fallen by 11, to 894, the company said.

LEAD: A small number of black educators and psychologists, believing that black children learn in distinctly different ways than do white children, have been urging schools to adapt their instructional methods to this difference.

LEAD: New Jersey's Education Commissioner, Saul Cooperman, likes to characterize his effort to take over the Jersey City schools as ''invasive surgery'' on a district riddled by mismanagement and possible corruption. His critics prefer phrases like ''political vendetta'' and ''abuse of power.''

LEAD: Mario M. Cuomo - who at various times has called reporters stupid, ingrates, spoiled, incompetent, arrogant and thin-skinned - took up pen and notebook today, working as a reporter to get a taste of the job and, just perhaps, to show the Albany press corps a thing or two.

LEAD: THE International Wine Center, a prominent school, is moving from midtown Manhattan, and its companion operation, the Tastings Wine Bar and Restaurant, has closed because the building that housed them is to be demolished. Together, they have formed a hub of wine activities in New York City since early 1982.

LEAD: Greg Norman reinjured his left wrist during a practice round at a Florida golf course this week and has decided to pull out of next week's British Open, according to a pubblished report. LEAD: The Times Square of the 1990's is now emerging from gaping, straight-edged concrete canyons that have been excavated north of 42d Street. LEAD: Marguerite Belleri, a member of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus for 57 years, died of heart failure Saturday evening at Hempstead (L.I.) Hospital. She was 93 years old. Mrs. Belleri, born Gretl Maerkl in Traunstein, Bavaria, was engaged for the Met in 1910 when still a Munich schoolgirl. During her tenure with the company she worked with many of the great conductors and singers of the century.

LEAD: A slain longtime aide to the leading opposition presidential candidate was buried here today, on the eve of the election, to the salute of angry anti-Government cries and an emotional rendering of the national anthem.

LEAD: Thomas C. Griscom, who until last Thursday served as the White House director of communications and planning, will join the teaching staff at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga. LEAD: THE presence of a tall, elegant Frenchman caused little commotion at the first International Pinot Noir Celebration in nearby McMinnville in the summer of 1987. Quite a few Burgundians had already found their way into the Willamette Valley.

LEAD: FOR the political pros eager to untangle the welfare maze, three of the prettiest words in the English language are ''make dad pay.'' Requiring absent fathers to support their children would make a dent in the cost of supporting chronic welfare dependents, as well as saving newly separated and suddenly poor mothers from a first visit to the welfare office.

LEAD: Few people would advocate solving the drug problem by killing addicts. Yet that's the effect of the drug policy now pursued by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo. By resisting measures to halt transmission of the AIDS virus among addicts, they are letting the infection spread. That does not eliminate drug abuse, only drug abusers.

LEAD: Satisfied that he will not be indicted, Edwin Meese has decided to resign as Attorney General. Even though he hasn't seen the just-completed report of the independent counsel who investigated him for a year, Mr. Meese said yesterday that he is certain of vindication. He thus clings to the wrong standard even as he rightly declines to cling to office until the bitter end.

LEAD: John Hopkins Heires, an international banker, died of a heart attack Saturday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 69 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

LEAD: An obituary on June 22 about Bobby Dodd, the former Georgia Tech football coach, misstated his birth date. It was Nov. 11, 1908.

LEAD: After the most competitive and contentious presidential campaign in nearly half a century, Mexicans are to vote Wednesday in an election being described here as a watershed in modern Mexican history.

LEAD: The Koppers Company has signed a letter of intent to sell its chemical division for $660 million to an investor group that includes some Koppers managers, Beazer P.L.C. said. LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts changed very little in the week ended yesterday, while yields of money market mutual funds continued to rise as investors moved to higher rates offered by other money market instruments.

LEAD: More than a year after a deputy refused to do so, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has issued a ''profound apology'' to James M. Beggs, former Administrator of the space agency, for the Justice Department's attempt to prosecute him on fraud charges.

LEAD: A diagram on the Business Technology page yesterday, with an article about speech recognition, reversed the labels on two parts of a speech recognition computer. The digital signal processor was on the left; the data base processor was on the right.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Iranian F-14 fighter that the warship Vincennes thought it had detected in an attack pattern over the Persian Gulf on Sunday would have posed a limited threat to the ship, aerospace industry and military officials said today.
LEAD: A 27-year-old Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering a crime witness and gave a graphic and chilling account of how he and another man had executed her.

LEAD: Members of the Senate said after Pentagon briefings today that the captain of a Navy cruiser had acted properly in shooting down an unidentified aircraft that turned out to be a civilian Iranian airliner, even though he acted on incomplete information.

LEAD: John Deuss, the Dutch oil trader whose attempt to corner the January market for North Sea Brent crude cost him $200 million, will more than make up for his loss with the planned sale of his Philadelphia refinery to the Sun Company.

LEAD: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, an independent power producing company that owns or leases generators, said yesterday that it had received a bid of $10.75 a share from Thomas B. Pickens 3d of Dallas, the son of T. Boone Pickens.
LEAD: SOMETIMES all the number crunching and market analysis that go into assessing the right merger candidate end up only secondary to a bidder's firsthand impression of the company's operations.

LEAD: A Congressional study says a Reagan Administration proposal to trade away potentially valuable oil rights in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge is not in the public interest and should be abandoned.
LEAD: Senior State Department officials say Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is on a roll, and they are watching to see whether his next move is a summit meeting with Deng Xiaoping of China.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Pentagon The following Pentagon officials were subjected to searches. Federal investigators have said they are under scrutiny for passing information to consultants. None have been charged with wrongdoing, but all have been reassigned to jobs that do not involve procurement. Stuart Berlin: Procurement specialist with the Naval Air Systems Command.

LEAD: The men, mostly in work clothes and, by the dictates of their faith, barefoot, were rapt in prayer, bodies curled in supplication and foreheads bent to the prayer rugs on which they knelt, facing the Kaaba, the holy house in Mecca, far away from Woodside, Queens.

LEAD: Better dental instruments and techniques and a new adhesive coating have made attaching false teeth directly to the jaw bone an increasingly popular alternative to bridgework and dentures.

LEAD: A lawsuit unsealed today contends that workers at the Lockheed Missiles and Space Company used Government computers to run a football pool, built a private airplane at public expense and billed the Government for time used to write the Bible into a computer.
