LEAD: A Federal district judge in Boston said yesterday that the Gillette Company had violated a Securities and Exchange Commission rule by running a misleading newspaper advertisement that helped it win a proxy battle with Coniston Partners this spring.

LEAD: More than 15 miles of ocean beach on Long Island, including Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Parks, were closed today when a mysterious wave of sewage, syringes, blood vials and infectious hospital waste washed ashore.

LEAD: Egypt has been reinstated in the Arab League Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization, effective next December, the organization announced today. Egypt was suspended in 1979 after signing the peace treaty with Israel. The organization works closely with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and with the Arab League, which also suspended Egypt in 1979 and has not reinstated it.
LEAD: A prestigious American who holds a life membership in the National Rifle Association made a suggestion recently that set off reverberations here.

LEAD: SUDDENLY a quiet descended on the country. Some wondered if it wasn't just the twitching calm after the storm of Fourth of July celebrations, when fireworks sequined the sky, when the din rattled windows, when the requisite careless revelers maimed themselves as well as assorted neighbors and companions, and all in the name of hot dogs, apple pie and Jefferson, Franklin and Francis Lightfoot

LEAD: Negotiators for striking writers say their proposal for an interim agreement is the best hope for resuming production, but the chairman of Paramount Pictures said the plan would prolong the strike, which began March 7.

LEAD: The International Civil Aviation Organization said today that it will hold a special session of its governing council to consider Iran's demand for an inquiry into the shooting down of an Iranian passenger plane by an American ship.

LEAD: The men gathered under the Spanish-style arcades of this village's only plaza all agreed that the sight of peasants in straw hats and shawls lining up this morning to vote was altogether unusual for an election day in Comanja.

LEAD: Restrictions on the location and serving time of food vending pushcarts in the more congested areas of New York City will take effect Monday. Those who ignore the prohibitions could be fined and their carts and contents removed, city officials said.

LEAD: Recent fans of the ad game and old participants as well will find interesting reading in ''Emperors of Adland,'' a new book by Nancy Millman, advertising columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times. It is a readable guide to, and background study of, the merger mania that has infected the industry worldwide.

LEAD: The Prime Minister's office said today that it is investigating an allegation that officers of the Israeli internal security service disguised themselves as ABC News reporters and cameramen to arrest a Palestinian last month.

''We saw how they were behaving but, at the time, we didn't associate much of it with our moving plans.

Either they talk too much, and fill the screen with jargon, or they talk too little, and the camera is left to do all the work by itself, roaming around mute buildings as if they were natural wonders.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis, deliberating over his choice of a running mate, has not asked Jack F. Kemp who he thinks would bring the most strength to the Democratic ticket. But at a luncheon yesterday the upstate New York Congressman, an erstwhile contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, voiced his opinion anyway.
LEAD: An Energy Department advisory board today recommended building a nuclear reactor in South Carolina to provide raw materials for the nation's atomic weapons arsenal.

LEAD: A meeting of Soviet and American theater people opened here Tuesday at Eugene O'Neill's boyhood home, and, were he alive, the playwright might have been jarred to hear talk that was more reminiscent of box office than of ideological ferment. The script for the sessions, which are to end Friday, calls for practical cultural exchange unimpeded by governmental staging and moralistic declamation.

LEAD: An Israeli journalist, Benny Morris, has written a careful and timely book about the origins of Israel's endless conflict with Palestinian refugees. It addresses two questions. Were Arabs expelled from Israel as part of a predetermined Zionist plan? Or did Palestinians flee voluntarily, as instructed, in the expectation that they would return after invading Arabs had driven Jews into the sea?
LEAD: Announcing an important change in policy toward North Korea, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that he would allow trade, family visits and student exchanges with the North.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The White House said today that it would move quickly to nominate a successor to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d even though there is little time left in the Reagan Administration for the Senate to complete the laborious confirmation process.

LEAD: SHE was sitting cross-legged on the sidewalk one day not long ago, the woman I suspected of being the most successful panhandler in all of New York City. She was a young woman with old eyes who had taken up her station on Fifth Avenue, which may be blighted by ersatz curio shops and lost-our-lease signs but nonetheless remains an international metaphor for privilege and plenty.

LEAD: To The Home Section:

LEAD: On the Fourth of July, one day before Stanley M. Friedman gave up his independence to begin serving a 12-year term in Federal prison, the telephone in a one-room office at 641 Lexington Avenue was, coincidentally, disconnected.

LEAD: An international gathering of scientists, here for Thursday's launching of a expedition to the small Martian moon Phobos, today heard the Soviet Union's leading space scientists outline a program of exploration that could culminate in a manned mission to the planet in 2010.
LEAD: A bomber's incompetence probably saved this small southern Indiana town from explosions that could have damaged six bridges as well as offices and businesses, the authorities say.

LEAD: Excessive fiscal deficits are the main cause of the third world's economic problems, the World Bank said today. It suggested that governments increase revenues by charging more for basic services like health and education.

LEAD: NEW counter tops can transform the appearance of a kitchen or bathroom. But those that are professionally built and installed are usually expensive, and constructing counter tops from scratch seems daunting to many homeowners.
LEAD: An explosion and fire on a North Sea oil rig killed one worker and injured at least 25 others Wednesday night. Many of the injured were severely burned.

LEAD: Helped by the deep pockets of new corporate owners and growing interest from advertisers, Spanish-language television in the United States is shedding its status as the stepchild of the broadcasting industry and maturing into a more professional and competitive business.

LEAD: In describing why he loved the game of chess so much, James T. Sherwin told a reporter last year: ''You can engage in diversionary tactics. You can try to fool your opponent into thinking you can do one thing and you're really doing something else.''

LEAD: Eastern Air Lines and unions representing its pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and other employees have agreed to work together to make sure that their longstanding labor dispute does not jeopardize safe operation of the airline, Federal officials announced yesterday.
LEAD: The Washington Bullets indicated yesterday that they would make no attempt to re-sign Moses Malone, the 33-year-old center who has been an All-Star 10 times.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A superior pianistic talent was disclosed by Lilia Zilberstein, the young Moscow-born winner of the 1987 Busoni competition, at her local debut in Weill Recital Hall Tuesday evening. The program - a part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts - was all Russian, and the style corresponded, but Miss Zilberstein moderates the harsh excesses that have been associated with Soviet piano playing in recent decades, and brings a fluid lyricism, a free swing of tempo and a sense of color to much of her playing.

LEAD: Goldman, Sachs & Company said it had bought a 5.1 percent stake in Shoney's Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the New York-based broker-dealer said that the Shoney's shares had been acquired ''in connection with arbitrage and other activities in the ordinary course of the firm's business.
LEAD: Sales of passenger vehicles rose 9.1 percent in the first half of 1988 over the comparable period last year, as domestic models increased their share of the market.

LEAD: The Marriott Corporation, which owns hotels and restaurants, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter had risen 1 percent, to $64.5 million, or 53 cents a share, from $63.9 million, or 47 cents a share, a year earlier.

LEAD: Frank Viola won his league-leading 14th game tonight, pitching a three-hitter as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-1. The Twins moved within three and a half games of Oakland in the American League West.
LEAD: Japan will lower the price it pays farmers for rice this year, a Government spokesman said today.

LEAD: A fire that killed five people has been ruled arson, Fire Chief Charles J. Bunyan said today. Investigators have traced the origin of the blaze to the enclosed porch of the victims' duplex, he said. Killed in the fire Monday were Jack Blose, 35 years old, his wife, Deborah, 31, and their children, Jack Jr., 12, Rachel, 5, and Lacey, 4.

LEAD: Members of Congress said today that the American downing of an Iranian passenger plane again raised troubling questions about Administration policy in the Persian Gulf, but they acknowledged that there was little Congress could do to force changes in it.
LEAD: It's a long way from the stature of the Park Avenue address where he once lived, but Dennis B. Levine has finally returned home.

Environmental officials said that the kill was linked to the hot weather and that similar kills were likely to occur in the western portions of Long Island
LEAD: The team physician of the Portland Trail Blazers has said the Soviet basketball star Arvydas Sabonis would risk a career-threatening injury if he plays in the Olympic Games this year.
LEAD: Airline and airport officials in Europe say they have stepped up security since an American warship shot down an Iranian airliner last Sunday, killing all 290 people aboard.

LEAD: DICK TARLOW, who denied the major leagues his left-handed pitching talents and made them available instead to advertisers, now makes the claim that Tarlow Advertising is the fastest-growing new agency since Backer & Spielvogel - a year and a half in business and $50 million in billings.

LEAD: Wahlstrom & Company of Stamford, Conn., the Foote, Cone & Belding Yellow Pages specialty agency, has acquired McCrea Associates, a 27-year-old Philadelphia shop of similar bent, and has merged it into its own operation in that city. Wahlstrom also has offices in Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.
LEAD: Federal Judge David Doty will rule in Minneapolis Monday whether to grant unrestricted free agency for more than 300 National Football League players, a source said yesterday.

LEAD: For months Michael S. Dukakis waved off any questions about his choice of a running mate with a breezy, ''There's plenty of time.'' Now, with 12 days left before the Democratic National Convention begins in Atlanta, Mr. Dukakis is on the brink of a decision, but he is giving very few clues about what it will be.

LEAD: The dollar's recent rally has exposed a rift in the worldwide policy coordination that has governed the currency markets since 1985, when the United States and its allies agreed to force a big decline in the dollar.
LEAD: Watching Hideki Noda dash around the stage is like watching a teen-ager run amok in a video arcade. His plays are fun, flashy, noisy and light on the message.

LEAD: The Bodleian Library at Oxford University is seeking funds for the conservation of manuscripts and the introduction of technology.

LEAD: AT the beginning of the year, some market analysts boldly stated that this would be the year that investment managers began beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and it appears that they were correct. After lagging behind the index for four of the last five years, the average independent investment management firm has been outpacing the once seemingly unbeatable index -and by a fairly wide margin.

LEAD: Nothing will put Iran Air flight 655 back into the sky, but there is one sure way to avert another tragedy - withdrawing our naval forces from the Persian Gulf. Fortunately, Iran's declining fortunes on the battlefront with Iraq present Washington with a compelling and face-saving reason to leave.

LEAD: An investment group led by the Beverly Hills investor Robert N. Goodman has raised its offer to acquire Perini Investment Properties Inc. to $21.50 a share, or $84.3 million, from its earlier $19-a-share proposal.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday indicted the GAF Corporation, its vice chairman and two subsidiaries, charging that they manipulated the price of shares of the Union Carbide Corporation in 1986 after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company.
LEAD: In a ceremony behind home plate tonight at Comiskey Park, Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois signed into law a bill providing the financing to build a new stadium for the Chicago White Sox.
LEAD: Volvo Penta of America, the marine division of Volvo North America, has awarded its engine business to Lowe Tucker Metcalf, a partner agency of Lowe Howard-Spink of London.

LEAD: A victim of the Howard Beach racial attack erupted emotionally on the witness stand yesterday at the second trial in the case, spitting angrily into the air, cursing and refusing to testify further after a defense lawyer asked him a sarcastic question.

LEAD: For the 28th time this season, Dave Johnson flashed the red-alert message to the bullpen: Send Myers. And for the 18th time, Randy Myers trotted to the mound with his heater and either won or saved a game for the Mets with his strikeout pitching.

LEAD: Five Palestinians were convicted today and sentenced to be hanged for the 1986 hijacking of a New York-bound Pan American World Airways jumbo jet in which 21 people were killed and nearly 200 wounded.

LEAD: WHEN not traversing the country in their recreational vehicle, Dorothymae and Harold Groves of Kansas City, Mo., research the history of quilts. Their efforts have yielded discovery of patterns originally published in a weekly quilt column in The Kansas City Star.

LEAD: Both Defense Department officials and private consultants have widely ignored some regulations intended to prevent conflicts of interest in weapons purchases, the Pentagon's inspector general testified today.

An additional one-fifth of the lakes in the region are so acidic they are considered ''endangered,'' according to the study.

LEAD: Carolyn Reidy, the publisher of Anchor Books, yesterday was named president and publisher of Avon Books, the mass-marketing division of the Hearst Trade Book Group. Ms. Reidy will replace Rena Wolner, who announced her retirement from book publishing. Ms. Reidy was director of subsidiary rights at William Morrow from 1983 to 1985.

Sean Kelly of Ireland, the Tour of Spain winner this year, finished third in the 91-mile leg from the northern French city of Neufchatel-en-Bray to Lievin near the Belgian border.

LEAD: Months of drought and weeks of blistering temperatures have destroyed half the corn crop in Illinois, the nation's second-largest producer of corn, state agriculture officials said today.

''Loose Connections,'' the 1983 English film that opens today at the Public Theater, is of main interest for having been directed by Richard Eyre, the director of the good, strong, politically provoking ''Ploughman's Lunch'' (1984), written by Ian McEwan. ''Loose Connections'' is a politically aware romantic comedy about a pretty, committed feminist named Sally (Lindsay Duncan), a representative of the middle class, and her adventures on the European road with Harry (Stephen Rea), a rough, young male chauvinist out of Liverpool's working class.

LEAD: Harry Hook's subdued and powerful first film is a coming-of-age story loaded with history. Mwangi, a 12-year-old boy of the Kikuyu tribe, is a clear metaphor for Kenya's political development. Set in 1950, at the start of the struggle that would lead to independence from British rule 13 years later, ''The Kitchen Toto'' suggests how blacks such as Mwangi were doubly oppressed - by the white colonists and by the Mau Mau, the terrorist group that forced other Kikuyus to swear allegiance to them.

LEAD: Jazz With J. J. Johnson J. J. Johnson, Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South, near 11th Street (255-4037). J. J. Johnson's appearance at the Village Vanguard last year had the club packed not only with jazz fans, but also with trombonists, most of whom were slack-jawed in amazement. Mr. Johnson, the first be-bop trombonist, set the rules for most trombonists who followed him, not only in his unadorned, graceful swing, but in his tone and perfect intonation as well.

LEAD: IN George Coates's music-theater spectacle ''Actual Sho,'' one of three events that kick off the Pepsico Summerfare arts festival in Purchase, N.Y., this evening, archetypal images are beamed from 26 slide projectors onto an elaborate system of Levolor blinds. Against an eclectic polyrhythmic score by Marc Ream, the images transform and dissolve like a grandly designed Rorschach test.
LEAD: The roof of a downtown clothing store collapsed this afternoon in a torrential rainstorm in this border city, killing at least eight people and injuring at least 41 more.

LEAD: Jeff Robinson and Paul Gibson combined on a four-hitter tonight, and the Detroit Tigers hit five home runs in an 8-1 victory over the slumping Oakland Athletics.

LEAD: People often think of the Frick Collection not simply as fixed and immutable, but also as a paragon among museums that came into being full grown. Hesitation and doubt can have played no part in its development, let alone anything so humdrum as a mistake. What did Henry Clay Frick ever do but get the best advice and act upon it?
LEAD: The dollar drifted again yesterday, but some currency traders said they were still confident that the two-week rally would be revived.

LEAD: In a surprise for both Wall Street and the computer industry, Apollo Computer Inc., a maker of computer work stations, said yesterday that it expected to report a second-quarter loss of between $5 million and $8 million because of lower demand for its machines in the United States and Europe.

LEAD: The early-19th-century portraits by Joshua Johnson, now on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center, come to life slowly. Johnson, one of the first known black artists in the United States, was active as a portraitist in Baltimore between 1795 and 1825, and the considerable strengths of his art emerge from behind a screen of social propriety, artistic awkwardness and pictorial convention.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Mexico failed to make public all but the most fragmentary results from a presidential election, which was intrepreted as indicating that the ruling party had been rejected by more voters than ever before. Page A1
LEAD: Alleco Inc., Cheverly, Md., said it had given preliminary approval to Lapides Corp.'s $10-a-share offer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: EVEN people who hate the outdoors generally love outdoor cafes. This may seem pretty strange, but that's the way it is. They're ready to forget the debris stirred up by the tiniest breeze, the pungent scent of horses, the acrid fragrance of exhaust fumes. That's the price to be paid for the illusion of space, sunlight and fresh air, and diehard Manhattan weekenders pay it willingly.

LEAD: A victim of the Howard Beach racial attack who erupted emotionally on the witness stand Wednesday will have to continue testifying at the second trial in the case despite his mental and emotional problems, the judge ruled yesterday.

LEAD: Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, talking to reporters at news conference yesterday in Washington. The Republican leadership outlined proposals for legislation in the continuing war on drugs. With him were, from left, Senators Pete Wilson, Phil Gramm and Arlen Specter. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)
LEAD: Contemporary Soviet art came out of the shadows and into the glittering world of the Western marketplace today as Sotheby's held the first international art auction in Soviet history.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Bobby Allison left his room at Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa., in a wheelchair yesterday for the first time since his racing accident June 19. Ed Gossage, spokesman for Allison's sponsor, Miller Racing, said Allison remained in guarded condition. Allison, 51, suffered a concussion and several broken bones in the accident in the Nascar Miller 500 at Pocono International Raceway.

LEAD: Yes, railroads gouge shippers who lack a transport alternative. An isolated coal mine in Kentucky is sure to pay a lot more than an auto parts manufacturer in Illinois that has railroads and truckers bidding for its business.

LEAD: Among the paintings Manet chose to exhibit in the 1873 Salon, a portrait of Berthe Morisot particularly rankled the Parisian critics. ''Le Repos'' depicts its subject reclining awkwardly on an overstuffed couch. Manet displays her left hand draped elegantly across the cushioned seat, but the other hand looks bizarre - a claw painted in loose, flat brushstrokes.

LEAD: The Mexican Government today failed to release all but the most fragmentary results from the presidential election Wednesday, an action immediately interpreted here as indicating that the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and its candidate had been rejected by a larger proportion of the electorate than at any other time in the party's 59-year history.

LEAD: Twelve more employees of the New York City Health Department, along with three private consultants, were charged yesterday in a scheme to extort hundreds of thousands of dollars from restaurants by threatening to close them or cite them for health violations.

LEAD: A Federal jury today awarded $22.6 million to the estate of the defunct E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., ruling against the financier Marvin L. Warner, who the firm claimed had unjustly profited from its 1985 failure.

LEAD: The selection of the United States to host the 1994 World Cup raises the question of why Americans call the sport soccer when it's football everywhere else. A well-traveled friend explains that the name evolved when the game came over from England, which has two sports called football - rugby football and association football.
LEAD: With tears and angry words shouted over flag-draped coffins, Iranians today continued to mourn the victims of Flight 655 at a memorial ceremony in Teheran.
LEAD: In the first sign of dissent within the Afrikaner establishment over Pretoria's military presence in Angola, the main Afrikaner church has publicly questioned South Africa's role there.

LEAD: Since 1981, the poor woman who wants to end a pregnancy incurred through rape or incest has found no help in the Federal Government. That's when Congress removed the exception that allowed Federally funded abortions for those so victimized. She has, however, had a friend in Senator Lowell Weicker, the Connecticut
LEAD: Department of It's All a Question of How You Look at It:
LEAD: The Norwegian Government declared a pollution alert along its coastline today after an oil rig exploded and caught fire off the coast of Scotland, on the other side of the North Sea.

LEAD: In an effort to reduce the chances of a market collapse like last October's, the boards of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have approved a proposal under which trading in both markets could be halted before such a plunge.

LEAD: When word spread that the state planned to use 120 beds for AIDS patients at the Wanaque Convalescent Home, there was quite an ugly hoo-ha in this small town. The Mayor vowed, ''Never!'' and led pickets in circles. ''Keep AIDS Out of Wanaque!'' said signs.

LEAD: Representative Edward J. Markey, one of the key House Democrats with oversight responsibilities in the nation's securities markets, introduced his legislative proposal today to reform those markets in the wake of the October market collapse.
LEAD: The Political Language of Islam By Bernard Lewis 168 pages. The University of Chicago Press. $14.95.
LEAD: TBWA Advertising has been selected by Parfums Stern, a division of Avon Products, to create and place advertising for Oscar de la Renta fragrances for women and Perry Ellis Fragrance for Men.

LEAD: A ballot cast by the Heine Securities Corporation for Bank of New York during its campaign to unseat the board of Irving Bank should never have been revoked, a court-appointed referee concluded yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The New Jersey Health Commissioner today recommended the revaccination of certain groups of children in Burlington and Ocean Counties because of an outbreak of measles that began in May.

LEAD: Wrapping up an intense debate that has spanned five years, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to prevent public corporations from issuing new classes of stock that would diminish the voting power of their existing shareholders.

LEAD: A Soap Musical There aren't a whole lot of new musicals scheduled for the fall season, but there'll be at least one more if everything goes according to plan. It's a fable set in a Laundromat, it's called ''Suds'' (what else?), it played seven weeks to sellout audiences at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, and it's due here Sept.

LEAD: A not-so-little red brick schoolhouse once sat on a knoll not far from Main Street, here in the downtown section of this small city in Litchfield County. Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, learned arithmetic in its airy, high-ceiled classrooms. David Halberstam, the writer, played football on the dewy green grass behind the building.

LEAD: The defense in the Howard Beach racial-attack trial sought to show yesterday that the prosecution had improperly coached a victim so that he would later identify a defendant as one of his assailants.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today sent Congress a legislative proposal that would give the Federal Reserve Board the authority to set margins, or down payment requirements, on stock index futures and index options.
LEAD: Investors and industry experts reacted favorably yesterday to the announcement by the Sun Company late Thursday that it would spin off its domestic oil and gas production.

LEAD: A police officer was hit by a car and seriously injured and a passing motorist was inadvertently shot by another officer on Route 22 in Mountainside, N.J. yesterday in a bizarre chain of events that was set off by the report of a stolen car and that included a chase of several other cars stolen in separate incidents, the authorities said.

LEAD: A week after Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci ordered a freeze imposed on nine contracts under investigation in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud, Navy officials have not yet figured out how to carry out the order.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Gov. Rose Mofford of Arizona will not be charged in connection with gifts she gave as Secretary of State or with her financial disclosure statements, a County Attorney announced today.
LEAD: Governor Cuomo, complaining that he has been frustrated by the Republican-controlled State Senate, says he wants to push for a Democratic takeover in this year's election.
LEAD: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

LEAD: The Federal district judge in the Iran-contra case today ordered Oliver L. North to stand trial Sept. 20 on conspiracy charges. The judge also ordered prosecutors to give the defense any secret documents showing Mr. North acted with higher authority.

LEAD: Lynda Clarizio, an associate at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Mark Foulon, a Foreign Service officer assigned to head the political and economic section of the United States Consulate General in Jerusalem, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Verona, N.J.

LEAD: Four children and two adults were rescued this morning from the wreckage of the store where they had been entombed since Thursday in a macabre mix of concrete, steel, dirt and children's clothing that was still on hangers, price tags intact.

LEAD: Boxing Curry Wins Title: Donald Curry captured the World Boxing Council junior-middleweight title yesterday when a bleeding and battered Gianfranco Rosi failed to answer the bell for the 10th round in San Remo, Italy. Rosi, an Italian, went to his knees seven times in the nine rounds - he was knocked down five times and slipped twice - while losing the title in his second defense.
LEAD: Theodore Frederick Koop, a former vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died Thursday of complications following surgery at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 81 years old.
LEAD: The French champagne giant LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Guinness P.L.C. will take 10 percent stakes in each other under a complex deal whose terms were announced today.

LEAD: Hobbyists take holidays too, in the summer's heat and haze. There are fewer hobby shows and fewer opportunities to buy, sell and trade. So this is a good time to put a collection in order. You will get more enjoyment from your hobby when activity resumes in the autumn, and if your collection ends up in someone else's hands, he or she will thank you.

LEAD: In the late afternoon, before he walked to the mound to face the Kansas City Royals, John Candelaria sat in front of his dressing stall at Yankee Stadium and slowly unpacked the suitcase he had taken on the team's last trip. If he was disappointed about not being selected for next week's All-Star Game,

LEAD: President Oscar Arias Sanchez called on the Nicaraguan Government and contra leaders today to hold another round of peace talks before Secretary of State George P. Shultz returns to Central America on Aug. 1.
LEAD: William Walton Behind the Fcade By Susana Walton Illustratred. 255 pages. Oxford University Press. $22.95
LEAD: Labrador By Katheryn Davis 225 pages. Farrar,Straus & Giroux. $19.95
LEAD: The United States has received intelligence reports indicating that the Soviet Union may pull military units out of Hungary, a senior State Department official said today.

LEAD: Patsy Nasher, who with her husband, Raymond, created one of the world's leading collections of modern sculpture, died of cancer on July 1 at the Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas. She was 59 years old. Mrs. Nasher, a friend of many of the artists whose work she collected, began by collecting pre-Columbian art, later becoming interested in Texas artists and 20th-century

LEAD: Participants in a program sponsored by the New York Botanical Garden tilling an unlikely spot, Lafontaine Avenue and 179th Street in the Bronx. The garden provides its keepers with vegetables and flowers such as the hollyhock Jose Garcia is holding, above. At left, the program director, Terry Keller, teaches Michelle Inteagro, 5.

LEAD: The confusion over who has won Mexico's presidential election deepened here today as the Federal Electoral Commission canceled all further scheduled meetings and said no election results would be announced until Sunday.

LEAD: In a move that could bolster Taiwan's drive toward democracy, President Lee Teng-hui won the powerful post of ruling party chairman today at a landmark convention that will test the party's commitment to further change.

LEAD: A Federal court in California has issued the most definitive ruling yet that a Federal law barring discrimination against the handicapped protects healthy carriers of the AIDS virus as well as those who have actually developed the deadly disease.
LEAD: The Government published plans today to establish black regional assemblies that would have limited powers to make laws on matters like education, welfare and local rule.

LEAD: The retirement years can be among life's most fulfilling, with opportunity for travel and leisure, for community and volunteer work or for that hobby or second career one has always dreamed of - but only if the financing is in place.

LEAD: CBS announced yesterday a reworked schedule for the fall that emphasizes movies, mini-series and special programming by the network's sports and entertainment divisions. The move represents CBS's strategy for filling in gaps in its schedule left by the strike of the Writers Guild of America.

LEAD: Officials from many financial exchanges throughout the country yesterday criticized a plan by the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange under which trading could be halted in rapidly falling markets.

LEAD: Roy Williams, an assistant basketball coach at the University of North Carolina who received a strong recommendation from Coach Dean Smith of the Tar Heels, was named head coach at the University of Kansas yesterday.
LEAD: Massachusetts lawmakers have added to the 1989 budget a $1 million plan under which the state would pay suburban public schools to accept students who live in Boston and neighboring Worcester.

LEAD: Amid reports of medical waste washing ashore for a third day, 15 more miles of ocean beaches in New York City and on Long Island were closed to swimming yesterday, and it appeared likely that they would remain closed for part of the weekend.

LEAD: Resisting pressure to cut short platform debate at the Democratic National Convention, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has said he may go outside the convention hall in Atlanta to speak if he has to, aides in his campaign said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Shortly after noon on Wednesday, bathers at Lido Beach in Nassau County plucked two empty vials, syringes and other suspicious material from the surf. Almost immediately, worried lifeguards, following standing orders, ordered hundreds of bathers out of the water.

LEAD: Compared with the Metropolitan Opera's grandiose ''La Boheme,'' the New York City Opera's production has an appealingly modest, homey quality, and one could argue that its chamber opera ambiance is the most appropriate setting for Puccini's Bohemian love story. On Thursday evening at the New York State Theater, the company offered the first performance in this season's run.

LEAD: For the Mets, the omens weren't good: The Houston Astros hadn't beaten Dwight Gooden in four years and hadn't beaten anybody in five games, so they were probably coiled and dangerous. And, sure enough, they broke both streaks tonight.
LEAD: Evert Clark, a reporter who specialized in aviation, science and space, died Thursday after surgery for an aneurism at Montgomery General Hospital in Olney, Md. He was 62 years old.

LEAD: ''Summerpier,'' a free six-part series of outdoor performances, begins at 6:30 P.M. today at Pier 16, Fulton and South Streets. Among those appearing are Carlos Barbosa-Lima and Sharon Isbin, both guitarists, and the pianist and composer Emiliam Sichkin accompanied by an ensemble. Mr. Sichkin will give the world premiere of his ''Concerto for Astronauts.

LEAD: With only one of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's three completed merger deals in Texas having attracted much new cash from investors, some experts fear that the agency's slowly moving plan to close or merge more than 130 of the state's savings and loan institutions could hurt healthy institutions.

LEAD: American modern dance has been the raison d'etre of the American Dance Festival for 54 years. In the 1980's, however, there has been a new development: The performances, premieres, conferences and dance classes initiated by this ever-dynamic institution have also illuminated the burst of experimental activity in dance abroad.

LEAD: In a news conference reflecting a week of emotional strains and tensions, Fire Chief Anthony A. Aiellos said today that intense flames blocked attempts to rescue five firefighters who were killed in a burning auto dealership here a week ago.

LEAD: Mark McGwire of Oakland drove in two runs with a grounder tonight and his 16th home run and Dennis Eckersley earned his 26th save as the Athletics ended a losing streak at four games with a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
LEAD: Window service at the nation's post offices, reduced last February to save money, will be returned to normal levels in September, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank announced today.

LEAD: The Israeli Government announced tonight that it would expel 10 Palestinians accused of being ''active in various terrorist organizations which played a central role in planning and implementing'' the seven-month-old Palestinian uprising.

LEAD: Bobby Palmer, left, and Paul Choi, both 6 years old, awaiting the decision after their matches yesterday in the USA Karate Federation Atlantic League championship at Manhattan Community College. Choi was first and Palmer second in the 6-year-old novice category. (NYT/Neal Boenzi)

LEAD: Mayor Koch said the other day that the ''daughter of Westway has more than seven veils.'' He was probably too discreet to say that the veils are rapidly slipping off. As they reveal her blemishes, the danger increases that Westway's ''daughter'' will turn into another Westway fiasco.

LEAD: Two top officials of the telecommunications division of the General Services Administration are being reassigned and a deputy administrator of the agency has been transferred, agency staff members said yesterday.
LEAD: Over the protests of the Irving Bank Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday granted the Bank of New York a 60-day extension to continue its efforts to take over Irving.

The punchy ABC documentary was first broadcast in April and is being shown again tonight at 10 o'clock, as background for a new documentary, ''Drugs: Why This Plague?,'' which can be seen Monday at 8 P
LEAD: At the entrance to the newly renovated National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame here, the bell sounds over a life-size starting gate. And they're off!

LEAD: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a Hong Kong affiliate of New Zealand's largest investment concern, has purchased a 12.7 percent stake in the Durham Corporation, an insurance and broadcasting company in Raleigh, N.C. It will seek permission from regulators to raise its stake as high as 50 percent.
LEAD: Britain is engaged in a bitter debate over oil-rig safety after the explosion of a North Sea rig in which officials say 166 workers died.
LEAD: An off-duty court officer, Alphonso B. Deal, was killed in a gun battle Thursday night trying to keep peace on the block he loved.

LEAD: ''We suggest that the United States has some additional crimes stored away for Iran, and that is why we do not push for any revenge. Wise people understand why we do not take revenge.'' - Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of Iran's Parliament and commander of the armed forces. [ 1:3. ]

LEAD: James C. McKay, the independent prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, said today that a court order prohibiting any disclosure of his report on the Attorney General had been violated and that he would investigate and seek sanctions against those responsible.

LEAD: Loehmann's chain of specialty stores, one of the pioneers in discounting women's apparel, will be sold to an investor group led by Sefinco Ltd., of Spain, and the Sprout Group, a division of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

LEAD: Ray Barbuti, who won two gold medals in track for the United States in the 1928 Olympics and was for many years one of the leading officials in Eastern college football, died yesterday in Pittsfield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: A Brooklyn newspaper, citing medical records, has concluded that Tawana Brawley was a rape victim and that she was ''near death'' when found in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., last November after a four-day disappearance.

LEAD: On Friday some of the color will go out of the drug and cosmetics industries: Red No. 8, Red No. 9, Red No. 19 and Orange No. 17, to be precise.

LEAD: Dr. John D. Clark, a chemist who specialized in storable liquid rocket fuels, died Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J., after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Newfoundland, N.J.

LEAD: For sheer mad spectacle there is nothing quite like Hideki Noda's ''Comet Messenger - Siegfried,'' which is at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday. LEAD: A sampling of new patents illustrates how inventors keep thinking of new ways to play old games or to avoid familiar pests, especially in summer, when travel and outdoor activities are at their peak. Purifying Water With Ultraviolet Light
LEAD: In a modern industrial complex on the outskirts of Santiago, Chilean technicians are meticulously reconstructing a French-built Mirage 50 fighter plane that crashed two and a half years ago.
LEAD: Inmates wounded 15 corrections officers at Trenton State Prison today in what prison officials said was a planned attack. None of the officers were seriously hurt.

LEAD: Organizers hoping to promote a National Football League exhibition game here met with an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today. Avi Pazner, the spokesman for the Prime Minister, endorsed the idea, saying it would be good for Israel's image to stage such an event.

LEAD: * Armco Inc., Parsippany, N.J., said it would take a second-quarter charge of about $15 million related to those insurance operations of its Armco Financial Group that have stopped writing new business and are being liquidated.

LEAD: The founders of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation said they had revised a recapitalization plan to liquidate their holdings and temporarily ward off a potential takeover. Still to be worked out is the premium the company will pay for the founder's controlling stake and the restrictions on reselling new shares to be issued as part of the recapitalization.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Humor is not usually an element in card play, but there is an occasional opportunity for a sly technical joke. The most famous type is the Grosvenor Gambit, a conspicuously foolish play made in the knowledge that the opponent will not be able to take advantage of the opportunity that has been offered.
LEAD: Stock prices fell yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 16.54 points to close at 2,106.15.

LEAD: Employed March 115,839,000 April 116,445,000 May 115,909,000 June 116,703,000 Unemployed March 6,801,000 April 6,610,000 May 6,783,000 June 6,455,000 Employment figures include members of the armed forces in U.S. who numbered 1,685,000 in June.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A man believed to be an associate of the Gambino crime family was found dead Thursday in his apartment in Staten Island and appeared to have been murdered, the authorities said.

LEAD: International 2-5 Soviet troops may leave Hungary, according to the State Department, which said intelligence reports showed that Moscow may be preparing to withdraw some of the 65,000 troops stationed there. Page 1 Iran will not seek revenge against the United States for shooting down a civilian jet with 290 people, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of Iran's Parliament, told worshipers at Teheran University.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Prince Norodom Sihanouk today that Washington would support an international peacekeeping force to help guarantee a settlement in Cambodia, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: The former top education adviser to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was sentenced today to two and a half years in prison and ordered to pay up to $80,000 to the state in restitution for the money he siphoned from a program.

LEAD: Four out of every five flights into the nation's 27 busiest airports arrived on time in May, with airports in cities in the West and South showing the best records, the Transportation Department said Thursday.

LEAD: Leonard Cohen occupies a special niche in the roster of composer-performers who achieved prominence in the late 1960's. The singer, poet and guitarist, who played at the Ritz on Tuesday and moved to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, writes authentically poetic songs whose quasi-Biblical lyrics transform personal experience into the language of sacred myth.

LEAD: Haiti's military leader, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who last month seized power from the civilian Government of Leslie Manigat, announced today that a new constitution would soon be submitted to Haitians for approval to replace the one they approved 16 months ago. General Namphy indicated supporters of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship would be rehabilitated.

LEAD: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday gave an outdated name for a firm involved in a merger. The firm, which merged with Lord, Day & Lord earlier this year, was Barrett, Smith, Simon & Armstrong.

LEAD: Payless Cashways Inc. said a unnamed foreign company might make a proposal to acquire the company. The Kansas City, Mo., building supply concern has already accepted a $909 million leveraged buyout proposal led by a group of its senior management.
LEAD: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that his nation would ''not push for any revenge'' against the United States for shooting down a civilian jet carrying 290 people last Sunday.

LEAD: Considerable new information about the involvement of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in a number of matters under investigation is included in parts of an independent Federal prosecutor's report that were obtained today.
LEAD: The thermometer at the kitchen window, which is in shade, read 98 degrees at lunchtime, so we drove over to the shopping center to eat, rather than walk it.
LEAD: The designated hitter, the controversial element the American League adopted in 1973 and the World Series added in 1976, will become part of the All-Star Game next year.

LEAD: After almost 18 years in office, Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of New Jersey, knows only too well what the summer of an election year is like: Money has to be raised, the press needs to be prodded, advertisements must be prepared, volunteers must be enlisted. Then come the speeches, the debates, the whole great free-wheeling road show that is American democracy in action.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The early favorites in the Tour de France began sorting themselves out today as a time trial through the Rust Belt of the French North yielded the outlines of the scramble to come.

LEAD: Alfred Reginald Allen, who had a long career as an assistant general manager at the Metropolitan Opera and as the executive director of operations for Lincoln Center, died last Sunday in Washington. He was 83 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on June 29 about the birth of a child to Edwin and Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg misidentified Nancy Tuckerman. She is a spokeswoman for Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

LEAD: The good folks at the First New York International Festival of the Arts seem to have had trouble coming up with an alliterative marketing slogan for their concert Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall. This was an imaginative grouping of three contemporary practitioners of extended vocal techniques, none well known to the general public.

LEAD: Vladimir Agopov, a Ukrainian composer who teaches in Finland, recently delivered a new string quartet to his colleagues of the Sibelius Academy Quartet. They in turn brought the piece - Mr. Agopov's second in the genre - to listeners at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Major Indoor Soccer League, which lost two more franchises yesterday to reduce its membership to seven teams, will begin discussions next week to determine the future of the league, Commissioner Bill Kentling said. The Tacoma Stars and the Chicago Sting, who failed to post a $400,000 letter of credit by the deadline yesterday, joined the St.
LEAD: For months now Suren Bursalyan had been expecting his brother, Zareh, to emigrate from Soviet Armenia to join him in Hollywood, but the phone call from Moscow Wednesday brought bad news.

LEAD: Margaret Ochs Palmer, founder in the early 1030's of a West Orange, N.J., workshop for people with disabilities, died yesterday at Shell Point Village, a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla., after a long illness. She was 90 years old.
LEAD: More than 100 people were killed today when a train derailed while crossing a bridge in southern India, plunging the engine and nine cars packed with passengers into a lake.

LEAD: Binoculars come out in summer, for nature watching, sporting events and outdoor festivals. When shopping for a pair - through a catalogue or at a specialty store - consider not just the magnification power, but also the angle of view and the size of the front and rear glass elements. The wider the angle, the easier it is to track moving subjects.

LEAD: Joseph A. Brunton Jr., chief executive of the Boy Scouts of America from 1960 to 1967, died yesterday after a long illness at St. Barnabas Village, a retirement home in Gibsonia, Pa., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: The closest American equivalent to Sound Space Ark, the Japanese new-music quintet, is the original lineup of Tashi. Both groups were formed in the early 1970's and brought together an odd but flexible combination of instruments, and both had a fascination with the music of the Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis courted a Vice-Presidential prospect today, embraced a former rival and, in his last campaign swing before the Democratic National Convention, offered words of economic hope for the West and the Southwest.

LEAD: What proportion of students drop out of New York City high schools? According to a recent study by the Board of Education, the figure is 26.3 percent, an improvement from the 27.9 percent calculated a year ago. But by another, more sophisticated calculation that tracks students through all four years, the rate is 22.4 percent, up from 21.8.

LEAD: The theme had been repeated on election day for as long as anyone could remember as both supporters and opportunists gathered Wednesday evening to celebrate the victory of the presidential candidate of Mexico's long-ruling official party.

LEAD: A front-page headline and a subheading on Tuesday on an article about actions taken by a white F.B.I. agent, Gary W. Miller, against a black agent characterized Mr. Miller's admissions incorrectly. As the article reported, Mr. Miller acknowledged that he and his colleagues planned a campaign of ''retribution'' against the black agent, but Mr.

LEAD: Explosive percussion and flamboyant dancing concluded the World Pop series of the First New York International Festival of the Arts on Thursday. Two groups from French-speaking West Africa, Les Amazones de Guinee and a 30-member percussion orchestra from Senegal led by Doudou N'diaye Rose, made their American debuts in a euphoric concert at the Beacon

LEAD: The New Orleans Saints signed first-round draft choice Craig (Ironhead) Heyward of Pitt to a three-year contract yesterday that did not include a weight clause. Terms were not disclosed. His agent, Bruce Allen, refused even to say whether it was close the league average of $1.1 million paid to first-round draft choices last year.

LEAD: A lawsuit seeking $6.9 million in compensatory damages and an unspecified amount of punitive damages was filed yesterday in Lexington, Ky., by Dwane Casey, an assistant basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, against Emery Air Freight Corporation.

LEAD: Vice President Bush, arriving today for a rally in the city where the Democrats will soon gather for their national convention, found himself recoiling from Democratic charges about who is paying some of his campaign costs.

LEAD: A race far closer than even the opposition expected has left real doubt over who the next Mexican president will be. That in itself is a political earthquake in a country where the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has captured every presidential, senatorial and gubernatorial election since its formation in 1929.
LEAD: Insect repellents are standard summer equipment in beach bags and backyards. Nevertheless, they should be used with care.

LEAD: Heinz Rehfuss, a distinguished Swiss bass-baritone known for his musicianship and for his interpretation of music by such modern masters as Hindemith, Stravinsky and Frank Martin, died of cancer June 27 in Buffalo. He was 71 years old.

LEAD: House Republicans are forever complaining that the majority Democrats, who have reigned for three decades, act as if they owned the place. Much of that is sour grapes. But the Republican leadership now documents trends that reveal the hazards of prolonged one-party control.

LEAD: The ad firm of Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey is one of Madison Avenue's hot new agencies, but the fact is the principals can't play golf. If you don't think that hurts, you should have been around recently when they were wooing a new client, an auto importer.

LEAD: Donald Trump said today he would act as an adviser to Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, on business and boxing matters. The real estate developer is also aligning himself with Tyson in the dispute with Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager.

LEAD: Britain announced a major arms agreement with Saudi Arabia today, apparently involving planes, helicopters, ships and construction projects in a 10-year arrangement that will replace the United States as the Arab kingdom's main arms supplier.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, lost his last stronghold in the Beirut area today when a handful of his followers were forced out of a refugee district on the southern outskirts of the city.
LEAD: The International Tennis Federation has voted to adopt the tie breaker in Davis Cup competition beginning next year, following the formula used in the Grand Slam tournaments.

LEAD: As Michael S. Dukakis neared a decision on a running mate, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today distanced himself from his own campaign manager's criticism of Senator Albert Gore Jr., who has emerged as one of the top contenders for the post.
LEAD: Fourteen marines who were wounded in a mortar accident that killed two other marines have been flown to Honolulu for further medical treatment, officials say.

LEAD: Corn and soybean prices fell yesterday, partly because many market participants have begun to liquidate or hedge their positions as they await a special Agriculture Department report on Tuesday on the estimated crop damage caused by the nation's worst drought since the 1930's.

LEAD: These are the times that try men's microchips, when overloaded electrical systems fail and are restored with a surge of power, when lightning bolts hit overhead lines and send through thousands of volts.
LEAD: Last year Fairway Ford sold nearly 20,000 new cars and trucks from its tiny building in this bucolic western Pennsylvania community.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: Spurred by the prospect of a stronger United States economy, the dollar surged against the West German mark yesterday, reaching its highest level in almost 10 months.

LEAD: A report of a steep decline in the nation's unemployment rate in June sent prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbling and yields soaring yesterday. The discount rates on Treasury bills also soared as this latest sign of economic growth heightened fears that the Federal Reserve would tighten credit to prevent a resurgence of inflation.

LEAD: The Texas Rangers have placed Larry Parrish, a designated hitter, on the irrevocable waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release, the team announced yesterday. . . . Tom Lasorda was given a contract extension through 1990 by the Los Angeles Dodgers, the club announced yesterday.

LEAD: In baseball, a grand slam is as common as a rhinestone. But in tennis or golf, a Grand Slam is a velvet pouch with four different precious jewels. As the Australian and French champion, Mats Wilander had an opportunity for a tennis Grand Slam this year. But even as Wilander advanced to the Wimbledon quarterfinals, Don Budge doubted that the sturdy
LEAD: Questions appear on page 16.

LEAD: The Peterson Publishing Company, owner of such magazines as Motor Trend and Off-Road, said today that it had acquired Sport magazine from an investor group that has owned the monthly magazine for two years. No terms were disclosed.

LEAD: With young workers finding an exceptional number of jobs, the nation's unemployment rate slid three-tenths of a point last month to 5.2 percent, the lowest since May 1974, the Labor Department announced today.

LEAD: Today is the 50th anniversary of the death of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court, a remarkable figure who still has much to say to us about the way judges should decide cases.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Music is an element that we often take for granted when going to the movies. An effective score blends with the action so seamlessly that we may not be fully conscious of the emotional buttons being pushed. But take away the music and what's left can look dull and aimless.
LEAD: In a testy confrontation, Federal prosecutors suggested yesterday that a prominent New York law firm violated professional ethics in a billing arrangement with the Wedtech Corporation.

LEAD: Fifty 12-year-old musicians from the Chien Jin Primary School in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, performing at Queens Borough Hall. The Chinese classical orchestra performed the concert as part of an Independence Day celebration to honor residents of all national origins. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation suspects that three of the nation's largest military contractors gave money and gifts to Melvyn R. Paisley and his wife, Vicki, during Mr. Paisley's five and a half years as the Navy's top purchasing official, according to a search warrant made public here today.
LEAD: C. Jared Ingersoll, a former railroad executive and Philadelphia civic leader, died yesterday in his sleep in Dunwoody Village, a retirement home in New Town Square, Pa. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: Americans increased their installment borrowing at a modest annual rate of 4.6 percent in May, as growth in consumer credit slowed from the rapid expansion of earlier this year.
LEAD: DESPITE the popularity of aluminum and vinyl siding and other contemporary varieties, many homes still feature traditional overlapping wood clapboards.

LEAD: Q. The ceiling in our upstairs bathroom develops ugly black stains that look like mold. We keep repainting, but the stains return. Is there a special kind of paint we can use?

Chandler, chief executive of the Eastman Kodak Company. But there is a good chance that their successors - or their successors' successors - will have a foreign stint on their resumes.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson vowed today to carry on his Presidential campaign despite criticism, including strong complaints from supporters of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, that he did not know how to stop.

LEAD: The directors of the two biggest international development agencies today rejected accusations that they imposed unjustifiably harsh economic policies on developing countries, causing human suffering and environmental damage.

LEAD: When Sister Rose Philippine Duchesne worked among the Potawatomi Indians of Kansas in the 1840's, she was called ''Quah-kah-ka-num-ad,'' the woman who always prays. Last week she officially became a woman to be prayed to - Pope John Paul II canonized her as the fourth American to attain sainthood.

LEAD: ''BYE, Mrs. Fisk have a nice summer.'' The lazy, hazy summer hasn't started yet, but my sophomores are busy taking exams, and I'm running back and forth to the bookroom returning American lit texts and counting ripped covers. It's that wonderful quiet time between the end of the school year and the beginning of vacation and it's a time of taking inventory both literally and figuratively.

But they are some of Spain's new fashion-makers, an expanding constellation of designers who showed their collections for fall l988 in Barcelona and Madrid earlier this year.

LEAD: It is true, at least in this one respect, that the movies are like life: beautiful women are all over the place. Beyond that - for me, anyway - the two media begin to diverge, each with its own inevitable vexations, though in the movies women are not among them. After all, they exist in two dimensions only, and that really uncomplicates everything.

LEAD: New Yorkers paid $14.5 billion more in taxes to the Federal Government last year than they got back in aid and programs from Washington, according to a report issued this week by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

LEAD: IT was threatening to rain that morning when I decided to walk into Hartsdale to go to the bank and the hardware store. I probably should have carried an umbrella, but I was feeling optimistic and decided that I would surely get back before the rain came.
LEAD: SOMETHING caught fire in the house I live in last night. The house didn't blow up or burst into flames but I was frightened nevertheless.

LEAD: BEFORE the People Mover monorail in Detroit began shuttling passengers around a 2.9-mile loop a year ago, critics feared it would be a ''horizontal elevator to nowhere.'' Instead, it has become a tourist attraction, drawing crowds that ride the computer-driven trains and look at the graffiti-free award-winning art in the stations.

LEAD: Mrs. Robert George Pancotti of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carolyn Ann Pancotti, to Michael Bradley Ray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Ray of Manhasset, L.I. Ms. Pancotti is the daughter also of the late Mr. Pancotti.

LEAD: IT IS 10 A.M. ON A MONDAY, and the Surgeon General is already at war. C. Everett Koop is addressing a room choked with reporters at the Department of Health and Human Services. As he stands with Amish severity in his Navy uniform, jabbing his pointer at poster-sized graphs and charts, Koop looks less like a spokesman for national health than a commodore outlining his battle plans.

LEAD: Corrie Fowler, a 29-year-old mother of four, spends her days and nights with her children inside one room in a welfare hotel in Newark, waiting for the one hot meal a day that uses up the daily $22.50 allowance for a family of five.

LEAD: With political tension growing in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government has refused to grant permission for a protest march organized by anti-Sandinista trade unions and supported by opposition political parties.

LEAD: Martha Rountree Collett and Francis Robert Mellon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mellon of Douglaston, Queens, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Sterling Ruffin Collett Jr., in Morganton, N.C. The Rev. Parker Trevilian Williamson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Indictments were issued against the GAF Corporation, its vice chairman and two of its subsidiaries on charges that they manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986 after GAF failed in an attempt to take over Carbide. Prosecutors contend that GAF and Jefferies & Company, a Los Angeles brokerage, agreed for Jefferies to buy large blocks of Carbide stock to inflate the price so that GAF could get a higher return from selling its 10 percent stake in Carbide.

LEAD: The Suffolk business community is overreacting [ ''Businesses Assess Impact of Law on Video Terminals,'' June 19 ] . As a business executive operating an enterprise that employs more than 100 people, I too am concerned when government mandates an increase in my costs of doing business. But the fears of many employers are unfounded.

LEAD: New England Telephone considers the addition of a new area code in Massachusetts a positive reflection of the state's prosperity, and besides, it was unavoidable. To many of its customers, the change is a nuisance and some of them are fighting it down to the wire.

LEAD: George Bernard Shaw once claimed that there were three tragic nations: the Jews, the Irish and the Poles. Of these it is the Poles whose history, passions and culture are least known by other nations. For a thousand years they have straddled a civilizational fault line where the influence of Rome gives way to Byzantium.
LEAD: Ellis Burks's tie-breaking, bases-loaded single keyed a six-run 10th inning as the Boston Red Sox beat the Chicago White Sox, 8-2, tonight to gain a doubleheader split.

LEAD: Evelyn Waugh's novel ''A Handful of Dust'' is the work of a man who had been deeply wounded by the failure of his first marriage: lurking at the heart of it are a cry of pain and an act of revenge. It is true that by the time Waugh's feelings reached the printed page, they had been transmuted into comedy - he was far too much of an artist to serve them up raw.

LEAD: Demographers tell us that human fecundity increases in time of war and other catastrophe. A sort of population thermostat apparently kicks in, as if nature were programmed to counteract the death count. Some cultural historians have suggested in a similarly mystical vein that artistic creativity tends to decline in relatively calm periods, but to flourish when society is convulsed.

LEAD: Philip E. Marlow, 10, sits high in a tree in the Forest of Dean, which, with its abundant, heavy foliage, looks as if it might once have sheltered Robin Hood, Will Scarlet, Friar Tuck and the others. The Forest of Dean is, instead, a kind of seed covering for West Gloucestershire's sooty, barren coal-mining villages, where lives are as bleak as the forest is rich.

LEAD: SALAD is usually served after the main course. But in the summer I sometimes like to serve salad and a fish or meat dish together. This practice is not only convenient, simplifying things when you are entertaining - it is ideal when you want to eat light.

LEAD: LESS than an hour's drive south of Amsterdam is a region that seems a microcosm of the Dutch countryside. Enfolding the River Vecht in its north-south course between Vreeland and Maarssen, the region consists of centuries-old villages, expanses of flat and watery pasture land punctuated by windmills, castles and dozens of mansions built by Amsterdam merchants as weekend retreats during the 17th and 18th centuries.

The large barn-like stand on Chestnut Ridge Road is a mini-mall of produce and trinkets. The northern Bergen County farm stayed intact as it was surrounded by wealthy suburbs such as Saddle River and Montvale, skirted by the Garden State

LEAD: The Phobos spacecraft, center, on the launching pad Friday at the Baikonur astrodrome. The unmanned craft will travel about 400,000 miles in 200 days to explore Mars and Phobos, a small gray moon of the planet. (Tass via Agence France-Presse)

LEAD: Less than two weeks ago, the several institutions housed within the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris launched a multidisciplinary examination of the explosion of art, culture and commerce that followed World War II. From now until Oct. 17, when this effort draws to a close, the Pompidou is once more the scene of the kind of multimedia extravaganza for which it is best known.

LEAD: PROPOSALS to expand the role of the armed forces in drug interdiction have been the most publicized aspect of the Congressional war on drugs, and legislation intended to accomplish that is included in the $299.5 billion defense authorization bill that was approved in late June by House and Senate negotiators.
LEAD: Lou Whitaker hit a three-run homer and Darrell Evans had a bases-empty shot as the Detroit Tigers beat the Oakland Athletics, 4-3, today in a match of divisional leaders.

LEAD: The Mets continued their midseason swoon today, when they lost for the fourth time in five games. This time they fell to a legend: Nolan Ryan, the king of the strikeout pitchers.

LEAD: Since Eastern Airlines was bought by Texas Air, Eastern has been plagued by troubles, ranging from poor relations between its labor unions and management to big financial losses. LEAD: America has devised many new media for advertising, including cable television, auto bumpers, skywriters at the beach and blimps at the ballpark. Of them all, the most intriguing may be the human torso, medium for message T-shirts.

LEAD: THE name Guadalcanal generates feelings that still stir the American soul. Here, in 1942, United States marines were very nearly abandoned on a toehold of beach and jungle. Then, after six months of grisly fighting, they brought the Japanese onslaught to deadly and permanent halt. The story of that fighting, at places with names engraved in the American memory - Red Beach and the Tenaru River, Matanikau, Lunga Point and Bloody Ridge overlooking Henderson Field - was written by a correspondent who slogged the ridge and jungle with men of the First Marine Division.

LEAD: ONE fine morning quite recently, I occupied myself doing some neglected housework, but even while I washed the dishes, folded the laundry and swept the kitchen floor, my subconscious wrestled with weighty problems, such as which writing project I would begin now that my contemporary horror novel was finished.

LEAD: The recent announcement by the WD-40 Company of San Diego that its well-known penetrating oil - dear to the heart of every handyman or mechanic wrestling with a rust-frozen nut or bolt - is also being used as a fish attractant is not as startling as some might think.

LEAD: At Carlyle Towers in Cliffside Park, N.J., exposure sets expense. LEAD: Rescue workers loading debris into a scoop yesterday as they continued to dig through the rubble of the store that collapsed Thursday in Brownsville, Tex. The volunteers have reached the first floor of the three-story building. One body was removed yesterday and is thought to be the last victim. At least 14 people were killed and 47 injured in the disaster.

LEAD: A COMPANY can trim its staff overnight, but the task of trimming office space is rarely as fast or simple. Like a jigsaw puzzle with missing pieces, a company that dismisses employees and perhaps eliminates a weak department rarely fits back together easily in a new compact form.

What else could a listener expect? The young Soviet musician won first prize in the Paganini Competition three years ago at the age of 16.

LEAD: A chart last week about water consumption gave incorrect figures for fresh-water use in the United States. Daily residential use was 25.4 billion gallons in 1980 and 28.4 billion gallons in 1985. Daily industrial and commercial use was 51 billion gallons in 1980 and 37.9 billion gallons in 1985.

LEAD: ACROBATIC CHINESE Feats that for centuries entertained Chinese emperors (known to be a hard audience) will be performed tomorrow at the McCarter Theater in Princeton when the Chinese Golden Dragon Acrobats and Magicians of Taipei take the stage.

LEAD: HOUSING abandonment, once the scourge of New York City neighborhoods, has declined sharply over the last few years. Even so, city officials are preparing to assume ownership of a few thousand more parcels of real estate on which owners have fallen behind in their property taxes.

LEAD: Malaysia, concerned about a sustained increase in the number of Vietnamese boat people arriving on its east coast, is sending its Foreign Minister, Abu Hassan Omar, to Hanoi soon to urge Vietnam to stop the refugee outflow at the source.

Back in the not-so-distant 1970's, Iggy Pop, Patti Smith and Pere Ubu were wild-eyed rebels, out to overhaul and shake up the rock music they saw ossifying around them.

LEAD: Eventful is the word for the Paris Opera Ballet's highly varied season that closed last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. New York saw a great deal of unusual, even extraordinary, presentations for the first time.

Musical, because Mr. N'Dour and Mr. Keita have two of the finest voices around, irrespective of genre; and both of them set their singing in ebullient, triumphant, rhythmically enlivening instrumental contexts.

The future bride, who is an assistant in the facilities-planning department of the Hearst Corporation in New York, graduated from Boston University.

LEAD: THE hot summer became even hotter during last month's unseasonable heat wave when a number of swimming pools and beach areas were closed by the County Health Department. According to waterfront and pool directors, the closings came swiftly and without much warning, after new regulations by the New York State Public Health Council.

LEAD: THE loud sound emanating from Mexico last week was that of a monolith shattering. After nearly 60 years of virtually unchallenged one-party rule, the Institutional Revolutionary Party was introduced to competitive politics and immediately found the results not entirely to its liking.

LEAD: The simultaneous booking of Vince Giordano's 10-piece band, the Nighthawks, and Frank Vignola's string quartet, the Hot Club of France, for a four-week engagement at Michael's Pub that began on Tuesday, suggests that the restaurant at 211 East 55th Street is offering a double bill. In a sense it is, but the quartet has been enfolded within the big band to form a large ensemble in which the groups sometimes play separately and at times are combined.

LEAD: A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that 13 unexploded dynamite bombs discovered in this small community earlier in the week had been traced to a theft of dynamite in another Indiana town last month.

LEAD: ''The street is a room by agreement,'' the great architect Louis Kahn said many years ago. In his characteristically poetic manner, Kahn was stating perhaps the most important truth about the design of cities: that there is a kind of social contract involved in the making of a well-designed city, a tacit understanding that buildings be placed so as to make a coherent whole.

LEAD: This year is replete with audio anniversaries. The centennial of the phonograph record, as distinct from Edison's cylinder, was celebrated in May. This fall will see the fifth birthday of digital disks, and right about now - as far as anyone can fix the date - is the 30th birthday of stereo.

LEAD: History has never been easy for the French. It has, for them, probably more than for any other European people, produced a mix of exultation and anguish. Ninety-nine years ago, the French celebrated the 100th anniversary of the beginning of their great Revolution of 1789, and, by a rather extraordinary coincidence, they did so only a couple of years after inaugurating for the first time a permanently republican form of government, finishing a century-long alternation between monarchy and anarchy.

LEAD: TERRY BACKER, 34 years old, of Norwalk, the new appointed Soundkeeper, is charged with protecting the marine resources of Long Island Sound. He is also president of the 300-member Connecticut Coastal Fishermen's Association, which set up the Long Island Soundkeeper Fund after receiving a $176,000 settlement in its lawsuit against the City of Norwalk for dumping sewage into Norwalk Harbor.

Kemp of upstate New York yesterday at a rally in Atlanta, where the Democratic National Convention opens July 18. ''If you're undertaxed, vote for Dukakis,'' he said. LEAD: A Pro Bowl selection at free safety for six of his seven years with San Francisco, Ronnie Lott yesterday signed a 3-year $2.5 million contract with the 49ers making him the team's highest paid defensive player.

LEAD: A Travel Advisory report on June 26 about an exhibition of Chinese art misstated the university affiliation of an organizer, Dr. Robert Thorp. It is Washington University, in St. Louis, not George Washington University, which is in Washington.

LEAD: What do the following operas have in common: ''Carmen,'' ''Tristan und Isolde,'' ''Marriage of Figaro,'' ''Dido and Aeneas,'' ''Norma,'' ''Mignon,'' ''The Magic Flute,'' ''Parsifal,'' ''La Gioconda,'' ''Cenerentola'' and ''Die Walkure''? All of them - or, rather, parts of them - appear in some form as parts of yet another opera, John Cage's first, titled ''Europera,'' which will have its American premiere Thursday (with repeats on Saturday and next Sunday) at the PepsiCo Summerfare in Purchase, N.Y.
LEAD: More than 85 percent of Vermont's dairy producers have applied for subsidies under the first such state program of direct payments to farmers.

LEAD: A security guard, on overnight vigil outside a Staten Island pizzeria, was found shot to death yesterday morning outside the store, which the killer apparently had broken into before fleeing empty-handed, the police reported.

LEAD: Next January, the new President will confront complicated and demanding challenges to national security policy. Although internal changes in the Soviet Union may offer new opportunities, Soviet military power continues to grow. Arms control negotiations will become more complicated. We face new threats from terrorism and other forms of unconventional warfare.
LEAD: By 9 A.M. most mornings, Harvey Zirofsky is on the street in Brooklyn tracking down one of the half-dozen truant high school students he sets out to find on a typical day.

LEAD: Disclosures from the Justice Department's broad investigation of fraud in military procurement have provoked disputes between lawmakers and the Pentagon over the best way to change the military's purchasing system.

The manager saw the shortstop chase foul balls ''that he had no chance for, that were 40 feet into the stands.'' At bat, the player was so undisciplined, recalled the manager, ''that he'd swing and miss so hard he'd wind up in the other team's dugout.

LEAD: The Senate has voted to replace a rule requiring city employees to live in the District of Columbiawith a hiring plan that gives preference to residents of the District. The measure modified earlier House action that would have killed the residency rule.

Those shouting for Shelton Jones and Jerome Lane, as I naturally was, were blinded by loyalty and poor judgment.

LEAD: Gary Jobson, representing the United States, waiting on his boat yesterday for a wind to fill the sails at the Liberty Cup competition in New York.
