LEAD: There's a Cape Cod town for every character.

LEAD: A GROWING number of authorities believe that the age of mass supersonic air transportation in long-haul routes may be in the offing. If they are correct, there will be major opportunities for aircraft manufacturers, airlines and travelers alike. Significant steps are being taken to make this development a reality.

LEAD: NED SCHNURMAN knows what he should do when he returns to New York after a vacation. He should, as he put it, ''go home, unpack, go into the office the next day with presents for everybody and be a nice guy.'' He does none of those things. He times his return so that he can go directly to the office, luggage and all.

LEAD: PEOPLE LIKE US. By Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Plunging into this densely populated roman a clef by the author of ''The Two Mrs. Grenvilles'' is like coming late to a cocktail party where the socially prominent guests are already in full cry. Although the faces are familiar, there are too many to sort out; at first it's hard to catch the tune, but give it time.

LEAD: A gun club must pay a woman $100 in damages for denying her membership application in 1980 and admit her, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. The Concord Rod and Gun Club Inc. had appealed a Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination order, affirmed by a lower court, that the woman, Donna Page, was unconstitutionally excluded from the all-male club.

A wealth of indigenous and imported plants flourish in the southern tip of the state - the only area in the continental United States where cultivation of a wide range of tropical fruits and vegetables can take place.

The sale puts on public view one of the most important collections of Art Deco ever assembled, and one that was put together in almost utter secrecy.

LEAD: IN 1985, a Trenton businessman named Shelley Zeiger initiated a sister relationship between his own city and the Lenin District in Moscow. Since then, Trenton has been host to Ukrainian dancers and the Kirov and Moscow Ballets.

LEAD: SOMETIMES, as dawn's first purple splotches ooze through the folds of mist that swaddle the steep hills here, the rattle of firecrackers echoes from a not too distant treeless slope as a group of Miao people bury one of their dead. Though burials are officially banned in China in favor of cremation, the coffin-maker on the main street was busy the day before, planing and sanding long white planks in a trade that has all but disappeared from this country.

LEAD: HEARTS OF LIONS: The History of American Bicycle Racing. By Peter Nye. (Norton, $19.95.) Peter Nye has written a sumptuously detailed account of American bicycle racing, emphasizing the early years when cycling was a big-money sport. Drawing principally on newspaper accounts, Mr. Nye chronicles the amazing feats of competitors such as Charles (Mile-a-Minute) Murphy, who in 1899 covered a mile in 57.8 seconds riding through the slipstream of a Long Island Rail Road locomotive.

LEAD: One car of an Amtrak train derailed near here early today, injuring a passenger and delaying the Miami-to-New York run by about four hours, a spokesman for the railroad said. The accident occurred when an axle broke, the official said. The passenger's injuries were not believed to be serious, the spokesman said.

LEAD: Donna Akerson, who hopes to be a V.P. or - who knows? - maybe even a C.E.O. someday, is 6 months and 18 credits away from her M.B.A. She knows all about cost accounting and operations research, and the other day, she learned all about white-collar crime.

Tannenbaum of Jericho, L.I. Miss Rosenberg is the manager of an Ann Taylor store in Richmond. Her fiance is a member of the class of '89 at the Medical College of Virginia.

LEAD: In June 1956, the most senior representatives of the Yugoslav and Soviet Governments -Tito and Khrushchev, accompanied by their chiefs of staff - sit in one of the parlor cars of the special train that shuttles between Moscow and Kiev. There is no need for an interpreter. Since their schedule is overburdened (the meeting's purpose is to smooth out the numerous ideological differences that had accumulated during the Yugoslav ''schism''), little time remains for ancillary matters.

LEAD: Tennis Muster in U.S. Pro Final: Eighth-seeded Tom Muster of Austria defeated Bruno Oresar, 7-5, 6-0, yesterday to advance to the final of the United States Pro championships. The 21-year-old Oresar struggled through a series of long games in the early stages of the 1-hour-22-minute match at Longwood Cricket Club and led, 5-2.
LEAD: On the eve of baseball's midsummer classic in this election year, consider the differences between how we select baseball All-Stars and how we choose a President.

LEAD: SINCE it turned out its first batch 13 months ago, a concrete factory that New York City helped establish has changed owners. Now city officials say the plant, at the foot of West 57th Street, is finally ready to do what they wanted it to do all along, spur competition in the construction industry.

LEAD: To the Editor: It's about time that hotels included state and local taxes in their advertised rates. Instead of running in small print, ''Taxes not included,'' just say, ''Taxes included'' in regular print. For example, the uninitiated would be astonished at the big addition to their bill at New York hotels.

LEAD: A Communist Party commission reviewing the repressions under Stalin announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was posthumously reinstated as a member of the party on June 21.

LEAD: CLOSE your eyes. Think Clam Diggers Restaurant. What do you see: a rustic fish house, shore dinners, steamers, paper plates? Now, open your eyes and look at Shelter Island's Clam Diggers Restaurant: a bright yellow Victorian house with hanging baskets of fuchsias and outdoor dining porches. Inside, it is white lace curtains, tablecloths, cut flowers, candlelight, floral paintings, antiques, towering vases of flowering branches and strains of progressive jazz in the background.

LEAD: China will send 301 athletes, its largest delegation ever, to the Seoul Olympics and will compete in 20 of the 23 sports, the official Xinhua News Agency said today. LEAD: IF you want free maps and information from a state travel bureau in the busy season, do not wait until the last week before vacation to ask. LEAD: I was struck by the portrait of Frank Lentricchia teaching ''The Waste Land'' and ''pointing out the buried allusions to Ovid and Dante, Marvell and Verlaine.'' Mr. Lentricchia's lecture is undoubtedly at its most effective when his students know Ovid and Dante firsthand and not merely as disembodied references.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As a junior at Yale, majoring in literature, I found James Atlas's article interesting. The movement to widen the academic canon is not just an effort by junior faculty ''to define themselves and to validate their own identities.'' It is also an attempt by students to establish a curriculum which reflects the variety of cultures in the nation and world we live in.

LEAD: A polar map of Canada and the Soviet Union in The Week in Review last Sunday carried erroneous shading, misrepresenting the status of the sovereign territory of Finland. Finland should have been shaded, not left white like the Soviet land mass.

LEAD: WHICH brand of floppy diskettes do you buy? The question is not a trivial one, especially for those companies that buy thousands of diskettes a year. Prices for standard double-density floppy diskettes range from $1 to $5 for a 3.5-inch diskette and 30 cents to $1.50 for a 5.25-inch model. The price range on other types of diskettes is even wider.

Mr. Phillips, who had been suffering from cancer, was 65 years old.

LEAD: James Atlas's article stresses canon revision as reapportionment - expansion of the tradition to include writers hitherto ignored or devalued. But equally important is the reformulation of the canon from inside. For example, feminist critics and new historicists agree that Shakespeare's work cannot be treated as esthetically autonomous or historically transcendent.

LEAD: Richard Becken had worked 14 years as an engineer at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant in this southeast Vermont community of 4,000 residents when the company, which employed 300 people at a time, pulled out in April 1987. Now, one year later, Mr. Becken is back at the plant in a business of his own.

LEAD: Harold Salmon's ancestors were ''sooners'' long before anyone heard of Oklahoma and Conestoga wagons. LEAD: THE state meat store on Malaya Kolkhoznaya Ploshchad offered a typical selection the other day - baloney, salami and baloney. In the fish store a few doors down a sales clerk was pounding a block of frozen ocean perch with a sledgehammer to break off pieces for a long line of impatient customers. At the fresh produce shop next door, beets, cabbage and a mound of soggy squash were the vegetables of the day.

LEAD: ''Sure, I'm nervous about flying through the gulf, and I have been for a long time,'' said Capt. Harold Ewing, a commercial pilot who regularly flies Boeing 747 airliners into Dubai. ''Everybody is.'' Commercial airline pilots and air traffic controllers in the southern Persian Gulf are among the most eager to hear the conclusions of investigators looking into the downing Sunday of an Iranian airliner by a United States warship.

LEAD: A Labor of Love

LEAD: The other evening my son and a dozen or so classmates pped up to his teacher and received an official-looking diploma, complete with ribbon. It was the annual picnic of the cooperative nursery school where Sam had spent two years of his young life and from which he was now graduating. My husband and I, bleary-eyed and reeling from the round of wholesome family activities that mark the end of every school year, looked on, slightly stunned, feeling as if we were watching a movie.

LEAD: The Chilingirian String Quartet drew a slim crowd for its First New York International Festival of the Arts concert Thursday night at the 92d Street Y. But then, this was a pretty rarefied program for any time of the year, and for those who bothered to scale its heights, the rewards proved considerable.

LEAD: A SERIES of studies will get under way this summer, all seeking ways to protect or enhance a necessity: water.

LEAD: IF it's difficult for young married couples, single professionals and semiskilled workers to find affordable housing on Long Island, it's even more difficult for young people who finish high school and leave family homes to live on their own. For many, there is no choice.

LEAD: Poland could start fully servicing its huge foreign debt by the end of 1991 provided exports continue to grow, the National Bank president, Wladyslaw Baka, said. Mr. Baka, appointed Poland's economic chief last month, also indicated he would follow a tight money policy to curb inflation that some economists say will exceed 60 percent by year-end.

LEAD: Despite the television writers' strike and the growing success of the cable networks, early signs are that the ''up front'' buying season for the three television networks will be stronger than anticipated, executives from advertising agencies and television networks say.

LEAD: Danny Mydlack takes us on a tour of his distinctive art and life in ''How to Win Friends and Influence People,'' presented over the weekend at Performance Space 122. LEAD: A 17-year-old Palestinian was shot dead early this morning by soldiers who opened fire on Arab protesters who had attacked them with rocks at a roadblock on the West Bank, an army spokesman said.

LEAD: House members came close to approving an effective plan to shut some obsolete military bases last week, then shelved it and went home for the weekend. Preliminary votes showed solid support, but last-minute maneuvering by the Democratic leadership scuttled a similar plan last year. It's time, and there's plenty of reason, to let the apparent majority prevail.
LEAD: The dollar began the week higher against the Japanese yen in early trading today, while stock prices eased.
LEAD: The schedule of new Treasury issues for this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills and tomorrow's auction of seven-year notes.

LEAD: In a fiscal sleight of hand, the Federal Government has begun delaying payment of Medicare bills by 10 days as a means of stretching out payments and cutting $815 million from this year's budget deficit. On Oct. 1 the delay will be extended to 14 days on the nearly $80 billion of Medicare claims that hospitals, physicians and individuals are expected to file in the 1989 fiscal year.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about Spanish-language television misstated the 1987 after-tax income of Hispanic households in the nation. The correct figure is $115.6 billion.

LEAD: Daniel Lim is suffering from hypergamy, a widespread ailment that is causing Singapore's Government serious concern about the future of its economy, social structure and national defense.

LEAD: Government and industry officials said a likely result of this week's disaster on the Piper Alpha oil platform in the North Sea, in which 166 workers are presumed to be dead, is that there will be major safety-minded features in future oil rigs.
LEAD: ''Dubbelspoor'' was a theatrical conjuring trick. It was all done with mirrors.

LEAD: Maxwell's Plum, the flamboyant restaurant and singles bar that, more than any place of its kind, symbolized two social revolutions of the 1960's - sex and food - closed abruptly yesterday. LEAD: THE 19-year-old Warren, Gorham & Lamont, which publishes more than 300 titles for professional readers, has never created a magazine until now.

LEAD: Since 1975, N. W. Ayer Inc. has held a minority interest in Charles Barker P.L.C., of London, and Barker has had a subsidiary called Ayer Barker. Now, Ayer plans to acquire a 25 percent position in Ayer Barker and will work toward total ownership. This will not affect its equity in Charles Barker, which is now at 12.7 percent.

LEAD: Campaigns have always cost money but never the breathtaking $25 million it now takes to win the Presidential nomination of either party. Fund raising always mattered, but never was it so demanding, ceaseless and pivotal as it is today.
LEAD: Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday and charged in the arson fire of an abandoned schoolbus last week and in the death of a 35-year-old woman who had been sleeping inside, the police said.
LEAD: In District 4 in New York City parents can enroll their children in any one of the district's 33 elementary school or 19 junior high school programs.

LEAD: Bobby Jones spent nearly a month in England and Scotland in preparation for the 1926 British Open, which he won after hitting a spectacular 175-yard bunker shot to the 17th green in the final round at Royal Lytham and St. Annes, a links course in Lancashire, on the west coast of England.

LEAD: When the Yankees resume the season on Thursday, they will send the hitting of Rickey Henderson, Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield and the relief pitching of Dave Righetti against recent history. The way the Yankees have played in the past few weeks, recent history may be favored to win.

LEAD: In Malaysia, the idea of an independent judiciary is old hat, as musty a notion as freedom of the press and the rule of law - as outdated, even, as the nation's feisty 85-year-old founder, Prince Abdul Rahman.

LEAD: You can't get off to a better start than Lillian Gish, now in her 90's and still managing to hit just the right balance between fragility and feistiness. LEAD: The six advertising agencies that have been selected as finalists for the International Business Machines account, billing in the neighborhood of $150 million, are scheduled to receive identical creative assignments this week.

LEAD: About four years ago, when Placido Domingo first offered to sing a free concert in Central Park as a gift to his fans in New York, the Parks Department told him it would be a lovely gesture, and that the city's security and sanitation services would cost him around $400,000. There would also, of course, be the expense of hiring an orchestra and renting a stage and a sound system, along with the crews to oversee them.

LEAD: Even one year ago, it would have been difficult to imagine the Pentagon wining and dining the Soviet Union's top military officer, let alone piping him aboard an aircraft carrier for an air show. Yet Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev was treated to precisely those events and more last week as he began a six-day visit to the United States.

LEAD: A study by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company recommended that part of the Social Security system be made private to avoid the temptation of squandering the huge surpluses accumulating in the system's trust funds.

LEAD: After months of controversy, the leadership of the Episcopal Church has shown itself unwilling to depart from traditional church teachings about sexual morality but also unwilling to rule out change in the near future.

LEAD: Minnesota has threatened to revoke the license of the Chubb Insurance Companies if it refuses to issue drought-insurance policies to about 1,000 farmers who paid for more than $40 million in coverage.

LEAD: The World Bank, facing small but rising delinquencies on its loans for the first time in its history, has quietly raised provisions for loan losses to $500 million, from $100 million, according to bank officials.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis breathed the crisp mountain air this morning, strolled along a spectacular alpine lake and climbed atop rocks for a better view of snow-capped Rocky Mountain peaks.

LEAD: The closer the Rev. Jesse Jackson gets to the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta next week, the more he talks about it as a celebration of his campaign. Mr. Jackson speaks of the thousands of supporters who will join him there, the issues they will raise and the history they will make.

LEAD: The production of ''Rigoletto'' that the New York City Opera introduced on Saturday evening had two bankable assets: the voices of Faith Esham and Richard Leech. Miss Esham as the virginal Gilda and Mr. Leech as her lecherous seducer, the Duke of Mantua, gave a patina of Verdian authority to a performance that otherwise dealt, at best, in promissory notes.

LEAD: Like other big American investment firms, Goldman, Sachs & Company has found that intense competition has diminished the allure of the ''Big Bang'' of deregulation in London's stock and bond markets.

LEAD: A defender who misjudges early in the play, giving the declarer some help, should not be too quick to apologize in the post-mortem. LEAD: When the army staged a coup d'etat in Haiti earlier this month, a handful of foreign reporters climbed to a creaky upper veranda of the Grand Hotel Oloffson to peer into the steamy darkness in the direction of all the shooting.

LEAD: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he believed the Tawana Brawley case would have been settled by now by the courts or by the criminal justice system if it had not been a front page story for so long.

LEAD: Army troops mounted a big rescue operation today after the death toll in annual floods rose to at least 121 people, forcing large-scale evacuation. At least 5 million people have been affected. An official at the Relief Ministry said soldiers were moving marooned people to safer areas but that rescue operations were difficult in the northeastern district of Sunamganj because all the roads were under deep water.
LEAD: A growing number of senior Iranian officials are warning that an acute economic crisis combined with the burdens of the war with Iraq are endangering the Iranian revolution.

LEAD: The European Community announced on Friday a provisional dumping duty on Japanese daisy-wheel computer printers. The action follows the decision in late May to place a similar duty on the makers of dot matrix computer printers. The commission said a duty of 43.2 percent would be imposed on the daisy-wheel printers made by all companies except the Tokyo Electric Company and the Tokyo Juki Industrial Company, whose printers will be taxed at a lower rate of 12.4 percent.

LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said its net income for the second quarter rose sharply from a year earlier. Earnings in the quarter totaled $23.5 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share. Revenue rose 22.8 percent, to $308.1 million, from $250.8 million.

LEAD: Choreographers like to work with Harry de Wit. And it is easy to see why. LEAD: USING a computer can be a pain in the neck, the back, the arms, the wrists, the shoulders, the knees, the eyes and virtually every other part of the body. It doesn't have to be that way.

So said Gen. Henri Namphy last week as he ripped up Haiti's 1987 Constitution, the last tangible vestige of his country's recent bid for democratic change.

LEAD: PICTURE the scene: A team of doctors has just identified a strange and apparently new form of arthritis that showed up in Lyme, Conn., and they want to name it appropriately. They decide to call it ''Lyme arthritis,'' and thereby unwittingly manage to insure a certain measure of confusion about that disease for years.

LEAD: Interest rates at the weekly auction of Treasury bills rose modestly yesterday, and now stand at the highest level since the middle of last October,when rising interest rates were one factor blamed for the sharp drop in stock prices.

LEAD: Six days after medical debris began turning up on New York area beaches, city and state officials were still unable yesterday to say where the material came from, what infections, if any, it might cause and how great a risk to public health it posed.

LEAD: A helicopter plucked three inmates from a state prison yard amid of gunfire today. The helicopter was later ambushed by state police and forced down here after an aerial chase, state officials said.
LEAD: As courts and local governments begin to unlock the doors of all-male clubs to women, the Y.W.C.A. is resisting rising pressure to open jobs and membership to men.

LEAD: Watching ''The Struggles for Poland,'' the absorbing new public broadcasting series on that unlucky nation's efforts to find independence, you may wonder how anybody ever came up with the notion of a Polish joke.

LEAD: Nancy Colbert Friday, the writer, and Norman Pearlstine, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, were married last night at the Rainbow Room in New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: New Rules for Banks The United States and 11 other nations will require banks to keep more capital on hand, forcing some to raise billions of dollars. Page D1. Gorbachev in Poland Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in Warsaw, urged a meeting of European leaders to seek a breakthrough on cutting conventional arms.

LEAD: Dwight Gooden, the National League all-star team's starting pitcher for the second time in three seasons, recalled making the discovery that there is something worse than missing the All-Star Game break and its three highly anticipated days of rest. And that is an enforced rest.
LEAD: Thursday is novice day at Orchard Hills public golf course. ''You're on your own now,'' the cashier, John Rogers, says after taking the golfers' money. ''Wear a helmet and goggles.''

LEAD: Lev Polugayevsky started badly but finished strongly to win the Sweden International Chess Tournament held May 9-21 in Haninge, a suburb of Stockholm. The 53-year-old Soviet grandmaster, a former world championship candidate, topped an almost-all-grandmaster field with an 8-3 score.

LEAD: Hasbro Inc. said it had reached an agreement with Coleco Industries to buy part of Coleco's indoor and outdoor children's furniture and ride-on toy product lines for $21 million. Two manufacturing plants in Amsterdam, N.Y., that were recently closed are also included, the company said.

LEAD: Baedeker, the trusted world-travel guide, offers some forbidding advice to a horseplayer visiting Japan: ''Betting is under state control and offers poor odds. In particular the system is so complicated that it is virtually impossible for foreigners to participate.''

LEAD: The Martin Agency of Richmond, a subsidiary of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which in turn is part of the Ogilvy Group, has signed a letter of intent to acquire Market Source, also of Richmond. Martin plans to merge Market Source, which specialized in direct response services, into the Steinrich Group, its own direct-response company.
LEAD: An announcement today is planned by the Federal Home Loan Banks on the interest rates for a three-part bond offering totaling $2.805 billion.
LEAD: An appeals board of the General Services Administration yesterday denied the United States Postal Service's request for reinstatement of its contract with the Texas entrepreneur H. Ross Perot.

LEAD: Officials from the United States, South Africa, Cuba and Angola met under conditions of strict secrecy on Governors Island in New York Harbor yesterday in the latest round of talks designed to reach agreement on a Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola and black majority rule for South-West Africa.

LEAD: Rorer Group Inc. said the United States District Court in Richmond had ordered the A.H. Robins Company to pay a $25 million fee for terminating its merger agreement made last year. LEAD: The Imperial Sugar Company of Sugar Land, Tex., which acquired the Holly Sugar Corporation of Colorado Springs, has changed its name to the Imperial Holly Corporation but will continue to market the brands separately.

LEAD: The ability of a microscope to reveal fine detail in a sample illuminated by ordinary light is ultimately limited by the wavelength of the light itself. If an object is smaller than a single wave of the light striking it, no lens, however powerful, can form an image of the object.

LEAD: Clinton House, who survived 14 months with a donated heart and lungs he received after donating his own healthy heart in the nation's first domino donor transplant, died today, Johns Hopkins Hospital said.

LEAD: The Cooper Companies said it had received indications that several outside companies were interested in buying each of its three main businesses. They are medical diagnostic systems, contact lenses and related products and surgery equipment.
LEAD: * Alan Neadle was promoted to executive vice president at Princeton Partners.

LEAD: Investors shrugged off a flow of positive news yesterday and the stock market closed modestly higher. It was the third-slowest trading day of the year, with 123.3 million shares changing hands, down from 136.1 million on Friday.

LEAD: Eastern Airlines Inc. has reported a 15.7 percent decline in passenger traffic in June and said it reflected its continued ''downsizing.'' Revenue passenger miles, the number of miles flown by paying passengers, fell 18.6 percent for the first six months of 1988, compared with the first half of 1987.
LEAD: The unparalleled opposition showing in the elections last week is being interpreted here as an indictment of Government policies that brought Mexico six years of economic stagnation.

LEAD: Everyone wants to do business at New York's busiest corners: missionaries and card sharps, break dancers and book salesmen - and, as always, vendors. Many peddle merchandise but none serve so basic a need as the food vendors. In this age of budget gourmetry, they have gone from hot dogs and peanuts to falafel, shish kebab, egg rolls and deluxe ice cream.

LEAD: It is likely that the performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, on an outdoor stage at Battery Park City in the early evening on Saturday and Sunday, will prove to have been one of the highlights of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. Mr. Cunningham believes in making dances that can fit into a variety of spaces.
LEAD: Two people were killed this morning when a N.J. Transit commuter train collided with their van as it crossed an intersection in this northern New Jersey suburb, the authorities said.
LEAD: Richard D. Farman will become the chairman and chief executive of the Southern California Gas Company, the nation's largest gas utility, effective Jan. 1, 1989.

LEAD: When the White House announced Monday that the United States would compensate the families of the 290 people who died on Iran Air Flight 655, only the circumstances were new. The practice in which one country makes amends for misfortune visited on another country's citizens has deep roots in modern diplomacy and international law.

LEAD: A Federal judge indicated yesterday that he intended to create a special commission with the power to carry out his court-ordered housing desegregation plan in Yonkers, bypassing a recalcitrant City Council that has refused to put his order into effect.

LEAD: In general, a partnership that finds a satisfactory major-suit fit has no reason to look further. But it is also true, and obvious, that 9 trumps are better than 8, and 10 are better than 9.

LEAD: Balloon angioplasty, the medical procedure in which a tiny balloon is inflated inside a blood vessel to clear a blockage, is growing in popularity among doctors as an alternative to coronary bypass surgery. A thin tube, or catheter, is inserted into a blood vessel and the balloon inflated so that it pushes the blockage, called plaque, back against the vessel walls.

LEAD: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, selected by Michael S. Dukakis to be his running mate, will continue his bid for a fourth term in the Senate, a dual campaign made legal in Texas in 1959 to let Lyndon B. Johnson run two races. If Mr. Bentsen wins both races this year, his Senate seat would become vacant in January.

LEAD: Most people who live in Los Angeles, and certainly visitors to the city, probably have no real sense that there's a major strike going on here and that a group of writers has brought the entire show-business industry to its knees. They may have read or heard about the strike in passing, or seen a few scattered picketers, but in a sprawling city like this one, a strike is almost invisible to the untrained eye.

LEAD: The AIDS-related tests used on blood samples from beach debris detect antibodies to the AIDS virus, substances the body produces in response to the virus. Their presence in a specimen would not necessarily mean that live, infectious viruses were still present. That could only be determined by attempting to grow the virus from the sample, which takes weeks and is unreliable.

LEAD: A year ago, the West Coast sunset provided the American League hitters with a convenient excuse. They couldn't score a run because they couldn't see the ball. LEAD: Two months before a Boeing 737 jetliner was ripped open on a flight in Hawaii in April, the manufacturer told the Government that special tests had verified the effectiveness of a design feature to prevent explosive decompression. Other experts had warned that this design might be inadequate.

LEAD: Joshua L. Logan, the director of some of Broadway's most enduring and prestigious hits, among them ''South Pacific,'' which won the Pulitzer Prize, and ''Mister Roberts,'' died yesterday afternoon at his Manhattan home. He was 79 years old and had suffered for many years from supranuclear palsy, a debilitating disease.

LEAD: The most twisted, hair-raising and scream-inducing landmark in New York City was created yesterday when the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island was given official status by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

LEAD: President Reagan has decided to pay compensation to families of those who died in the Iranian airliner mistakenly shot down by the U.S.S. Vincennes. That's plainly the right decision. But it prompts a tough question: Should compensation be linked to other goals, like return of the American hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon, or an end to the Iran

LEAD: When a team of New England college football All-Stars embarks on a 17-day goodwill mission to England today, the purposes of the four-game trip will be to teach basic football skills, to provide some exposure to Europeans and perhaps to give John Miller a taste of victory.
LEAD: Dr. Heinz Joseph Wittig, a pediatrician and head of the allergy division at the Ochsner Clinic, died at his home here Sunday after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
LEAD: The Harvard Business School is expected to announce shortly that it will require entering M.B.A. students to take a three-week course on business ethics.

LEAD: In the latest skirmish in a simmering feud between the Guardian Angels and the New York City police, 11 Guardian Angels were arrested early yesterday after they surrounded two plainclothes officers in a Manhattan park. The police said the officers were in the park to investigate complaints that the civilian patrol group was harassing homeless people.

LEAD: In sweltering Faneuil Hall yesterday, Michael Dukakis announced what he called his first Presidential-caliber decision, his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas to run with him. It's a shrewd, audacious decision, likely to advance the Democrats' chances.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: After an investigation that revealed improper personal use of gifts and services, Neale Stoner, the athletic director at the University of Illinois since 1979, is expected to resign within two days, according to Morton Weir, the school's chancellor. Weir said that Stoner had used athletic association employees to perform personal work and would step down as soon as details of an agreement are reached.
LEAD: As their All-Star teammates were chatting, taking batting practice and posing for pictures, the three representatives of the Yankees were forced to conduct a too-familiar ritual.

LEAD: What a pleasure to have the Bartok Quartet in New York performing music by the man whose name it bears! Saturday night's concert at the 92d Street Y offered the Third, Fourth and Sixth of Bartok's String Quartets. They were played by four splendid Hungarian compatriots.

LEAD: Claire Shulman, Borough President of Queens, is asking the Board of Estimate to reconsider its earlier approval of the 42d Street redevelopment project. She argues that the project has changed significantly since it received the original go-ahead. In particular, she objects to the fact that the project's proposed merchandise mart will be occupied mainly by manufacturers and sellers of furniture and fixtures used in interior decorating.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With rookies scheduled to report by Friday night, it became nine down and three to go for the Jets yesterday when they signed three more of their 12 draft choices. Signing were James Hasty, a cornerback from Washington State, who was the Jets' second pick of the third round; Mike Withycombe of Fresno State, a tackle and the fifth-round pick, and John Galvin of Boston College, a linebacker and the 11th-round choice.

LEAD: Coleco Industries, the toy company that soared to wealth and renown five years ago as the maker of Cabbage Patch dolls, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code late Monday.
LEAD: Panama is refusing to take part in the work of the agency that manages and operates the Panama Canal, State Department officials said today.

LEAD: The Brown Shoe Company, part of the Brown Group of St. Louis, has appointed the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to do advertising for its Naturalizer brand of women's shoes. Its budget is believed to be around $4 million.

LEAD: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, has said whenever he finds himself in a long dull meeting where new ideas for improving schools bump up against bureaucratic obstacles, he reminds himself: ''Why should I get discouraged? Gorbachev is trying to do the same thing.''

LEAD: Most staff members of The Washington Post withheld their bylines and credits from the newspaper yesterday and planned to do the same today in a protest marking the second anniversary of the expiration of their union's contract with the newspaper.
LEAD: Senate Approves V.A. Bill

LEAD: Robert H. Drysdale, the former president and chief operating officer of Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day Inc., a brokerage firm, has been named president and chief executive of another Wall Street firm, the Jesup & Lamont Securities Group.

LEAD: Dozens of severely deteriorated and damaged paintings that the New-York Historical Society is storing in a Manhattan warehouse are not owned by the society but are part of a collection on long-term loan from the New York Public Library.

LEAD: The problem with holding competitive elections in which the outcome is predetermined is that credibility and legitimacy suffer dearly. That is the moral of last week's elections in Mexico, and that is one of the burdens that Mexico's next president will carry into office.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said it intends to sell its semiconductor equipment business to Silicon Valley Group Inc. for undisclosed terms. The parties signed a letter of intent and will try to negotiate a definitive agreement and win the approval of both boards, Government regulators and the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing Allegheny International's Chapter 11 reorganization.
LEAD: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company today reported a 25 percent increase in its first-period earnings from the corresponding period a year earlier.

LEAD: The First Boston Corporation said it would give one of its competitors, Kidder, Peabody & Company, access to its computer system, a move that will help cover the system's cost and help pay for its future development. First Boston developed its advanced global trading and clearance system in 1985. It will allow the companies to do 24-hour trading, introduce new products more quickly and major costs.

LEAD: The Federal Government plans to equip 52,000 pharmacies with computer terminals and programs to keep track of medications and drug expenditures of the nation's 32 million Medicare beneficiaries.

LEAD: Taiwan opened the door to China wider today when its ruling party adopted new guidelines allowing businessmen to make indirect investments in China and permitting some Chinese citizens to visit Taiwan for the first time.

LEAD: Alfred Harvey Wheeler, a social studies teacher in the New York City public school system for 42 years, died yesterday at his home in Huntington, L.I., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: New York City and the firefighters' union tentatively agreed yesterday on a three-year contract that would provide annual 6 percent pay increases, maintaining the traditional economic parity with police officers, but require each firefighter to work 54 more hours a year.

LEAD: New Jersey's Education Commissioner today prohibited Englewood Cliffs from removing its students from a predominantly minority-group high school in Englewood, ruling that a withdrawal would have a ''significant negative impact'' on racial balance and educational quality.

LEAD: A report in some editions of SportsMonday on the Chrysler I Love New York Grand Prix horse show incorrectly described the selection procedure for the United States Olympic Equestrian Team and omitted the names of seven candidates still eligible for the team. A corrective article appears on page A20.

LEAD: Chris-Craft Industries and its partly owned subsidiary, BHC Inc., have filed a lawsuit against Warner Communications Inc., contending that Warner's acquisition of the Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation violates agreements between Chris-Craft and Warner.
LEAD: Societe Generale's New York branch made its first debt offering in the United States yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

Currently, the action is mostly on the East End of Long Island, where wineries and vineyards have proliferated on the North

LEAD: Every day the baby can do something new. It isn't always dramatic, often amounting simply to an added subtlety in a smile or a firmness in a grip. For John Vanbiesbrouck, whose first child was born on June 18, these have been days of wonder for him and his wife, Rosalinde. They have also brought wonderfully useful lessons for him.

LEAD: A janitor who has worked in the same East Harlem apartment building for 23 years claimed a New York State lottery jackpot of $22 million yesterday, making him the second richest individual lottery winner in the state.
LEAD: FROM time to time articles crop up in newspapers noting the recall of ceramic ware because of high levels of lead.
LEAD: SOMETIMES, the rich feed the poor. They contribute to charities, or they volunteer in soup kitchens. But often, the poor feed the poor.

LEAD: ''The Dead Pool'' is the fifth film in which Clint Eastwood has appeared as Harry Callahan, the San Francisco cop introduced in ''Dirty Harry'' in 1971. Harry is still the sort of guy who believes that if you spare the rod you spoil the psychopath. When in doubt, shoot.

LEAD: Among the things that American Passage, a Chicago advertising company, has been doing is representing military and college newspapers to national advertisers. It has also been selling ad space on college newspaper racks.
LEAD: The attitudes of many Americans appear to have shifted sharply against the use of illegal drugs in the last year, according to a study released yesterday.

LEAD: President Reagan formally selected Dick Thornburgh, a former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania, today as his new Attorney General, and lawmakers from both parties praised the choice and predicted quick confirmation by the Senate.

LEAD: ''The Massachusetts and the Texas axis was good for the country and good for the Democratic Party in 1960 and it's going to be a real winner in November of '88.'' - Senator Lloyd Bentsen, on his selection as the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate. [ A1:6. ]

LEAD: The Agriculture Department, in a long-awaited report, estimated today that the drought would cut the nation's corn harvest to 5.2 billion bushels, 2.1 billion less than was expected when the crop was planted.

LEAD: Half the nation's major cities face potential deficits this year and most are increasing fees for services in an effort to narrow budget gaps that many attribute to cuts in Federal aid, a report by the National League of Cities said today.

LEAD: The latest battle in the orange juice wars ended yesterday when the Coca-Cola Company, which had begun promoting its new Minute Maid Premium Choice orange juice as ''straight from the orange,'' agreed to drop those words from its packaging.

LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices fell yesterday, as securities dealers said investors stayed on the sidelines in advance of today's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman.

LEAD: Chanting ''We want respect'' and ''We don't want to be scapegoats,'' dozens of 911 operators and dispatchers spent their lunch hours and breaks demonstrating in front of Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan yesterday, protesting what they said was generally poor treatment from the Police Department.

LEAD: American warships in the Persian Gulf do not routinely monitor civilian air traffic control channels and have not been ordered to do so since the American downing of an Iranian airliner last week, Navy officers said today.

LEAD: The Cherokee Group, which last month rejected a $12.50-a-share bid by management to take the company private, said it had received a sweetened $13-a-share offer, or about $161 million, apparently from the same group. James P. Argyropolous, chairman and chief executive of Cherokee, a women's clothing and shoe company based in Sunland, Calif., said the investor group was interested in friendly deal.

LEAD: SURELY suffering from writer's cramp for autographing so many copies of his best-selling autobiography, Dave Winfield set only one All-Star Game record with a fourth-inning double, tied only one other record and scored the winning run last night in the American League's 2-1 victory.

LEAD: Tennis Shriver Gains: Playing her first tournament since losing in the semifinals at Wimbledon, top-seeded Pam Shriver advanced yesterday to the second round of the Virginia Slims of Newport tournament. Shriver, ranked No. 4 in the world, defeated Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., 7-5, 6-1.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who just the previous night said he would accept the Vice-Presidential nomination if offered it, greeted the selection of Senator Lloyd Bentsen today with an icy refusal to either embrace or condemn the prospective Democratic ticket.

LEAD: A mudslide killed 35 workers at a power station in southwestern China, where flooding after heavy rains had already claimed 76 lives, the official New China News Agency reported today. The slide also injured 10 workers when it swept through an electric generating plant in Sichuan on Sunday evening, the agency reported.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis reached for regional and ideological balance today and selected Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as his running mate, counting on the conservative Democrat to strike at the heart of Vice President Bush's Southern base.

LEAD: Soviet and Afghan attacks on positions captured by Afghan insurgents have recently stalled and in some areas reversed the guerrilla campaign to topple the Kabul Government, Western diplomats said today.

LEAD: Talk about a more stable European security relationship is burgeoning, but it isn't getting anywhere yet. Mikhail Gorbachev sounds impatient. Now he offers pan-European summit talks, like his Reykjavik meeting with Ronald Reagan, and removal of 72 U.S. fighter-bombers in return for withdrawal of some Soviet planes in Eastern

LEAD: Bela Karolyi, who on Saturday resigned as head of the United States women's gymnastics delegation to the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, said yesterday he would not attempt to tutor his pupils from the sidelines in future Olympics the way he assisted Mary Lou Retton in 1984. ''This is an even greater problem than we had in 1984,'' said Karoly.

LEAD: No one thinks of Michael S. Dukakis as a big risk-taker. But his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as a running mate represents a series of gambles that the Massachusetts Governor's admirers see as bold and his detractors see as dangerous.
LEAD: * Allegheny Power System Inc., elected as a director Eleanor Baum, dean of the School of Engineering at Cooper Union.

LEAD: COMPANIES Polaroid will sell conventional film, challenging Kodak and Fuji in the $7 billion world market. The change reflects the declining popularity of the instant photography market. [ Page D1. ] Coleco filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors under Chapter 11. The filing by the maker of Cabbage Patch dolls was accompanied by a management shakeup.

LEAD: The United States Equestrian team has announced its list of 16 riders eligible for selection to the Olympic show-jumping team. They must compete in the final trial, which will be held at the Hampton Classic Horse Show July 28-31 in Bridgehampton, L.I.
LEAD: The Deutsche Oper Berlin is to perform two complete cycles of Gotz Fried rich's innovative staging of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the Kennedy Center from June 2 through June 18, 1989.

LEAD: The All-Star Game is that once-a-year showcase where allegiances to one's hometown team are momentarily discarded in favor of reverence for the game itself. But for many baseball fans, there are no allegiances to discard. That's because they have no team.

LEAD: There once was the commercial, you may remember, in which a soap-opera actor proceeded to hawk a pharmaceutical product. ''I am not a doctor,'' he said, ''but I play one on television.'' The exploitation was so blatant that most viewers hooted. Tonight at 10 o'clock on NBC, ''Modern Medical Breakthroughs'' is a touch more subtle.
LEAD: What kind of cents-off coupons have the highest redemption rate?
LEAD: The House of Representatives, tackling one of the most politically sensitive issues in Congress, approved legislation today to expedite the process for closing obsolete military bases.
LEAD: Dave Carazo, the 43-year-old head pro at Tuxedo in Orange County, shared the lead and the credit after the first round of the Michelob New York State Open golf tournament today.

LEAD: Riding a wave of popularity for its latest microprocessor, the Intel Corporation reported today that its net income nearly tripled in the second quarter from a year earlier.

LEAD: Prices of all farm crops rebounded yesterday as the futures market awaited the Agriculture Department's special report on the damage caused so far by the worst drought since the Dust Bowl of the 1930's.

LEAD: The Cullum Companies, the dominant supermarket chain in North Texas, said today that a group including its top management and a private investment fund headed by Morgan Stanley & Company had offered to buy Cullum for $360.8 million in cash.

LEAD: Come with us to a vault deep in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 40 Wall Street. Sit down at a table with a wise old man, Ernest Chambre. Watch as Mr. Chambre sifts through the fraying contents of four heavy boxes. As he skips across the centuries, the story coalescing in front of your eyes is the story of America.

LEAD: Dick Thornburgh's arrival as head of the Justice Department will be as welcome as Edwin Meese's departure. The regret is that the nation couldn't have had an attorney general of Mr. Thornburgh's caliber all along.

LEAD: Whom the gods would madden, they first make writers. This leads inevitably to a requirement for typewriter ribbons. Cat's-paw that I am to these Olympian sadists, I had bought three typewriter ribbons scarcely 10 minutes before the Monday mail arrived with news that they would have to be amortized.

LEAD: A headline in some copies on Monday on a short article about the choice of Carlos Saul Menem as the Peronist presidential candidate in Argentina referred incorrectly to the nominee of the Radical Party. He is Eduardo Angeloz, who was selected in an uncontested primary; President Raul Alfonsin will not seek re-election.

LEAD: The Royal Spanish National Ballet does not have great dancers but proficient ones. No matter. The company's New York debut Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House was greeted with wave after wave of delirious applause.

LEAD: As part of the continuing divestiture of its military businesses, Gould Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Ocean Systems division to the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major military contractor. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The division, which makes underseas surveillance systems for use against submarines, posted revenues of about $100 million in 1987.

LEAD: The International Paper Company said today that it would appeal a ruling that could cost it $25 million in back pay to workers locked out of its Mobile mill. The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that it was illegal for the company to permanently replace 280 maintenance employees at the mill.

LEAD: Federal and private spending on biotechnology research and development exceeded $4.5 billion last year, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment reported yesterday. The spending, coupled with industry sales that for the first time exceeded $1 billion last year, puts the United States well ahead in the international biotechnology race, industry experts said.

LEAD: The second of two Soviet spacecraft bound for Mars was launched from the space center at Baikonur today. It and the craft launched Thursday represent the first missions to Mars since the American Viking probes arrived in 1976.

LEAD: More than a thousand New York City food vendors, chanting anti-Koch slogans, marched on City Hall yesterday to protest the Mayor's ban on food vendors in congested areas of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

LEAD: WHEN strip shopping centers first appeared on the suburban landscape in the 1950's and 1960's, they typically were no-frills structures consisting of little more than long flat-roofed buildings with little visual appeal.

LEAD: On trial in Toronto's provincial court on charges of assault during an incident which occurred in a National Hockey League game in January, Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars, pleading not guilty, testified Monday that he was acting in self defense and that the play in question was ''part of the game.
LEAD: Reflecting the slowdown in its brokerage business, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that its profits fell 35.8 percent in the second quarter.

LEAD: When Samuel de Champlain visited this New World island in 1604, he was struck by the rocky summits of the mountains that rise dramatically from the sea and dominate the sailor's view. The French explorer named the place l'Isle des Monts-deserts, or the Isle of Bare Mountains.

LEAD: Citibank, the nation's largest bank, will triple, to $3,000, the average minimum monthly balance it requires for customers to avoid fees for checking accounts and the use of automatic teller machines.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed more strength in the week ended yesterday than they have in more than a month.
LEAD: Just when you thought you had heard everything important about Lloyd Bentsen comes a new book, The American Sampler Cookbook.

LEAD: Three years ago Loran Fraser, an official of the Interior Department's National Park Service, was temporarily assigned as deputy executive director of the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors, a panel appointed by President Reagan to make recommendations for long-range land and outdoor recreation policy.

LEAD: The Young Choreographers and Composers in Residence project of the American Dance Festival annually brings dancers and musicians together to explore common artistic concerns and to collaborate on new works that are eventually presented at a public concert. Judging from the dances shown Monday night at Reynolds Industries Theater on the Duke University campus, this year's young choreographers and composers had the jitters.

LEAD: Steve Bauer of Canada held on to a slight lead today after the Tour de France entered the mountains in a stage won by Fabio Parra of Colombia.

LEAD: TOLD that she looked too young to have voted for Franklin D. Roosevelt more than once, Sylvia Schauman tugged on the hem of her skirt and smiled like a Ziegfeld girl. ''I know, I know,'' she said. ''Everyone tells me that.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: If the State Public Health Council could regulate public smoking, a lot of New Yorkers would be breathing easier by now. But that power, the Court of Appeals ruled last year, rests with the Legislature. Having won its point, the Legislature now owes it to New Yorkers to do its job.

LEAD: IN two stylish country houses, it is the bathrooms, curiously, that underscore the essential differences in approach. One is neo-classical in inspiration, formal without being stuffy; the other, white and breezy without being bland.

LEAD: Interest rates on a $982 million bond issue of the Louisiana Recovery District were reduced by about a tenth of a percentage point because of strong investor demand, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said yesterday.
LEAD: Two 16-year-old Long Island boys who were last seen paddling a surfboard in Long Island Sound Monday afternoon remained missing last night and it was feared they had drowned, officials said.

LEAD: Researchers who studied 105 injured motorcyclists in Washington State have found that public money was used to pay for 63 percent of their care even though they were not receiving public assistance at the time of the accidents.

LEAD: On the eve of his tour of southern Illinois drought areas, President Reagan today signaled his support for a far-ranging drought relief bill agreed to Tuesday by leaders of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees.
LEAD: Viacom International Inc. has put WVIT-TV, Channel 30, up for sale. The station is the NBC affiliate in the Hartford-New Haven market.

LEAD: I REMEMBER being homesick, although I'd rather not. It is one of those things you can't forget if you've experienced it, like sky diving or falling in love with the best-looking boy in the senior class when you are a freshman with bad skin and posture. Except that being homesick is more horrible than either of these, and more resonant, too: that sense that if you were only in one specific ordinary place the nausea would disappear, and the misery, and the palpable sense of unhappiness and disaffection that keeps you only inches from tears except, of course, when you are actually crying.

LEAD: A picture last Nov. 3, with articles about the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution, was published in error. LEAD: Repression and poverty in Vietnam breed ever more boat people. An appalling 1.5 million Vietnamese and other Indochinese have fled since 1975. Each month, new thousands try to escape on flimsy vessels sailing pirate-infested coastal waters. Now they face a fresh peril: compassion fatigue, an official euphemism that amounts to blaming victims for the cruelty of their jailers.

No Image's early set offered the kind of smart, crackling pieces that make Mr. Haynes one of the movement's strongest composers.

LEAD: Multicolored triumphal arches are being erected throughout this capital and across the roads leading to it. Garish signs are going up on grandiose Government buildings, raw, new office towers and shoddy Chinese shops, and chains of Christmas-tree bulbs illuminate them.

LEAD: A VCR alert would not be out of the question for the next three nights. Channel 13 is rerunning some of the best programs ever made for television. Of course, this being public television, the productions were made in Britain. But quality is quality, and here is a windfall both for those who normally disdain television and for those of us who know better.

LEAD: The Royal Spanish National Ballet presented a number of dancers in new roles on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Most notable of these performances was that of Ana Gonzalez in the title role of Jose Granero's ''Medea,'' set to brooding music by Manolo Sanlucar, which takes place in a Spanish village and retells the classic tragedy in a blend of dance styles that includes well-timed outbursts of flamenco as well as ballet and modern dance.
LEAD: Exposure to poison ivy, the summertime scourge of suburbia, should be considered more a dermatological emergency than a nuisance to be salved, according to experts in skin disorders.

LEAD: Hollis Watkins attended his first Democratic National Convention in 1964, when blacks from Mississippi had to scrounge passes to get inside the hall and fight for seats in their state's delegation.
LEAD: State Department officials said today that they hoped to send more diplomats to Nicaragua as soon as possible to show continued support for the political opponents of the Sandinista Government.

LEAD: Dr. Stanley Block Tunick, a lawyer, accountant and educator, died of heart failure on Tuesday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 88 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.
LEAD: Soldiers used tear gas and clubs today to disperse peasants delivering food to striking electrical workers.

LEAD: ABOUT 15 years after the bulls of Merrill Lynch first tested the waters of network television advertising, Thomson McKinnon Securities has finally decided to take the national advertising plunge.

LEAD: A previously unknown group linked with Palestinians said today that it carried out the terrorist raid on a Greek cruise ship Monday. At the same time, the Palestine Liberation Organization strongly condemned the attack.

LEAD: Q. I live in an aging, rundown apartment house and constantly struggle to keep the sinks, tubs and toilet bowls clean. The toilet bowl seems to have a permanent ring around it at the water line. Scrubbing with most household cleansers does not seem to help. Are there any suggestions you can offer?

LEAD: Azerbaijan has rejected an attempt by a predominantly Armenian enclave to secede and join Armenia, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. The action deepens the stalemate in a territorial dispute that has caused months of ethnic turmoil in the southern Soviet republics.

LEAD: Beverly Sills, the director of the New York City Opera and the host of hundreds of operatic performances, charity benefit dinners and awards ceremonies in the last 10 years, plans to return to television with her own afternoon talk show.

LEAD: An Israeli soldier and three Arab guerrillas were killed in a short exchange of fire this afternoon when Israeli troops entered the southern Lebanese village of Libbaya on a search-and-destroy mission, the army said tonight.

LEAD: THERE is a growing tendency among both marine and fresh water anglers to release many of the fish they catch, but this commendable act may be no more than a gesture if the fish is played to exhaustion or roughly handled while being set free.

LEAD: The Energy Department's estimate of $110 billion as the highest cost of cleaning up radioactive and toxic pollution from its bomb-producing plants is far too low, Congressional researchers said today.

LEAD: An extensive survey of modern crafts is so rare that an attempt at such an exhibition becomes a landmark. In the 15 to 20 years since American crafts began to shake loose from their earlier utilitarian background, there have been only a few shows that looked at the whole field.
LEAD: Felix Eyle, a former concertmaster and orchestra manager of the Metropolitan Opera, died of heart failure on July 5 at his home in Hamilton, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: Bernard Rabin, project conservator, standing under the newly restored fresco ''The Apotheosis of George Washington,'' inside the Capitol dome. The fresco, painted by Constantino Brumidi in 1865, will be exposed to the public in stages as the scaffolding is removed. (NYT/Michael Geissinger)

LEAD: Like upwardly mobile immigrants, Huberts restaurant has followed each surge of its success with a move to a better neighborhood. LEAD: Thanks to Lyndon Johnson, Texas law allows Lloyd Bentsen to run for re-election as a Senator at the same time he's running for Vice President. This leeway was written into the state's election code in 1959 for then-Senator Johnson, who had his eye on the 1960 Presidential nomination. While it smacks of opportunism, it actually makes good sense.

The youngsters visited the maternity ward as part of the school's ''I Have a Dream'' class. LEAD: The International Civil Aviation Organization today rebuffed a bid by Iran for a condemnation of the United States for shooting down an Iranian airliner in the Persian Gulf. It voted instead to issue a statement that ''deplored'' the use of weapons against a civilian aircraft but did not mention the United States.

LEAD: Set in World War II Germany, ''The Berlin Affair'' is the story of a married couple sexually obsessed with a total cipher named Mitsuko. First Mitsuko seduces Louise, the brittle but beautiful hausfrau in her art class. Louise's husband, Heinz, works as a Government minister for the Nazis, and is less upset by his wife's betrayal than by the threat it poses to his career.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Major banks raised their prime lending rate to 9 1/2 percent, from 9 percent, confirming the recent trend toward higher rates. The second increase in the prime this year brought it to its highest level since March 1986. The increase may affect consumer spending but is unlikely to be a major drag on the economy.

LEAD: ''Die Hard,'' the movie that gambles a $5 million salary on Bruce Willis, has to be the most excessive film around. It piles every known element of the action genre onto the flimsy story of a New York cop who rescues hostages from a Los Angeles office tower on Christmas Eve. LEAD: Enthusiasts continue to pay extraordinary prices for exceptional examples of Americana. Last month a historical clock, a rare silver service, a Windsor chair, a cigar-store Indian, several firemen's hats and three major pieces of lighting and furniture designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, John Henry Belter and Gustav Stickley brought prices that took everybody by surprise.

LEAD: A mural by Red Grooms and a sculpture by Duane Hanson are lively additions to an exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery through Aug. 7. They are the highlights of an informal showing of post-1950's items from the gallery's permanent collection.
LEAD: THE new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, must at times long for the relative calm of the Texas courtroom he left behind.
LEAD: A four-day celebration of the ratification of the United States Constitution by New York State opens here next week in the city where it was voted on 200 years ago.

LEAD: Q. The front of my wood-burning fireplace is made of off-white color bricks. From constant use, some of the bricks under the mantle have blackened. I would like to restore the chalky off-white appearance that the bricks originally had. How can I do this?

LEAD: James LeMoyne's article ''Testifying to Torture'' (June 5), includes testimony of a sergeant in the Honduran Army who reports having been trained by the Central Intelligence Agency in Texas in various forms of psychological torture: forcing prisoners to stand for prolonged periods, keeping them naked in isolated cells.
LEAD: FOR months, Richard and Linda Pallitto sought a summer home on the water - so they bought a boat.

LEAD: At St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church in Bear Creek, Pa., Patricia A. Burke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Burke of Moorestown, N.J., and Bear Creek, was married yesterday to Thomas L. Savage, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Savage Jr. of Chadds Ford, Pa. The Rev. Donald J. Grimes performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The judge has spoken. There will be no immediate free agency for some 300 National Football League players, but the cheers or sighs of relief from 28 owners and their commissioner ought not to be too loud. Judge David Doty all but promised the players' union that they would win their antitrust suit if it comes to trial.

LEAD: The second half of ''Victor,'' a dance-theater piece by Pina Bausch, begins with a woman making exactly the same arm-rotating gestures that William Forsythe uses in ''Steptext.'' These are taken from the exercises and movement ''models'' developed by the German modern-dance pioneer, Rudolf von Laban.

LEAD: Wobbly wooden fence posts are a nuisance and can lead to the loosening of additional fence parts. Frequently, particularly if the fence is less than five years old, loose posts are the result of improper installation and can be corrected relatively easily.

LEAD: The United States Olympic track and field trials produced its three qualifiers in the 20-kilometer walk today but not before an unusual finish and the disqualification of the apparent third-place finisher for ''creeping.''

LEAD: As part of his punishment for drunken driving, John Norfolk was ordered by a Maryland court to attend Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. But Mr. Norfolk, an atheist, found going to A.A. a bit too much like going to church.

LEAD: Atlanta and its surrounding area are rich in sites important to the history of blacks in the United States - museums, neighborhoods, historic sites, even individuals with stories to tell. Any single excursion out of Atlanta can be completed in a day, starting in the city and ending back there in the evening.

LEAD: ABOUT 14 years ago the National Association of Home Builders introduced a program that would provide warranties on new homes. The aim was to stem the tide of consumer outrage over shoddy workmanship and fly-by-night builders who never seemed to be around to make good.

LEAD: American women, in general, have held off buying new clothes for more than a year, producing the longest dry spell for women's apparel in more than four years. Because sales of women's and girls' clothes represent about 60 percent of all clothing sales, this has severely affected the nation's retail sales.

LEAD: For several weeks a 900-year-old sculpture has been gathering dust in a storeroom at the Art Institute of Chicago while officials here and in Thailand argue over its fate.
LEAD: Too many workers are being killed on the job, especially in construction, because of Federal and state laxity in criminal prosecution, a private research foundation reports.

LEAD: The Chicago Cubs and the Los Angeles Dodgers were tied, 2-2, in the ninth inning today when rain forced postponement of their game. The game will be replayed in its entirety as part of a doubleheader Sunday.

LEAD: In this African delta port, where children run barefoot through oil palm plantations and men pilot dugout canoes through mangrove swamps, the arrival of a ship from Europe has often meant disruption.

LEAD: MUCH of the painstaking progress made toward peace in Nicaragua seemed to slip away last week as tension between the Sandinista Government and its critics dramatically increased. The Government cracked down on the political opposition and United States diplomats and confiscated the nation's largest private business.

LEAD: The County Government, which should be encouraging recycling and working to hold down refuse disposal taxes, is doing just the opposite. This results from its failure to enforce the terms of its waste disposal contracts with the local municipalities, and the county's disregard for sound fiscal practices in its dealings with the private carters.

LEAD: FROM the rear deck of their ranch-style home on Henry Street, Christopher and Dianne Lockwood say they once had an extraordinary view of the New York City skyline, particularly at night. And like some of their neighbors in the Farview Heights section of this upper-middle-class Bergen County community of 26,000 residents, they cringe at the obstruction that now impedes their view.
LEAD: NEIGHBORHOOD Housing Services of Stamford, a private, nonprofit corporation, is extending its development activities on West Main Street to include new construction.

LEAD: IN the 1970's, those who wanted to reform welfare saw poverty as the main problem; they proposed to raise benefits and extend coverage to new groups. In the 1980's, reformers are more worried about long-term dependency; most now propose ''workfare'' and other steps to move recipients toward self-sufficiency.

LEAD: Although Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann have titled their summer series ''Beethoven Bravo!'', Bach, Handel and Schubert are also on the programs. There is even one, aptly dubbed ''Ludwig Goes Fishing,'' where Beethoven gets the day off.

LEAD: All times are eastern daylight. 5:45 P.M.: Michael S. Dukakis arrives from Washington with Senator Lloyd Bentsen, his choice for a running mate. 7:00 P.M.: Parties for state delegations begin. 8:00 P.M.: Reception sponsored by Paul G. Kirk Jr., Democratic National chairman.

LEAD: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz paid his annual call on Southeast Asia this month, the region's message to Washington was clear: Don't let the Khmer Rouge go back to Cambodia. The plea seemed urgent because on July 25 in Jakarta, Communist and non-Communist Southeast Asians will meet to start on the tentative, treacherous road to a negotiated

LEAD: IN a city increasingly composed of rich and poor, New York's streets often seem like one of the last bastions of democracy, equalizing all in immobility and gridlock. But with many of the city's arteries clogged most of the time, and with Federal air-quality standards looming that could mandate sharply reduced automobile emissions by the early 1990's, traffic officials are being forced to consider alternatives that could strike at the very heart of the cherished tradition of driving one's own car even in midtown Manhattan.
LEAD: Billy Martin waving to crowd during Old-Timers festivities. (NYT/G. Paul Burnett) Page 3.

LEAD: STUNNED by its worst performance at the polls since coming to power 59 years ago though still strong enough to impose the victory of its candidate, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, Mexico's Institutional Revolutionary Party has been emitting uncharacteristically penitent sounds of recognition that the country wants a change.

LEAD: Ian Buruma sees Singapore as a ''city of homeowners . . . a city without slums, where women can safely walk the streets at night, in many ways an ideal society,'' but suggests that the absence of Western-style democracy makes Singapore a ''city of fear'' (''Singapore,'' June 12). Having years of exposure to Singapore (and a professional relationship with its Development Bank), we have a different perspective.

LEAD: THE United States may be getting battered in the daily headlines, out at Studio Theater the bruised flag is being proudly honored in a rousing revival of ''Tintypes.'' In this intimate musical by Mary Kyte, Mel Marvin and Gary Pearle, we are once again infused with the spirit of adventure of the great wave of immigration that took place around the turn of the century.

LEAD: THE FRAGILE BERRIES and fruits of summer are often best when eaten close to where they are picked. I can remember bringing baskets of strawberries picked in the country one morning to serve in the city for dinner that evening. I imagined placing them in little pastry shells set in a puddle of custard cream.

LEAD: THE GREATEST thrill a man can experience, Winston Churchill was reported to have said, is to be shot at and missed. (If that quotation cannot be found in his works, I have taken a shot at the source and missed.) For a writer, the big thrill is to coin a word or phrase that fills a linguistic void and becomes part of the history of the era.

LEAD: With more than four months to run, the Federal program to bestow legal status on alien farm workers in the United States has already drawn 675,000 applicants, nearly double the number officials originally estimated would be eligible.
LEAD: Boulders Inn on a hillside overlooking Lake Waramaug at New Preston has long commanded a superior view. In fact, for years the viewwas the sturdy fieldstone inn's star attraction.

LEAD: Like chicken soup, Governor Cuomo's new campaign to combat bigotry can't hurt and it may help. But as the Governor acknowledged, it will take more than public relations to improve the racial atmosphere in New York. When the State Legislature convenes again, it should put a bias-crime bill at the top of its list.

LEAD: The 525-foot Melrose Avenue Bridge, which connects Webster and Melrose Avenues in the Melrose section of the Bronx, was ordered indefinitely closed Friday when inspectors discovered piles of concrete blocks, boulders and slag dumped along its west side.

LEAD: WEAPONS are being sharpened these days on the arcane battlefields of literary criticism where recent disclosures that one of the leaders of the field entertained Nazi beliefs have raised a troubling question: How should we treat the reputations of intellectuals who at one time or another have been snared in the trap of objectionable politics?

LEAD: RED geraniums and blue delphiniums stand bright against yellow and orange marigolds in a clash of colors and fragrances that characterizes the summertime Southern garden. There is the heady sweetness of magnolia and gardenia blossoms, black-eyed Susans, daisies, day lilies and azalea hedges. Slate walkways wind through clipped spreads of ivy, with dogwoods, maples, oaks and pines towering over in a leafy mesh.

LEAD: Nearly all the tourists stepping off the bus at a prominent New England vacation spot on the Fourth of July carried cameras. The surprise was that, by a rough count, about one in five was a video camcorder - clear evidence that do-it-yourself video has become a common aspect of American life. The travel season naturally heightens interest in these hi-tech mini-marvels, and it is estimated that nearly two million camcorders will be sold in the United States this year.

LEAD: REMNANTS of the history of blacks in the South are largely hidden, apart from the well-documented heritage trails in main cities. Atlanta, for example, is fairly well preserved: There is Auburn Avenue, a two-mile strip that Fortune magazine once called ''the richest Negro street in the world.'' There is the childhood home of Martin Luther King Jr., the church where he preached and his tomb.

LEAD: Henry Aaron retired as a major-league baseball player in 1976 after hitting 755 home runs, more than anyone else in the history of the game. Now 54 yeras old, he maintains ties to the Atlanta Braves by serving as director of player development, a job that allows enough time at home to give him and his wife, Billye, the chance to sample restaurants all over the Atlanta area.

LEAD: To the Editor: We enjoyed the article about pizza in Provence by Patricia Wells (Travel, June 5), but your readers should know that they can satisfy their cravings for that thin crispy crust and super fresh ingredients here in the United States. A pizza remarkably similar to the finest fare in Aix and Arles is made by Judie's European Baked Goods at 126 Shore Drive in the Short Beach section of Branford, Conn., a few miles east of New Haven.

LEAD: THE partisan bickering that passes for communication among members of the State Legislature reaches its zenith when the subject is automobile insurance, and during last week's heat wave tempers were more frayed than usual.

LEAD: The basketball program at Tulane University, dropped in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal, is scheduled to be resumed in time for the 1989-90 season, and yesterday the school named Perry Clark as the new coach. The 36-year-old Clark, currently an assistant to Coach Bobby Cremins at Georgia Tech, will become the first black head coach in any sport at Tulane.

LEAD: Ines Murillo's story of torture in a prison in Honduras was known in 1983. She was interviewed by members of a delegation representing the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, Americas Watch and the Washington Office on Latin America. Few in authority or the news media had much to say then. Five years and who knows how much suffering later, the Reagan Administration is on its way out, power is shifting and the political climate has changed.

LEAD: I HAD been meaning to fix the floor-level door on the kitchen cupboard that holds sundry things from the larger pots and pans to my modest liquor supply. Several years ago I had the woodwork stripped of some unknown layers of paint and the door has not closed since then.It jams on the bottom of the frame.

LEAD: AS part of the most complex interplanetary endeavor yet attempted by the Soviet Union, two probes have soared into space in the last two weeks to explore Mars and its moon Phobos. While enthusiasts of detente were heralding the launchings as a prelude to a possible Soviet-American manned visit to the planet by 2010, some critics in the Reagan Administration were worried about military implications.

LEAD: THE water was brutally cold. Numbing as it touched the exposed parts of my body where the mask and hood made imperfect seals. My temperature gauge read 51 degrees Fahrenheit, winter water with a summer sun overhead. It wasn't quite summer yet, but it would be soon enough, and as soon as the water temperature rises with mid- and late-summer sunshine, another crisis will begin.

LEAD: HUBERT H. HUMPHREY never tired of proclaiming Democratic dedication to ''the politics of joy.''
