More noise, more disorder, more gleeful fratricide.

LEAD: In the days when Be-bop was the new thing in jazz, people who liked traditional jazz used to be called moldy figs. There's probably another derogatory name now for people who like be-bop, cool, New Orleans or any other mainstream jazz, but if so, it would have to apply to a lot of people. For, to judge by the number and amount of record sales of older jazz, there are plenty of lovers of mainstream jazz out there.

LEAD: To the Editor: In reference to the letter by Prof. Evon Z. Vogt Jr. (Travel, April 24), which recently came to my attention: The tendency to refer in English to the Yucatan is perfectly normal and correct. Just as we say the Ukraine, the Bronx, the Yukon, we say the Yucatan. Spanish usage has no bearing on it.

LEAD: A 35-year-old Brooklyn woman walking home from work early yesterday morning was killed on a Manhattan sidewalk when she was struck on the head by a cinderblock that the police said they thought was thrown from the top of a two-story garage.

LEAD: WHEN government and private groups get together to build low-cost housing, one of the issues they face is what kind of housing makes the most economic sense. The classic high-rise apartment building can put the most families on a given piece of land, but it costs more per unit, while the low-rise town home is cheaper but uses more land.

LEAD: Some of the male and female partners in William Forsythe's ballet ''Love Songs'' - presented by the Frankfurt Ballet at the First New York International Festival of the Arts last month - got no closer to each other than the flashing of dirty looks. And for those who did make contact, it was not by flinging themselves through the air with seeming abandon and then, in the nick of time, being spared a stay in an orthopedic bed by the fireman's catch of a muscular companion; contact was made with a vicious slap or a thrown fist.

LEAD: Some exhibitions are born great and could hardly be improved upon. One of them is the exhibition of drawings by Hans Holbein the younger that can be seen at the Kunstmuseum in Basel through Sept. 4. What makes it unique is that for the first and quite probably the only time the two great surviving collections of portrait drawings by Holbein have been brought together under one roof.
LEAD: THE pairing of ''Hamlet'' and ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead'' could turn out to be inspired, or just plain insipid. The proof is in the performance, not the programming.

LEAD: AS businesses throughout the region continue to follow their employees to the suburbs, creating new commuter patterns at cross purposes with the old, planners are working to unclog roadways never designed for such heavy use. Strategies range from building more roads to developing technology that may someday automatically route computer-equipped cars around traffic jams.

LEAD: The General Accounting Office of Congress is investigating the management of the respected malaria vaccine research program of the Agency for International Development in the wake of charges and countercharges of management irregularities.

LEAD: Before giving my midseason picks, let me suggest the Lou Gehrig award, given to the best offensive player in each league. Then the m.v.p. award would go to those who truly are m.v.p.'s.

LEAD: You could call ''A Fish Called Wanda'' an Ealing comedy that's been time-warped into a world recovering from the impact of Monty Python's Flying Circus. At any rate, that's roughly the way both Charles Crichton and John Cleese see the film, and they're the people best placed to know. Mr. Cleese, who wrote the script and plays a main role, is, of course, a veteran of British television's most wickedly inventive comic series.

LEAD: The article on opportunities in Connecticut for summertime study at the college and graduate level [ ''New Season for Studying: The Summer,'' June 26 ] was remiss in failing to take note of Wesleyan University's Graduate Liberal Studies Program. Founded in 1953 and designed specifically for part-time adult learners, this program is the oldest and largest of its type in the United States.

LEAD: A cautiously worded paragraph of justification in the program notes for Deutsche Grammophon's new ''Winterreise'' recording (423 366-2) reminds us that in recent decades it has been considered unusual or inappropriate for a female singer to perform this work. Christa Ludwig is not the first woman to record Schubert's great cycle in the postwar era, but she is certainly the most celebrated, and hers is the first to be issued on a major label.

LEAD: To the Editor: In response to Practical Traveler of May 22 on jet lag, a phenomenon or myth, depending on one's view: It is the latter in my case. I have made a fair number of trans-ocean flights and have never experienced it.

LEAD: LIKE a phoenix from the ashes, the hottest new attraction in Paris has risen on the site of the Fifth Republic's greatest financial scandal. Where the city's stockyards and abattoirs stood in the 19th century, the de Gaulle government squandered a fortune to build new slaughterhouse facilities that were obsolete before the 1960's, when they were started.

LEAD: THOUGH patent medicines for the common cold abound, the search for new, better and ever faster relief is endless. LEAD: OPTIMISM seems to have changed camps, leaving North America for Europe. As the Reagan era glides bumpily to an end, America appears to be in an introspective and self-doubting mood, fretting about symptoms of decline. But the Old Continent, both its capitalist and Communist halves, is palpably gripped by an unusual sense that momentous changes may be just over the horizon.

LEAD: WHEN I was 19 and full of romantic notions, I made the mistake of visiting the Bois de Boulogne in the warm sun of a summer afternoon. This, I decided then and there, was how life was supposed to be. This was Culture. This was Civilization. To my fevered, innocent eye, the Bois was the perfect embodiment of the dream picture I had painted in my mind of France.

LEAD: David Shults waits in his car. He may be parked by a sidewalk near a suspect's home. He may be in a parking lot at a housing complex or deep in the woods.

LEAD: Engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida intensified their search yesterday for a fuel leak in a space shuttle engine after 40 frustrating hours, increasing concern that the shuttle Discovery will have to be rolled away from the launching pad and its next flight will be delayed for months.

LEAD: The inventor of the wireless telegraph, Guglielmo Marconi, so adored his research ship that he named a daughter after her - Elettra -instead of the other way around. But the ship, which the scientist used as home and laboratory, was destroyed in World War II, and a piece of Mr. Marconi's history was lost with it.

LEAD: WHEN PLANS FOR A NEW STAGE version of Vincente Minnelli's 1944 movie musical ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' were hatched, some of the people who now want to be in it couldn't yet speak, much less sing. It's been four years since the producer Louis Burke got together with Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, composers of the original score (which includes ''The Trolley Song'' and ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas'').
LEAD: The police today banned all events marking Nelson Mandela's 70th birthday and set up roadblocks around Pollsmoor Prison in Cape Town, where the black leader is confined.

LEAD: AMONG the worries economists nag about these days is an apparent loss of liquidity in the stock market. Much has been made of a report from Bridge Information Systems that in 1987 a purchase or sale of 155,000 shares was necessary to move the average stock 1 percent on the New York Stock Exchange, while in 1988 that number was down to 87,000 shares.
LEAD: LIKE most of the key events of the 1988 legislative session, the abrupt break that came yesterday was more an act of resignation than of resolution.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: In 1896, Thomas Burke of Boston won the 100-meter dash in the first of the modern Olympic Games, and not much has changed since then.

LEAD: SOW fresh seed of biennials, either in pots or in nursery beds, where soil has been prepared; if sown directly in the ground, protect seed beds with chicken wire to keep rodents out. Spray hemlocks for control of woolly adelgids. Hedges are growing rampant; prune them back. Snap off watersprouts (upright twigs) from dogwoods; prune or saw out all dead branches/twigs.

LEAD: TOSSED and turned about, the direction of my life is decided by the swelling wave, that enormous multitude called the baby boomers. While I'm not alone, the numbers in my age group are so small I feel like a solitary wraith, an invisible mummy without my wrappings, easily ignored.

LEAD: THE way has been cleared for the development of a $7 million truck plaza and $22 million in additional commercial development at a newly completed interchange on Interstate 80, just outside Youngstown in Trumbull County.
LEAD: BASEBALL
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Commanding leads by skippers in seven of the eight Olympic yachting classes turned the last day of United States trial racing into a formality for the crews involved.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: AT least twice before in this century, crop damage from drought has coincided with a Presidential election campaign. In 1936 and 1956, drought became a national political issue, and, according to agricultural historians and students of the Presidency, 1988 looks no different.

LEAD: Last year, Jeff E. Levine decided that combining a blue-chip neighborhood with ''bread-and-butter housing'' would produce 32 condominium best-sellers. Now, as construction nears completion on 3220 Fairfield Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, a soft residential market has made Mr. Levine look particularly prescient.

LEAD: Federal District Judge Hubert I. Teitelbaum was in no mood to have some woman lawyer calling herself ''Ms.'' in his Pittsburgh courtroom and further offending his sense of propriety by refusing to use her husband's name. He ordered the lawyer, Barbara Wolvovitz, to call herself Mrs. Lobel - her husband is Jules Lobel, a law professor - and threatened to jail her.

LEAD: THE FISTS OF THE THREE-TIME world heavyweight champion, Muhammad Ali, the Greatest himself, were headed straight at my chin. These were the hands that had dissected and demoralized Sonny Liston, then dumped him like old laundry; that had beat upon Joe Frazier so badly he could not go another round; that had reduced George Foreman from a Goliath to a beanbag.
LEAD: WHEN the Fairchild Republic Company's Farmingdale plant closed last year after more than 50 years in operation, it looked like another severe blow for the Long Island aerospace industry.
LEAD: Give me a good catalogue to read anytime. Forget those books you promised yourself you would get to this summer - catalogues have everything.
LEAD: Kirby Puckett should be the American League m.v.p. He has kept the Twins in the pennant race with his .353 average, 11 home runs, 126 hits and 66 r.b.i.'s.

LEAD: WHEN a New York marketing executive was sent to work in London four years ago, his company subsidized his housing costs abroad, handled the rental of his New York home, gave him a car and, as an added inducement, paid for course work that his wife needed to complete her graduate education.
LEAD: THE conversation faltered at the word ''mingled.''

LEAD: HASSELBLAD, the Swedish company known for making medium-format cameras that are ultra reliable and nearly indestructible, has a new model on the shelves. Called the 503CX, it is essentially an update of the company's enduring classic, the 500C/M.
LEAD: I'VE always had the feeling that if I could store my leftovers neatly, the rest of my life would fall into place. A person who has an organized refrigerator has life by the tail.
LEAD: PICTURE this on a steamy summer day: a breezy recreation center, with a refreshing 10-lane swimming pool and open-air cafe, floating serenely on the New York waterfront.
LEAD: Geoffrey Bruun, a historian and biographer who taught at New York University from 1927 until 1941, died of a kidney ailment on Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: The Orioles' manager, Frank Robinson, underwent back surgery yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Donald Long, who removed a disk, said that the surgery went ''very well'' and that he expected a prompt and thorough recovery. Robinson is expected to remain hospitalized for three or four days.
LEAD: Long dismissed as an isolated band of violent fanatics, the Shining Path guerrillas of Peru have spread out from their Andean mountain haven and are emerging as a growing urban political force.
LEAD: THE HEAT DEATH OF THE UNIVERSE And Other Stories. By Pamela Zoline. 204 pp. Kingston, N.Y.: McPherson & Company. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.
LEAD: The temperature dipped to 98 degrees today, but the wind swirled at the United States Olympic track and field trials and helped produce the best performances in history in four events.

LEAD: FRUSTRATION with our current welfare system runs deep. Conservatives see it as a narcotic, encouraging illegitimacy and dependency. Liberals complain that welfare benefits are too small and that the system isolates, stigmatizes, even humiliates recipients. Americans generally oppose its expansion.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: SINCE it is an article of deconstructionist faith that a text has no fixed, single meaning, it probably shouldn't be surprising that books and articles written by deconstructionists are all but impossible for most other people to comprehend. Deconstruction is not just another philosophy, its champions proclaim, but a whole new style of thinking - and, to the consternation of the uninitiated, a way of using language that is based on the assumption that our words can never really say what we mean.

LEAD: The University of Alabama's star tailback, Bobby Humphrey, suffered a broken jaw early yesterday in an attack at a Tuscaloosa, Ala., area nightspot that left another Crimson Tide player slightly injured, Coach Bill Curry said.

LEAD: MANHATTAN is invading Long Island. This time it's more than the summer migration to the Hamptons. New York restaurateurs have found Long Island to be fertile ground. In the last year or two, Italian restaurants have led the parade of transplants: Sempre Vivolo in Hauppauge, Cirella's in Melville, Wainscott's Sapore di Mare and Villa Gattopardo in the village of
LEAD: The sounds of summer camp, missing last year at Camp Siwanoy in Wingdale, N.Y., are filling the woods again to the delight of Cub Scout and Boy Scout troops in the Westchester and Putnam area.

LEAD: Tennis Potter Upsets Shriver: Third-seeded Barbara Potter upset top-seeded Pam Shriver, 7-6, 7-6, yesterday in the semifinals of the $200,000 Virginia Slims of Newport, R.I. Potter of Woodbury, Conn., ranked No. 16 in the world, faces second-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston in the final today.

LEAD: Janet Lee Gilbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Gilbert of Gibson Island, Md., was married yesterday to David Michael Smith, a son of Nancy Reynolds Smith of Boston and Arthur J. Smith of New York. The Rev. Robert Jones performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Chesapeake Roman Catholic Church in Pasadena,

LEAD: Audiences at this year's Pepsico Summerfare festival might do well to check their program notes before the metaphorical curtain goes up in Purchase, N.Y., this week on the Sydney Theater Company's two festival offerings - Ray Lawler's 1955 classic, ''Summer of the Seventeenth Doll'' and Michael Gow's 1987 hit, ''Away.

LEAD: When the Mark Brent Dolinksy Memorial Foundation helped finance the Westchester Conservatory's ''Arts in Education Initiative'' last year, it was just the latest addition to a long list of donations to organizations and projects assisting Westchester adolescents.

LEAD: THERE are players who are spoiled, who are not content to have brought about a winning position but also seem to expect the opponent to lose according to their preconceived plan. When the opponent refuses to just sit there and be mated, these players often lose their concentration - and soon after, the game.

LEAD: If one didn't pay close attention, the new Mostly Mozart season's Thursday evening concert went amiably by. The large friendly audience seemed to like it, though one wonders if its thunderous applause was not as much for Avery Fisher Hall's virtuosic air-conditioners as for the music itself. The latter was by Vivaldi and Telemann, played by Christopher Hogwood and a small band of local musicians known as Music on Original Instruments.

LEAD: David McKendree Key Sr., a retired Foreign Service officer who served as Ambassador to Burma and Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, died Friday of cancer at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: To the Editor: One of my best memories of Madrid on a trip in 1971 was the thirst-quenching taste of horchata. A friend and I used to go almost daily to the little stand in the main park for a glass. Since I didn't speak Spanish, I thought it was made from coconut milk, but as the article by Penelope Casas (Travel, May 1) explained, it is made from an obscure

LEAD: The Warsaw Pact today opened the door a bit to the possibility of unilateral withdrawals of some Soviet forces from Eastern Europe. It stressed, however, that it would do so only after negotiations with the West.

LEAD: There is no airplane on the roof of the new office tower at 17 State Street in lower Manhattan, and there are no neon tubes in the lobby, or gigantic clocks, funny benches or umbrellas out front. Why, at first glance one might almost think that this sleek, thin skyscraper could have been put up by just any builder, and not by Melvyn Kaufman, the man who has made a virtual mission out of making the New York skyscraper entertaining.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH trans-Hudson transportation congestion is worsening at an increasing rate, it seems that the only corrective steps being considered amount to little more than Band-Aids. Moreover, the few practical solutions that have been presented are ''too little and too late.''

LEAD: A caption on page 17 in Television today incorrectly identifies the actors pictured. They are Christopher Connelly and Jodie Foster, who starred in the ABC-TV series ''Paper Moon,'' based on the 1973 film of the same name. The original film is to be broadcast today at noon and Friday at 2 P.M. on the Showtime cable channel.

LEAD: Sometimes I wonder if I am, all unaware, living in one of those reverse-image universes that science-fiction writers assure us exist out there. You know, the world in which large dogs and cats keep cute people as pets or the one where everyone dies at birth and then grows inexorably younger unto eternity.

LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: An article and picture caption in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described the Loehmann's store in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: THE life of a corporate chief executive in Europe used to look something like this: offices stuffed with antiques and oils in a palatial headquarters building with half a dozen fountains adorning the grounds; butlers who trolleyed in tea at the appointed hour. Beneath him were encrusted layers of upper and middle management whose main job seemed to be keeping dozens of chauffeurs and secretaries busy.

LEAD: Responding to an opposition summons to ''defend the popular will,'' more than 200,000 people marched on the National Palace here today to support their charge of widespread vote fraud in last week's presidential election.

LEAD: Retirement has been kind to Bjorn Borg of Sweden. At age 32, his life as the tennis king of the 1970's is a distant memory. ''I retired when I was 26,'' he said yesterday at the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I. ''If I had any regrets, I think I would have been back to tennis a long time ago.
LEAD: Two prisoners were at large today after six inmates escaped during a jail riot in northern England, the British Home Office reported. The four others were captured before dawn.
LEAD: WITHIN OUR REACH Breaking the Cycle of Disadvantage. By Lisbeth B. Schorr with Daniel Schorr. Foreword by Judith Viorst. 398 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $19.95.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-13
LEAD: Equipment can make the difference between ease of preparation and tedious chore. This is especially true in summer.

LEAD: WHAT made me think I could cope with a vegetable garden? We had just retired to Long Island. I was city bred, a lifelong apartment dweller. Now I had a little apron of space, about 8 by 10, that would accommodate a few vegetables.

LEAD: Charles W. Lubin, founder of the Kitchens of Sara Lee, died Friday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, apparently after suffering a heart attack while driving. He was 84 years old. A Chicago native, Mr. Lubin was apprenticed to a baker at the age of 14 in Decatur, Ill. In 1949, he named his first special cheesecake for his 8-year-old daughter, Sara Lee.

LEAD: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., whose liberal views have long alienated him from conservative Republicans, invoked the name of the Rev. Jesse Jackson as he accepted the Republican nomination for a fourth term Saturday.

LEAD: When the National Ballet of Canada opens its weeklong season tomorrow evening at the Metropolitan Opera, its program will include the much-anticipated New York premiere of Glen Tetley's hourlong ballet ''La Ronde,'' based on the play by Arthur Schnitzler and set to a score by Erich Wolfgang Korngold.

LEAD: The drought that has ravaged waterfowl nesting areas in Canada and the United States has produced habitat conditions described by some biologists as the worst they have ever seen. Responding to this, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has already announced plans for more restrictive regulations during the 1988-1989 hunting seasons.

LEAD: Encouraging economic reports sent the dollar soaring. The U.S. trade deficit rose slightly in May, to $10.93 billion. Although higher than the revised $10.3 billion of April, it was the second-smallest imbalance in almost three years. Imports rose 3.4 percent, to $37.6 billion, while exports also increased 2.3 percent, to $26.6 billion.

LEAD: The international agency charged with stopping the spread of nuclear weapons is seeking an automatic right of entry into more than 100 countries for its inspectors, who check that civilian nuclear installations are not being misused for military purposes.

LEAD: A former Yale University lecturer who was stripped of his United States citizenship for his role as a propagandist for the Nazis in World War II, has failed to attend a deportation hearing, and members of his family said today that they believe he has fled the country.

LEAD: To the Editor: Anne Wilson's article notes that Lindisfarne Castle is ''16th-century'' without further comment. Although this date, and its impressive location, may be sufficient reasons for some to seek it out, architecturally minded travelers might like to know that it was extensively rebuilt by Sir Edwin Luytens in 1903.

LEAD: Richard Redgrave (1804-1888) was one of the many painters represented in ''Hard Times,'' the survey of Victorian social realism that was recently staged at the Yale Center for British Art. But he was not the one who most deserved closer inspection. All the same, that is what he gets in the center's current show, ''Richard Redgrave R.A.,'' and evidently it is because he was not just an artist but a curator, educator, designer and, with his brother, Samuel, the author of ''A Century of British Painters.

LEAD: MEMORY OF DEPARTURE. By Abdulrazak Gurnah. (Grove, $15.95.) The mingled anger and longing of an expatriate seeking to come to terms with his homeland inform every page of this fierce, vivid first novel by Abdulrazak Gurnah, a Tanzanian-born writer who now teaches at the University of Kent in England.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: DISPOSING of garbage in American coastal waters has been banned since 1934, so investigators are pursuing the source of the medical wastes washing up on the shores of Long Island and New Jersey. But New York City, Westchester and Nassau Counties and six sewer authorities in Northern New Jersey dump millions of gallons of sludge - treated human wastes and other sewage - into the waters of the

LEAD: AMBUSH AT OSIRAK. By Herbert Crowder. (Presidio, $18.95.) Basically, ''Ambush at Osirak'' is about hardware, the kind of hardware that kills - offensive weapons with cute names like Sidewinder and good-neighbor names like SAM. Herbert Crowder sets this novel of political intrigue and suspense in the Middle East.

LEAD: A year ago, on a tour of a Unisys Corporation plant on Long Island, an aide to Representative Roy Dyson of Maryland was presented several campaign contribution checks by Dennis Mitchell, a Unisys employee. The checks, and several others later mailed, totaled $14,000 and were from business people and others who wanted to see military spending on Long Island increased.

LEAD: The Soviet Union and China have assured the United States that they will use their influence with North Korea to help make the 1988 Olympics in Seoul free of terrorism, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

LEAD: New York State voters favored political campaign ''reform'' but did not support a favorite proposal of Governor Cuomo, taxpayer financing of political campaigns, in a poll released last week by the State Commission on Government Integrity.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court on Friday upheld a Government decision to allow automobile manufacturers until 1993 to comply with a requirement for automatic safety belts in cars equipped with an air bag at the driver's position.

LEAD: The executive board of the teamsters' union picked William J. McCarthy as their new president last week, but it is uncertain how long Mr. McCarthy will stay in the driver's seat. The new head of the 1.7-million-member union defeated Weldon Mathis, the hand-picked successor to Jackie Presser, who died last weekend, in an election marked by rare - for the teamsters - open debate.
LEAD: Nick Chabra with life-size cutouts of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson yesterday.
LEAD: Pakistan has reduced deliveries of weapons to the Afghan guerrillas, American officials said today.

LEAD: ROBERT CAMPEAU'S FIRST JOB was at the International Nickel Company of Canada, in the huge mining complex near Sudbury, in northern Ontario. Giant steam shovels operated round the clock in the open pits, digging huge chunks of ore and dropping them into the dump trucks that rolled in a continuous circuit to the crushing mill and then to the smelter.

LEAD: MANY are the ways to save on hotels and motels. But when it comes to real savings, the way to go is economy lodgings. These are to be found either at plain independent places or at what are called ''limited service'' chains, such as Days Inn, Motel 6, Comfort Inn, Travelodge and Econo Lodge, which the publication Hotel and Motel

LEAD: NEARLY six decades ago Seymour Wyler took a gamble, moving an antique-silver shop his father had operated on Fifth Avenue to a low-rent neighborhood of fruit stands, candy shops, cobblers and grocers.
LEAD: THE land in the Northeast is not as parched as farms in the Midwest and Southeast. Normal rainfall in this region, so far, is down by about 25 percent.

LEAD: THE GLITTERY shades of eyeshadow, the scarlet bullets of lipstick, the clouds of pink blusher - all are mere frippery compared to loose powder. ''Powders can make a woman's makeup,'' says Bobbi Brown, a makeup artist. ''I can easily use nothing but different powders on my face.'' But despite the versatility of loose powders, they've been relatively scarce at cosmetics counters.
LEAD: A caption on page 17 in Television on July 3 misidentified the actor who plays the Cabinet Secretary in the series ''Yes, Prime Minister.'' He is Derek Fowlds.

LEAD: STORIES OF SICKNESS By Howard Brody. 210 pp. New York: Yale University Press. $27.50. THE ILLNESS NARRATIVES Suffering, Healing, and the Human Condition. By Arthur Kleinman. 284 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

LEAD: Jackie Joyner-Kersee completed her remarkable assault on another world record today in the heptathlon, finishing with 7,215 points at the United States track and field Olympic trials to become the first athlete to break 7,200 points, for her third world record in two years.

LEAD: The article 'The Thieves Who Steal History in the Niht'' [ June 26 ] has raised a firestorm. The mischief such biased ''reporting'' has done in the past started with citizens calling the police everytime they saw someone with a metal detector looking for mercury dimes in an old ballfield or sifting the beach for quarters.

LEAD: Livingston $348,000 336 Hillside Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; family room with fireplace, c/a, 2-car attached garage; taxes $4,647. Short Hills $520,000 97 Westview Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; patio, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,813.

LEAD: EQUIPMENT can make the difference between ease of preparation and tedious chore. This is especially true in summer.

LEAD: Anne Power Bonaparte, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bonaparte of Portland, Ore., was married in Stanford, Calif., July 2 to Gilbert Judd Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley G. Williams of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Penelope Duckworth, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Memorial Church at Stanford University.

LEAD: In the clubhouse camaraderie of another Yankee Old-Timers Day, the players on the 1978 World Series championship team shook hands and recelebrated how they had come from 14 games back on July 19 to force the Boston Red Sox into a one-game playoff in Fenway Park remembered mostly for Bucky Dent's home run.
LEAD: A Government plan to equip 52,000 pharmacies with computers to keep track of the medications and drug expenditures of 32 million Medicare beneficiaries has aroused concern about privacy.

LEAD: COGS IN THE WHEEL: The Formation of Soviet Man. By Mikhail Heller. (Knopf, $22.95.) Mikhail Heller, a Soviet emigre and author who has lived in Paris since 1969, has produced a textbook for the school of thought that depicts the Soviet Union as a great machine. Chapter by didactic chapter, he lays out the ideology and methods whereby, in his view, the Soviet citizen is denatured, beguiled, infantilized and frightened into becoming little more than a willing cog.

LEAD: Richmond Terrace was supposed to be the spine of a construction boom on Staten Island's northwest coast. The shoreline drive's harbor views and proximity to the Staten Island ferry were expected to be a magnet for workers in lower Manhattan just starting out. But when Harbour View opened in May at 388 Richmond Terrace, four-fifths of a mile from the St.

LEAD: A 26-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday for the June 21 murder of his ex-girlfriend, the police said. The murder drew wide attention because a 911 dispatcher apparently delayed at least 20 minutes before sending a car to the scene, and the victim was shot while she was making a second desperate call to police.

LEAD: The Riverside Shakespeare Company will give two performances of ''Love's Labour's Lost'' in Riverside Park, 81st Street and Riverside Drive, Wednesday and Thursday at 6 P.M. The show will be repeated in parks throughout the five boroughs Wednesdays through Sundays for four weeks. Information: 877-6810.

LEAD: LAST year I lost my job at a major corporation in Manhattan. I had been commuting there daily from New Jersey for over 15 years. The company gave me a decent severance package, and I immediately did what any reasonable person would under the circumstances: I put in for a refund on my unused bus tickets, and

LEAD: THE great illuminated sign proudly proclaiming Maxwell House Coffee has persisted for generations on the New Jersey waterfront facing the Manhattan skyline. But the one luring people to playtime at the Palisades Amusement Park has vanished with the park itself.

LEAD: To the Editor: While visiting Edinburgh in 1971, I decided to go to Duns, a nearby town, to meet with a British airman with whom I had become friends when we were both in uniform. Not having a car, I was advised to take the train to Berwick in England, where I could get a bus to Duns in Scotland.
LEAD: CRISS CROSS Starring Burt Lancaster and Yvonne de Carlo (in photo), Dan Duryea. Directed by Robert Siodmak. MCA Home Video. $59.95.

LEAD: This may well turn out to be the year of the accessory. As styles for fall become simpler, easily added elements can make or change an outfit. On this and the next page are three women who have chosen to concentrate their creativity on the expensive end of this field of embellishment. Two are new ''labels'' in the game.

LEAD: Leading off the ninth inning today, Kevin Romine hit his first major league home run, capping a comeback from a 6-0 deficit and giving the Boston Red Sox a 7-6 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

LEAD: Regarding your interview with Bruce Llewellyn [ June 26, ''Helping Blacks Get Ahead'' ] , I must comment on Mr. Llewellyn's response to cutbacks on the defense budget: specifically, his quotes, ''Defense spending is the white people's welfare program'' and, ''It's nice to be able to say that instead of going to the welfare office to get my check, I go to Grumman to get my check.

LEAD: GEORGE SAND A Brave Man, the Most Womanly Woman. By Donna Dickenson. Illustrated. 190 pp. New York: Berg/St. Martin's Press. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95. MARIANNE By George Sand. Edited and translated by Sian Miles. 171 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $14.95.

LEAD: My colleague John Rockwell was actually writing about something else, but what he said aptly describes the state of audio: ''Most of almost anything is not very interesting. Some of it is downright meretricious; much of it is mediocre or second-rate. Occasionally something first-rate comes along.''
LEAD: IT seems perverse, but one of the biggest problems facing a new collector is where to find stamps.

LEAD: JUAN MONTOYA WAS LOOKING FOR LAND when he happened on this 1939 stone house. Set amid 110 wooded acres in the Hudson Valley, the dilapidated structure was simply a building waiting to be renovated. And renovate he did, but over time. ''I left the property alone for a year in order to understand the terrain during each season,'' says the interior designer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Fears of a resurgence of inflation cast a pall over the credit market last week, and investor confidence in fixed-income securities is expected to be further undermined in the foreseeable future.

LEAD: Michael S. Dukakis arrived here today for the Democratic National Convention that is to nominate him for President on Wednesday, pledging to seek unity but insisting that he, not the Rev. Jesse Jackson, must be in charge.
LEAD: Yngwie Malmsteen, the 24-year-old Swedish heavy-metal guitarist, started his show from offstage at the Beacon Theater on Friday night.

LEAD: EUGENE CERVI, a crusading weekly newspaper publisher from Denver, made himself very unpopular in publishing circles in the late 1960's by railing against the newspaper industry's efforts to win Federal exemption from antitrust laws. He did not care much for railroads, mining companies or big banks, either, but he held a special place in his spleen for big-city newspapers, including his two hometown competitors.

LEAD: Philip Sills, a Russian-born immigrant who manufactured women's sportswear and collected contemporary American art ranging from cartoons to circus posters, died of lung cancer in his Manhattan apartment Saturday. He was 68 years old.
LEAD: * South Street Seaport to Siegel & Gale.

LEAD: Tiffany's is ready. All its salespeople have been instructed in basic Japanese, including counting. The Fifth Avenue jeweler has laid in a trove of medium-sized, 18-karat-gold Elsa Peretti heart necklaces, which, at $350 apiece, are the single most popular item among Japanese customers.
LEAD: The beach at Jacob Riis Park in Queens was closed to swimming yesterday after park rangers discovered some discarded syringes that they believe had washed up on shore with the morning tide.

LEAD: The continuing rally in the dollar has had short-term benefits, including making imports cheaper and reducing the prospect of higher inflation. But it also hides real long-term dangers, including a slowdown in economic growth and a widening, rather than narrowing, United States trade deficit, according to three new economic studies.

LEAD: Listening to the 18-year-old alto saxophonist Christopher Hollyday play is a bit like hearing a baby speak in a grown man's voice. Mr. Hollyday, who ended an engaement at the Village Vanguard last night, has learned the tricky be-bop vocabulary of Charlie Parker, Cannonball Adderley and Jackie McLean - a vocabulary created from intellectual and emotional maturity under social duress.
LEAD: THE nation's most prominent corporate raider, Carl C. Icahn, may be keeping a low profile these days but Wall Street has a watchful eye on him, nevertheless.

LEAD: This is an ideal city for the Democratic Presidential nominating convention. It is a symbol of the changing world, full of promise and problems, with its slums and skyscrapers broiling in the Southern sun.
LEAD: Ann Richards, who will deliver the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention Monday, has a theory about humor.

LEAD: A former Navy enlisted man who is the subject of an espionage investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been granted political asylum in the Soviet Union, the Soviet press reported today.

LEAD: The long-running debate over whether and how to compensate the Japanese-Americans who were interned in relocation camps in World War II is about to come to an end. A House-Senate conference committee has reached agreement on a new bill, and President Reagan, who was earlier urged by the Justice Department to veto the measure, is now reported as all but certain to sign it.
LEAD: More than 600,000 Mozambicans, fleeing the cruelty of war, have crowded into this tiny country over the last 20 months. Hundreds more come across the border each day, with no end in sight.

LEAD: Sales of mass-market paperback books have been flat for three years, unsold paperbacks are being returned in record numbers and the outlook for the next several years is equally bleak. LEAD: THE American fashion world has been in turmoil for nearly a year. The decline of the dollar, coupled with diminishing supplies of silk and wool yarns, caused prices to rise. Retail sales of women's apparel plummeted. Large companies engaged in a frenzy of mergers and acquisitions, which placed diverse stores under the control of a few huge corporations and put thousands of executives out of work.

LEAD: It has been a long, mean food fight for the few old residents of St. Margaret's House who have refused to take a mandatory daily meal in the cafeteria these last years, and the other day the management served notices to terminate their tenancies. LEAD: Trying to find the cause of defects in the paint on an mini-van hood, engineers identified seven possible causes. In a traditional approach, bottom, extensive experiments in which each possibility is investigated one by one would be conducted, involving as many as 500 different hoods. Using the Taguchi method, top, a brainstorming session is followed by a few experiments with about 40 hoods in which several factors are changed simultaneously, their selection based on statistical techniques.

''Mr. North'' is a comic fable about Theophilus North (Anthony Edwards), a clean-cut Yale graduate who has the self-assurance of a crackpot saint. At the height of the 1926 summer season, Theophilus makes his way through the social maze of Newport, R.I., with the aplomb and springy step of a very young, very American Mr. Hulot. He tutors the children of the rich, teaches them tennis, and reads to the elderly in English, French, German, Italian and Hebrew. He doesn't actually speak Hebrew, but he offers to bone up on it when a client resists his estimate of six weeks to read the Bible in English. Theophilus says that since Hebrew has no vowels, the reading time could be reduced by one third.

It was the Pirates' second loss in 14 games and it dropped them two games behind the first-place Mets in the National League

LEAD: Juli Inkster broke par today for only the third time in 32 rounds of United States Women's Open play and gained a tie for the lead with a couple of surprising Ladies Professional Golf Association rookies in the second round of the 43d United States Women's Open.

LEAD: Feverfew, a type of chrysanthemum that is also known as flitwort and featherfoil, may contain chemicals that relieve migraine headaches and other disorders.

LEAD: Lou Donaldson, an alto saxophonist, is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight. There is a $10 cover with a $7.50 minimum at tables or $10 admission at the bar.
LEAD: The White House announced today that it would impose economic sanctions on Brazil in retaliation for that nation's refusal to protect the patent rights of American drug manufacturers.
